Women with infants in arms coming to her for assistance had fainted on the doorstep from starvation and exhaustion. " Last week I called at the house and found a woman in bed at the point of death from starvation," said the secretary of the Hawthorn branch, Mrs. F. L. Baker. " Only the most generous financial assistance from every available source can prevent the deaths from starvation of many children in the winter we are now facing."

speech.para: Mrs. E. Dare, of Yarraville, said ;
No Christian seeing things as they are could resist the appeal for assistance. Women come to us to help them to save their sick babies.
The Lord Mayor, Councillor Luxton, who presided at the meeting, said -

quote.para: Unemployment is the most serious problem we have to face at present. The position of Lord Mayor would be very pleasant if it were solved satisfactorily. I cannot believe that the Ladies Benevolent Societies will close. The Ministry and the municipalities will have to come to their rescue.

speech.para: Much as I condemn the present Government in Victoria for many things, I honour it for not having allowed the Ladies Benevolent Societies to die. I accuse this Government and every supporter of the proposal to abolish the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, of helping to increase unemployment and its attendant miseries. Ministerial members have said that the Arbitration Court has been a failure. It has, in some matters, but only because there has been too much law, compulsion, and expense, and too little conciliation and justice. I recollect that when the tramway employees federated they had to spend more than ?15,000 to get an award from the Arbitration Court. If it were possible for me to hate anybody I would hate the profession of lawyers, although there have been glorious exceptions - Sir George Grey, Higinbotham, Kingston. Higgins, Deakin, and Sir Robert Stout. I believe that history will add the name of the honorable member for Batman (Mr. Brennan) whose legal knowledge and abilities have been devoted to minimizing industrial disputes. The most valuable factor in the community is a happy home in which the mother knows that her husband has a good billet and that on each Saturday he will bring home sufficient wages to meet the domestic requirements for the week ahead. "When u strike occurs it is the women who suffer most. Well do I remember the hardships that attended the great maritime strike. The man may leave his home for a few hours, smoke a pipe, and temporarily forget his worries, but they are with the mother always. If the children are without clothes or require their boots mended, if the landlord knocks at the door, if the tradesman's bill is overdue, she has to face those troubles. The Suffering of the women and children is one of the greatest curses of strikes and unemployment. We are doing our best to improve the conditions of the workers, but we are limited by the caprice of lawyers. The word " Parliament " is derived from " parler " which means to speak. Every honorable member is sent here to voice what he thinks is right and to denounce what he thinks is wrong. Thi department over which the Attorney-General presides may be a department of law, but it is not a department of justice. Adapting a sentence from Dante's Inferno, I suggest that above the portals of the Attorney-General's Department should be inscribed these words "To Lawbreakers. Abandon hope all ye who enter here unless ye own great wealth ". Is it not a fact that two men who escaped from the law are millionaires? Is it not true that a malefactor, who is living abroad to escape the consequences of his crimes could be brought back to Australia if the Government would threaten to confiscate the immense properties he owns in this country? On one occasion the head officers of the Attorney-General's Department were permitted to accept ?1,000 from a private source. When the Labour party exposed that abomination in this chamber the Prime Minister lost his temper, and I remember my leader saying that if Labour had been in power those officers might have been suspended or even dismissed. Throughout the history of the judiciary, from the days of Judge Jeffreys, I doubt if a greater infamy has been committed than the increase of hours and decrease of wages awarded by the president of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. For many decades noble men belonging to the Liberal and Conservative parties in Great Britain - I have in mind particularly Lord Shaftesbury - have endeavoured to improve the wages and living conditions of the workers. Reform progressed steadily until now, when a judge has increased hours and decreased pay by a legal direction. That infamy may well he the epitaph of the man responsible for it. I well remember the sense of triumph I enjoyed when I was able to insert into the bill introduced by Sir Thomas Bent for the construction of a tramway from St. Kilda to Brighton, a clause providing for a working week of six days of eight hours each, and a wage of 7s. a day. At that time the value of money was greater than it is to-day and the proposal was considered almost revolutionary. Indeed, after I entered the Federal Parliament, the Conservatives eliminated that provision from the act. I remember the Mayor of Brighton stating in evidence before the Railways Committee that the provision in the act relating to the working hours and wages was responsible for the financial failure of the line. Lord Leverhulme, one of the greatest organizers of labour that the British people have produced, and a multi-millionaire, was humane enough to reduce the hours of his male employees to 48 and female employees to 44, and in his hook, The SixHours Day, he advocates a working week of 36 hours. Yet Judge Lukin says that the working week should be increased to 48 hours! Will any honorable member say that he knows as much of industry as Lord Leverhulme?

talk.start.para: - I ask the honorable member not to reflect on the judiciary.

- I am merely comparing a man of purely legal training with a great captain of industry who has built up an organization second only to that controlled by Henry Ford. While Lord Leverhulme is advocating a working week of 36 hours a member of the Australian Judiciary is trying to increase the present working week to 48 hours. Would any man who was well acquainted with the organization of labour do such a thing? Is it not a fact that that mighty man, Henry Ford, is advocating a fiveday week? Yet, in this beloved Australia, that we used to say was in the vanguard of the world's progress, we are going backwards. That judgment will stand to the discredit of this Government and of the men, whatever position they may occupy, who carry it into effect. I do not believe that the Prime Minister, in the light of the experience he has had with the firm of which he is a distinguished member, would have felt inclined to take this action had it not been for the prompting of the Attorney-General. Over the entrance to the law courts there should be the inscription, " Abandon hope all ye who enter here, unless you own great wealth." Let us see what wealth has done for the Attorney-General in his constituency. Some time ago a list was published by Smith's Weekly showing the amounts made available out of the funds of the National Union to various constituencies. It shows that the sum of ?2,300 was paid to a Mr. Russell, the secretary of the campaign committee in the Kooyong electorate. Smith's Weekly has never been prosecuted for libel on account of the publication of these figures. Neither the Prime Minister nor the Attorney-General dare prosecute them. I challenge them to do so. I have been responsible for the reprinting of this list and its circulation in my electorate. If these members do not care to prosecute Smith's Weekly, they can prosecute me. We know that the men who have received these sums dare not take that action, because in the witness-box they would not commit perjury by denying their correctness. These monies are subscribed by the hidden hand which is controlling this Government, and has made it bring forward this measure. Every National candidate in Victoria had an amount ranging up to ?3,500 spent in his electorate. Why has this list not been extended to include the sums made available in New South Wales and Queensland? The reason is that no officer betrayed the secret.

speech.para: This bill is an abomination. When a similar measure was introduced on a former occasion, I quoted from a work written by Henry Demarest Lloyd, and edited by John A. Hobson, entitled A Sovereign People. It is so splendidly written that I shall make a further quotation from it. At page 155 we have the statement -

quote.para: The employers and employed in each group of trades elect their representatives, fifteen for each side, to form a conseil. The numbers choose by ballot a committee consisting of a president, vice-president, secretary, and vice-secretary, the presidency and the other offices being held alternately by an employer and a workman, with the further proviso that, when the president or the secretary is an employer, the vice-officer must be a workman, and vice versa.

The work of the conseil is divided as follows. First comes the conciliation board, consisting of an employer and a workman, who preside by turns. This board has summary powers of decision in cases involving sums not exceeding twenty francs. In case of disagreement between the members, or where sufficient evidence for a summary judgment is lacking, the case is referred to the second board, the tribunal.

The Tribunal de Prud'hommes consists of a president, three employers, and three workmen, hears evidence and, where necessary, summons experts and gives final decisions in cases not involving more than 500 francs.
Cases involving larger sums are carried to the third court, a chamber of appeal, which consists of a president, five employers, five workers, and a secretary (without a vote).

Finally, certain cases where competence of jurisdiction is disputed are referred for decision to a mixed court composed of two judges of the court of justice (nominated by this court) and three prud'hommes chosen from among themselves by the chamber of appeal.

speech.para: That is the only place to which legal men are admitted. There are two judges, but they are out-voted by the three members of the Court of Wise Men. The passage continues -

quote.para: The proceedings of the tribunal and the chamber of appeal are public, and careful rules are provided to secure that no member of a court shall have any interest direct or indirect that is prejudicial to the impartiality of his judgment in the case he is called upon to try.

The conseils have also other functions of a more general order. They are summoned by the cantonal government to deliberate upon questions affecting industry and commerce. A special committee of prud'hommes determines questions regarding the execution of contracts, and constitutes a sanitary authority regarding the conditions of trades. Finally, a central committee, consisting of two elected delegates, forms a reporting and mediating committee between the Conseils de Prud'hommes and the Council of State and governmental departments, and is also entrusted with general powers of investigation into industrial conditions, hygienic, technical, and educational.

Such is the system in force in Geneva and Vaud. Two other cantons, Neufchatel and Solothurm, which had adopted the same method, exchanged it later on for what is commonly known as the method of arbitration courts.

The distinctive feature of this method is the appointment of the president of the Industrial Court from outside the trade the disputes of which he has to arbitrate, thus securing a presiding officer of guaranteed impartiality and usually of higher experience and general competency.

speech.para: With the exception of the Court of Conciliation, all these courts are open to the public. The Court of Conciliation comprises one employer and one employee, who endeavour to maintain peace between the workmen and the owners. Judgment is given publicly, . either orally or in writing, and is enforceable by the ordinary processes of law. A further passage reads -

quote.para: Ten courts of arbitration deal with disputes in these groups of trades: -

item.para: Textiles.
Earth and building works.
Woodwork.
Metals.
Foodstuffs and liquors.
Clothing trades.
Paper-making and polygraphic industry.
Chemicals.
Transport.
Retail trade and other callings (banks, insurance, employments connected with literature, art and science ) .

speech.para: The following table will show the number of cases dealt with and the manner in which they were settled: -
I quote the following from Survey of Industrial Relations, 1926, page 388: -

quote.para: In France, bodies known as Conseils de Prud'hommes, organized in groups of trades and composed of employers and workpeople in equal numbers, have existed since 1806 for the settlement of disputes affecting individual workers.

The first law for the settlement of collective disputes was the Voluntary Conciliation and Arbitration Act of 27th December, 1892. This act is still in operation, and it forms part of Hook IV of the Labour code, having been incorporated in the code as recently as June, 1923. Under this law, either party to a dispute, or both parties conjointly, may apply to the local magistrate (judge de paix) for the appointment of a conciliation committee; but the magistrate may himself take the initiative in the case of a strike or lockout. If the conciliation committee fail to agree, an arbitration court may be set up at the request of either of the parties, each side naming one or more up to five arbitrators.

speech.para: The magistrate must give an answer within- 24 hours. Claims before the Federal Arbitration Court have been delayed for years before they could be heard. That is because too little use is made of conciliation in this country. In.

Italy, Mussolini has prescribed punishment for lockouts far more severe than that for strikes. The employer's sentence in the case of a lockout is a fine of from 10,000 to 100,000 liras and imprisonment for six months to one year. Fancy sending John Brown to prison in Australia! Why, the inhabitants of the tabernacles i of wealth would shriek with horror at the idea. When the workers of Italy go on strike the fine is from 100 to 1,000 liras and the punishment is from one month to six months' imprisonment. It is a pity that this Government does not follow the splendid example set by Mussolini. Since his dictatorship Italy has progressed by leaps and bounds. According to the writer of the Survey of Industrial Relations, conciliation and arbitration in Switzerland has a history dating back to 1S82, when the Government of the Canton of Geneva established industrial courts on the model of the French Conseils de Prud'hommes. Other Cantons followed this example. The whole question of conciliation and arbitration. was dealt with by federal enactment in sections 30-35 of the Federal Factory Act of 18th June, 1914, which read -

item.para: For the amicable settlement of collective disputes between factory-owners and work people and also in regard to the interpretation and execution of collective agreements, the Cantons shall establish permanent conciliation boards bearing in mind the requirements of the various industries. The organization of Cantonal conciliation boards shall be subject to the approval of the Federal Council. [Quorum formed.].

speech.para: Section 31 -

quote.para: The conciliation boards shall intervene on their own initiative upon the request of the authorities of the interested parties. Any person subpoenaed by a board shall be compelled, under penalty of a fine, to appear, to take part in the proceedings, and to give all necessary information. The procedure shall be free ofcharge.

speech.para: I want honorable members to notice that the procedure is free of charge. Compare that with the charge of ?15,000 made against the unfortunate tramway workers in the early days of conciliation and arbitration. Unions had to despatch 4,000 letters apprising the employers of the action that was being taken, when one small paragraph in the Government Gazette would have been quite sufficient notice. The remaining section read : -

item.para: Should a dispute extend beyond the limits of the Canton, the Federal Council shall nominate the Conciliation Board. The Federal Council shall also be entitled to appoint a Cantonal Board to arbitrate.

Should a number of factory-owners and their work people, belonging to the same industry, unanimously appoint a conciliation board, the latter shall, as far as they are concerned, replace the public board.

The parties shall have the right in every case to empower the Conciliation Board to settle their difference by means of an arbitral award. Should the board have been established by mutual consent, the parties may extend such power to all their differences.
The Canton shall have the right to confer more extensive powers on their Conciliation Board than those provided for in the present act.

speech.para: These clauses were implemented by federal resolution of 1st February, 1918, concerning the establishment of conciliation offices. The date 1st April, 1918, was then fixed as that on which the clauses in question should come into operation. It was reported in Soziale Praxis for 4th September, 1924, that Conciliation Offices have been set up in all except 4 of the Cantons.

I shall now draw the attention of honorable members to a paragraph in the Contemporary Review, 1883, in respect of the Courts of the Wise Men. Before these courts, cases were conducted with perfect courtesy. One case concerned an employee who was dismissed, and the court decided that the employer should pay 36 francs, and, for the two letters of the court, 60 centimes. That is equivalent to 6d. The writer states definitely that nowhere in England could justice be gained for 6d. Surely to goodness we, in Australia, should be able to make good laws. The great Gladstone said that a law to be willingly obeyed should be just and merciful, that it should be easier for a man to obey the law than it is for him to break it. I agree with the principle of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but it has in it too much compulsion and too much law. Too many lawyers take part in arbitration. In France, Italy, Belgium, and Switzerland, no lawyer is allowed to interfere in the courts of conciliation. Only when a case is before the Third Court are two judges chosen, and they are more than balanced by three of the court's wise men. The conciliation courts of those countries operate at a minimum of cost, whereas in Australia the cost of arbitration' is enormous. Lawrence Gronlund, in his book, TheCooperative Commonwealth lays down this code -

quote.para: If a lawyer wins a case by superior vigilance he has done just what his duty requires of him even if he knows he is on the wrong side. A lawyer must steer around, must dodge the law against him. A lawyer should see to it. if he may not surprise his adversary, or even the judge, into some action which will render a new trial . probable to the verdict against him ; for instance . make the judge overrule an objection by stating a flimsy ground, while he conceals the true one. Indeed, our shining lights of the bar do daily acts of a comprehensive rule, that they may do anything to gain a victory except suborning witnesses and forging precedents.

speech.para: This is what Lawrence Gronlundwrites about judge-made laws : -

quote.para: One more instance is too interesting to omit. Do you know why Christianity is a part of the common law of our country? Because an English judge, Lord Mansfield, mistranslating two words of a dictum of somebody in the loth century called ancien scripture (Norman French meaning: ancient writing) "holy scripture"! ! !

speech.para: That leads me to the following statement of this great writer : -

quote.para: Just as little Switzerland will furnish us a model of really popular democratic administration in the " referendum ", so it is possible that little Denmark will furnish us a model of popular administration of justice in her so-called Courts of Conciliation ", which have been in existence in that country since 1828, and, during that period, have given immense satisfaction, so much so, indeed, that similar courts have, to a certain extent, been adopted by other countries in Europe. The distinguishing feature of those courts is that no lawyers are allowed there. All suits, whatsoever, without regard to the amounts involved, must, in the first place, be brought before the courts. The judge takes down the oral complaint of the plaintiff, and the oral defence of the defendant, and renders judgment accordingly. If, however, either of the parties is dissatisfied with the judgment, the judge refers the case to the regular courts, in which case, however, no other evidence is allowed to be introduced but that which was laid before the judge sitting in the Court of Conciliation.

speech.para: When the late Mr. Justice Higgins was examining the law pertaining to Victoria, I introduced to him a worthy citizen of Denmark who wished to give evidence before the commission. It was explained to me that, in Denmark, the magistrate - the Pacificator - would be sworn to make peace between citizen and citizen, but if the parties failed to agree he would appoint a day to hear the case and give his decision in writing. No lawyers were admitted. The magistrate would hear the case, and give his decision together with reasons. In the event of the magistrate's decision being unacceptable to either of the parties, the case would be heard in a higher court, at which both parties could be represented by lawyers. The lawyers, however, could not introduce fresh evidence, and had to argue the. case on the written decision of the . magistrate. I now wish to quote the following extract from Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration, by Douglas Knoop, vide page 119 -

quote.para: With regard to the work done by councils, it is worth noticing that the great majority of the disputes dealt with are directly concerned with wages, e.g., questions concerning the exact amount agreed upon, the time and mode of payment, the amount of fines, hours of labour, absence from work, defective workmanship, apprenticeship, valuation of piece-work, and delay in completing task work. The most striking feature about the councils is the preponderance of conciliation. The average annual number of cases dealt with during the " eighties " slightly exceeded 40,000--

speech.para: Compare that number with the figures quoted by the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser) - and of these two-thirds were settled by conciliation or withdrawal. At the present time more than 50,000 cases come before the Committees of Conciliation. Some 60 per cent, of the cases are settled by the committees, or withdrawn, and only in about 15 per cent, is final judgment passed. On several occasions the Chamber of Deputies have passed bills to alter the existing law with regard to Councils of Prud'homnies, but in each instance the Senate has rejected them.

The second chambers are always opposed to humane legislation. In this instance the Government proposes to hand over the control of hundreds of thousands of working men who have wives and children dependent upon them, to the Legislative Councils in the States, which will have the power to veto any arbitration legislation passed by the lower chambers. The second chambers in Australia have always been noted for this infamous conduct. When a member of the Victorian Legislative Assembly I had the honour of introducing two private bills, which had been drafted for the protection of women, and which were passed by that chamber the same evening; but the infamous Legislative Council refused to pass one. The government of the day had supported them. One could not be considered by the Legislative Council until the following year, when, however, it became law. The late Sir George Turner, who was then Premier, congratulated me upon the success I had achieved, and I am sure that he regretted the attitude adopted by the Legislative Council. I have always been strongly opposed to second chambers. The quotation from Knoop's Industrials Conciliation and Arbitration continues -

quote.para: The chief changes proposed are: that experts should be elected for commerce, agriculture and mining, that the minimum age of electors should be reduced to 21, and that of members to 25, that foremen and chiefs of workshops should be counted as employers, that employers and workmen should remain electors and eligible for membership on the councils for ten years after retirement, that the franchise should be extended to women over 21 and that judgment should be final when the amount involved does not exceed 2,000 francs. The only suggestions which the Senate countenances are the extension of the jurisdiction of the councils to mining, and the raising of the limit under which judgment is to be final from 200 to 300 francs.

speech.para: In every instance the Senate was the stumbling block. Since the publication of this volume in 1905, all the suggestions of the lower House have been carried into effect, notwithstanding the attitude of the

Senate which, corresponds with the Legislative Councils in the States. With a few exceptions, Legislative Councils consist of members representing only one class, namely, land-holders and anyone who is not directly or indirectly a land-holder, is not eligible for membership. Honorable members opposite supporting this bill are placing the interests of 900,000 workmen and their dependants under the control of the Legislative Councils in the various States.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

speech.para: Mr.R. GREEN (Richmond) [5.8].- This measure is divided into two parts in one of which provision is made for the removal of a certain legislative structure, and in the other, for a new edifice. When a substantial structure is to be erected it is necessary to remove the old building and to ensure that the foundations arc secure. In this measure, provision is made for the demolition of the old edifice by the repeal of fifteen acts and the amendments of fourteen others. I hold a somewhat unique position in this chamber in that, prior to my election in 1922, I made the abolition of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court a main plank in my platform. That was the attitude I adopted towards arbitration in 1925, and again in 1928, and 1 was delighted when I was informed that it was the intention of the Government to abolish the Federal Arbitration Court. The policy I have advocated for years has on three different occasions been endorsed by my electors.I told my constituents that our arbitration ship was leaking so badly that although it would put to sea, it would undoubtedly meet with heavy weather and have to be docked or perhaps scrapped. I was willing that the vessel should be patched, but I was afraid that it was in such a condition that it would be unable to weather the storms it was sure to encounter.

talk.start.para: - The vessel is all right; the trouble is with the crew.

- That is not so. As I have advocated the total abolition of the Arbitration Court for seven years, it cannot be said that I have not received a mandate from the electors. The platform of the Country party does not go quite so far, and paragraph 4 (k) provides that conflict in industry should be avoided by making general arbitration awards in relation to interstate shipping and the pastoral industry. Under this measure, the Commonwealth will retain control over the maritime industry. Although I have always been aware that many major difficulties were likely to arise under the policy I advocated, it was not until the Transport Workers Bill was under consideration that I learned that the Commonwealth had authority to deal with the maritime industry under its trade and commerce powers, instead of under its conciliation and arbitration powers which are being exercised at present. I commend the Government for now introducing a policy which I first advocated in 1922. Is it not illogical to reason that, because an important matter was, or was not, mentioned in a policy speech, the Government is forbidden to place legislation dealing with the subject on the statute-book? Whether the Prime Minister has or has not a mandate does not make the least difference to the introduction of such a measure. as this. I claim that it is unnecessary to have a mandate. The right honorable member for North. Sydney (Mr. Hughes) proposes to move an amendment providing that the people shall be consulted by way of referendum before the measure becomes law. We have had many referendums, and I have still to learn that a government is forced to go to the people when it wishes to repeal an act. That is introducing a new theory into our Australian policies. Honorable members have been elected by the people to represent certain views. [Quorum formed.] It is their duty faithfully to maintain those views. We have to make our own decisions. If certain legislation is a brake on the progress of the nation we should be recreant in our duty if we failed to repeal it. I still desire to know how, and when, the theory was originated that it is necessary to go to the people before repealing an act. Many acts have been repealed and the fact that this measure now affects fifteen other acts makes no difference. There is no need to conduct a referendum on the matter. Honorable members opposite are merely seeking to cloud the issue.

speech.para: This afternoon I asked a pertinent question of the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin) when he was pointing out that the Federal Arbitration Court had done much for the wage-earners of Australia. I asked why, if it has been of such benefit to our wage-earners, employees have assisted to repudiate its awards. I received no answer.

talk.start.para: - Oh, yes, the honorable member did.

- I repeat, I received no answer. Honorable members opposite deliberately shirk the issue. This matter was brought to a head by a strike in the timber industry. Peculiarly enough, although we knew that there were exceptionally militant associations, such as the waterside workers organization and the coal-miners- organizations - the latter being responsible, in 1927, for 59 per cent, of the strikes in New South Wales - we believed that the timber workers union was of a very mild disposition. That leads me to put forward this aspect of the case. For a number of years, certain privileges were granted to various unions, but the first time that the court failed to grant the request of a union - in this case the hitherto docile timber workers union - that organization went on strike. In other words, the court created a militant union and a strike by refusing to grant what was sought from it. Is' it seriously claimed that the court can continue to be of benefit to Australia? I contend that that union, by going on strike when its claims were refused, effectively killed the federal system of arbitration.
- John Brown was the principal cause of the Federal Government withdrawing from the field of arbitration.

- He may have been a contributory factor. Through the considered action of several unions the court has been jettisoned. The most severe condemnation of that court was uttered by Judge Lukin himself. Following a determination by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions not to file further plaints in the Arbitration Court, and not to be represented in the court the Federated Carters and Drivers Industrial Union of Australia applied to Judge Lukin in the Arbitration Court to have its plaint dismissed. In this case Mr. R. Cheney represented the unions, and I shall read a significant portion of the report for the information of honorable members. It is as follows: -

quote.para: By Judge Lukin. - What have you to say about your members being out on strike?
Mr. Cheney. ; I say that our members stand for unionism.
Judge Lukin. - But that is not an answer to my question.

Mr. Cheney. ; We have no special interest in the timber workers' strike, except sympathetically. We are a component part of the Australasian Council of Trades Unions, and we have to obey a decision of that body.
Judge Lukin. - Whether it is against the law or not?
Mr. Cheney. ; Most certainly! I answer that with the greatest deliberation.
Judge Lukin. - I realize that.

speech.para: I ask the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell), who contends that the court should continue to operate, what he has to say to that.

talk.start.para: - If the honorable member had a guarantee that awards would be faithfully observed, would he be prepared to continue the court ?
- We have not the power under our Constitution to enforce awards.
- Will the honorable member answer my question?
- I have done so. We have not the power to give the necessary guarantees. Mr. Judge Lukin, dealing with the position of the unions, had this to say -

quote.para: There is another unpleasant and regrettable aspect of the present trouble to which I may refer. That is the position which, at the behest and direction of the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, the Federal unions are to take up against the arbitration laws of the community. I say advisedly " the laws of the commnity," because the court, as the community's representative, is the duly appointed authority empowered to make arbitration laws on behalf of the community in respect to interstate disputes.

Shortly stated, the position is a defiance of those laws, and an attempted boycott of the court. An individual or organization that persists in defying the laws of the community compels the community to treat him or it as what he or it claims to be, that is, an outlaw, One of the necessary consequences of outlawry is a deprivation of benefits of the law which the outlaw defies.

speech.para: Trade unions have defied the court on many occasions, and made themselves outlaws. Now they are trying, through their accredited representatives here, to have their privileges preserved, and honorable members are squealing, because the unions are to be deprived of the protection of laws which they refused to respect.

talk.start.para: - We are not squealing; we are fighting the issue fairly.

- The honorable member and his colleagues squealed all last night. " Judge Lukin said that one of the necessary consequences of outlawry was the loss of legal rights. The unions having placed themselves outside the law, have forfeited their right to the protection of the law. Therefore, take the court away; it is the only thing to do. If nobody else in this House has a mandate to support the abolition of arbitration, I at least can claim to have one. During three election campaigns, starting from 1922, I have pledged myself consistently to support the abolition of the Arbitration Court. That has always been one of the main planks of my platform.
- The honorable member can sympathize with his colleagues, who have to change their minds so often.

- There is no occasion to offer them sympathy; only commendation. In 1926, this House, with only two dissentient voices, agreed to refer to the people, by way of referendum, a proposal 'that the Constitution should be amended in order to give the Commonwealth wider powers, particularly in regard to arbitration. Singularly enough, the only two members who opposed the proposal sat on this side of the House. The proposal put before the electors was that, instead of having an emasculated Arbitration Court such as we have to-day, we should have one clothed with full powers. It is interesting to analyse the vote of the electors in order to determine whether or not honorable members opposite may claim to have a mandate from the people to oppose this bill. Were the constituents of the Leader of the Opposition in favour of the extension of powers asked in order to make the court effective? They were not. In the division of Tarra there was a majority of 24,129 against the proposal. In the division of Dalley, which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore) represented at that time -
- I was not a member at that time.

- I am sorry. At any rate, in that electorate the majority against the proposal was 12,802. In the electorate of some of the other verbose members opposite, the voice of the people in opposition to the extension of Commonwealth powers was just as definite. In the division of Maribyrnong, which the Opposition Whip, Mr. Penton, represents, that persuasive and talkative gentleman was not able to induce the electors to agree to the proposal which he recommended, and they voted " No " by a majority of 21,048. In the electorate of the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Anstey), who was at one time Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the majority against the proposal was 24,568. The honorable member for Cook (Mr. C. Riley) smiles; I shall furnish him with the figures for his own electorate. There the electors turned down the proposal by a majority of 17,223.
- What was the result of the vote in the honorable member's own electorate ?

- In my electorate the " Yes " majority was the biggest in the State of New South- Wales. That was their opinion on the question of the extension of powers of the Federal Arbitration Court, but since the Commonwealth was not able to secure those extra powers, the best thing to do is to get out of arbitration altogether. In Hindmarsh, which is represented by the secretary of the Labour party, Mr. Makin, the majority for "No" was 22,733, which shows the extent of his influence among his electors.
- What was the majority in the Flinders division?
- I do not know; I have not the figures here.
- There was a majority against the proposal, in spite of the personal appeal of the Prime Minister.

- I have quoted the results in the electorates of the officers of the Opposition party, and in no case was the majority for " No " less than 20,000. Yet those members come here and tell the Government that it has no mandate to abolish the Arbitration Court. Where, I ask them., is their mandate for saying that the court must be retained? Their own electors have said very definitely that the Commonwealth Government should get out of arbitration, and hand the control of industrial matters back to the States.
- They always vote for our platform by the same majority.
- That reminds me of a phrase used this afternoon by the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Cur tin) . It consisted of only three words, but it stuck in my mind. He said, "Individualism is dead."
- Among members of the Labour party.

- Of course I do not infer that it is dead among Government supporters.. There is a great deal of twisting and wriggling going on among members of the Opposition party. To speak crudely, the Labour party may be likened to a seething mass of maggots, because maggots have no individuality.
- Order! I ask the honorable member to modify his language. He must not use such expressions.
- What has the honorable member to say about those on his own side who have allowed their opinions to be submerged?

- I know of no one on this side whose opinions have been submerged. I wonder whether the flood of union secretaries who have been in Canberra recently has had anything to do with submerging the opinions of honorable members opposite? The honorable member for Fremantle extolled as a virtue the absence of individualism. We have been aware for a long time of the lack of this quality among members of the Opposition, and I am glad that one of them has at last admitted it. I am sorry to say that a more weak-kneed crowd of sycophants than the members of the Labour party I have never seen.
- The members of the honorable member's own party are silent, which shows that they do not agree with him.

- Not necessarily. A little while ago there was published in the Sydney Morning Herald a series of articles by an anonymous correspondent which threw some interesting sidelights upon the Federal Arbitration Court. In one of these articles the . writer states -

quote.para: The statement is made' that in Victoria 60 separate industries are subject to overlapping, and that in the other States the position is comparable. In some cases a single industry has to study and observe sheaves of detailed regulations included in more than 30 awards. A leading manufacturer of confectionery puts his position thus -

In my business we are under 38 wages boards and arbitration awards. The result is endless confusion and enormous expense. Some of our employees commence at 7.30, some at 7.45, some at 8 and some at 9. Some cease for lunch at 12, some at 12.30 and some at 1 o'clock. Some have 30 minutes, some 45 and some 60 minutes. Some cease work at 5, some at 5.15, some at 5.30, some at 6. Some work 35 hours a week, some 44, some 48. Can one imagine anything so complicated and irritating? A clerical staff is employed to check the hours and conditions. As a matter of fact, they are so complicated that I am unable to tell whether the employees should be coming or going.

speech.para: That is in one establishment alone.

talk.start.para: - That can be stopped by the States, but not so long as the Commonwealth is operating in the field of arbitration.

- Duplication is the cause of these troubles. This bill will remedy the existing unsatisfactory state of affairs. The report of the "Big Four " contains the following in relation to the overlapping of awards : -

quote.para: If the settlement of. industrial disputes must continue to be referred to Arbitration Courts, we think that the faults of the system will continue to be intensified, unless an end can be put to overlapping and conflict between the spheres of Commonwealth and State jurisdiction, and the courts themselves are laid under, an unqualified statutory instruction to have regard to the economic effects of their awards, both on the industry with which the awards may be immediately concerned, and on other industries which may be indirectly affected by them.

talk.start.para: - Of the 38 awards mentioned by the honorable member, how many are State and howmany Federal?
- I do not know. Let me quote again from the article to which I have referred. It gives particulars of the cost to the parties of the cases heard before the court -

quote.para: The costs of industrial Litigation amount to several thousands of pounds in many cases. Even the minor matter of taking notes and making transcripts of the evidence is serious. Here are some of the bills paid by the parties in this way: - Federated Engine-drivers and

Firemen, V.A.T. Amalgamated, Gold-miners and others, ?552 17s. 3d.; Australian Tramways Employees Association v. Railway Commissioners of New South Wales, vice versa, ?204 18s. Gd.; Printing Industrial Employees Union v. Arbuckle, Waddle and others, ?128 19s. 9d. ; Australian Workers Union v. Alston and others, ?120 3s. 3d.; Timber Merchants and Saw-millers Association v. ' Australian Timber Workers Union, ?555 2s. 9d. The general secretary of the Australian Railways Union has said that the arbitration expenses incurred on behalf of the union during the last six years have amounted to ?9,084.

talk.start.para: - Are those the court costs ?
- They are the hills that have been paid for arbitration expenses.
- What return did the unions get for the expenditure?

- They got too much return. I also desire to draw attention to the number of disputes which were settled during the years 1925-26-27, and 1928. In 1924 the number of all disputes was 500. In the following years mentioned the numbers were respectively 491, 356, 435 and 282.
- Do those numbers include the disputes mentioned by the honorable member for Kalgoorlie?

- I do not know. The figures I have given are those of the Commonwealth Statistician. Of those disputes the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Court settled twelve, or 2? per cent., in 1924; thirteen, or 3 per cent, in 1925 ; thirteen, or 4 per cent., in 1926, and nineteen, or 4 per cent., in 1927. During those five years, out of 2,064 industrial disputes, only 63, or about 3 per cent., were settled by the Federal Arbitration Court. The others were settled in various ways, mostly by negotiation as this bill proposes.
- One of them concerned a waitress who broke a plate and refused to pay for it.

- I am glad of that admission that a whole crowd of employees went on strike for such a trivial reason. The main objection to this bill is that it will throw a number of union secretaries out of a job. That is the reason for their lobbying. I do not blame them for coming here to save their jobs. Any man similarly situated would be justified in taking action to . keep himself employed. These men have, however, "put it over" members of the Opposition, who are not really voicing their own opinions, but the opinions of these union 'secretaries.

speech.para: Even the gentleman whose name is indissolubly associated with the Federal Arbitration Court - Mr. Justice Higgins - wrote against the repudiation of the court's awards. He pointed out on more than one occasion that the main weakness of the court was its inability to enforce its awards - " I have seen a cartoon in a Labour newspaper," writes Mr. Justice Higgins, in his book on arbitration, " showing a labourer walking towards a gate marked ' freedom ' and a bull-dog with a collar marked 'arbitration.' Arbitration bars his path."

What do honorable members opposite stand for - freedom, or the dictum of the honorable member for Fremantle' (Mr. Curtin) that his individuality has gone: he is one of the herd ; he will do what he is told? Honorable members opposite would deprive the " dinkum " worker of freedom. In the timber workers' case they wanted to prevent the taking of a ballot. That was an interference with the freedom of those workers, suggestive of the methods of the " basher gang " in Sydney. " Dinkum " workers in New South Wales are being barred to-day. You are pre' venting " dinkum " workers, who art willing to work, from obtaining it.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member uses the word "you." Whom does he mean?
- I refer to honorable members opposite.
- It is a lie. I ask you, Mr. Speaker, to call upon the honorable member for Richmond to withdraw his statement.
- The honorable member must withdraw his remark that another honorable member has given expression to a lie.
- I am prepared to do it for the time being.
- The honorable member must withdraw it unconditionally.

- I do not attach any conditions. I regard the statement of the honorable member for Richmond as most offensive and objectionable. It has no foundation in fact, and I ask that he be called upon to withdraw it immediately.

- To what statement does the honorable member refer ? While the honorable member for Richmond was speaking, the honorable member for Cook asked him a question, and, in reply, the honorable member for Richmond said he referred to honorable members opposite. I heard nothing offensive. If the honorable member takes exception to any statement made by the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green), and considers that it applied to him, he may, when the honorable member for Richmond has resumed his seat, make a personal explanation.

- I take strong exception to the base and false statement of the honorable member, for Richmond. He said that honorable members of the Opposition were connected with certain happenings associated with the " Basher Gang" in Sydney. That statement is most offensive, and I ask for its withdrawal.
- If the honorable member for Richmond made use of those words, they would certainly be offensive. If he used them, he should withdraw them.
- I have no intention of withdrawing a statement which I did not make.

- The honorable member for Cook (Mr. E. C. Riley), if he thinks that the honorable member for Richmond made the statement to which he has referred, is entitled to take exception to it as applying to himself. But when the honorable member for Richmond assures me that he did not make the statement, I must accept his assurance as a man of honour.
- I will repeat, as nearly as possible, what I did say concerning the Opposition.
- I rise to a point of order. The honorable member for Richmond said his remarks applied to all honorable members on this side. He said that we were denying work to " dinkum " workers.
- I said that, and I mean it.
- The honorable member referred to certain happenings in Sydney.

speech.para: He said that we on this side denied freedom to " dinkum " workers. He made it clear that he meant the whole of the members of the Opposition. The remark is offensive to me, and I ask that he be called upon to withdraw it.

talk.start.para: - I cannot see that the remark was offensive. The honorable member for Richmond suggested that freedom was being denied to certain men by honorable members of the Opposition. The honorable member for Adelaide (Mr. Yates) is entitled to deny the correctness of the statement at the proper time.

- The honorable member for Richmond referred to certain happenings in Sydney, with which the "Basher Gang" was associated, and then he said that we on this side denied freedom to " dinkum " workers. I point out, Mr. Speaker, that we have a definition of a " dinkum worker," which differs from that of the honorable member for Richmond. That, following his previous remarks, makes the term very offensive to me.

- Order ! I am afraid that if an honorable member uses a phrase, the meaning of which may be ambiguous, it is not for the Chair to interpret it necessarily as offensive, apart from the context. The honorable member for Richmond has given me his assurance that he did not apply to honorable members of the Opposition the words of which the honorable member for Cook complained.

- I shall repeat what I said in order that there may be no misunderstanding on the point. I said that freedom was being denied to the " dinkum " workers of Australia and that honorable members opposite and those who are sitting behind them are responsible for it.

- On a point of order, I take strong exception to that remark. I have had nothing to do with the timber workers' strike in New South Wales. I am not a New South Wales member. The timber workers of South Australia are working amicably. The honorable member has included me in the remark that he has just made, and I object to the inclusion.

- The remark of the honorable member for Richmond could not be regarded as offensive. If the honorable member for Adelaide feels that the statement made is incorrect he will have an opportunity later to correct it.

- There is no doubt whatever that intimidation tactics have been adopted against the workers of Australia which have had result, in some cases, of causing men to allow their wives and children to starve rather than submit to the nickname of " scab. " A man who does that deserves all that is coming to him. I was a trade unionist for many years, but in those days no domination whatever was exercised over me.
- And domination is not exercised over the unionists to-day.
- But you are under domination to-day.

speech.para: Mr.R. GREEN.- The Labour party is still speaking with two voices. The honorable member for Kalgoorlie says that there is no domination and the honorable member for Macquarie says that there is.

talk.start.para: - I said that the honorable member was under domination now.

speech.para: Mr.R. GREEN.- The opposition to the passage of this bill is not coming from the real trade unionists. I have a number of trade unionists in my electorate. I have fought my last three campaigns with " the abolition of the Arbitration Court " as an issue. Many trade unionists must have voted for me or I should not have obtained such a large majority.

talk.start.para: - Is the abolition of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court a plank in the platform of the honorable members' party?
- Paragraph k of section 4 of the platform of the Country party reads -

quote.para: Conflict in industry to be avoided by the limitation of Commonwealth arbitration powers to the determination of standards of basic wage, hours of employment and child endowment in industry and for the making of general, awards in relation to the interest of shipping and pastoral industries.

talk.start.para: - Then why is not something being done for the pastoral industry?

- The Government could not be expected to retain the Arbitration Court for the sake of one industry. It is not necessary to retain the court for the sake of the maritime industry, for the power proposed to be exercised over it is contained in those sections of the Constitution which deal with trade and commerce. We cannot use our industrial power effectively because our hands are tied.

speech.para: The main opposition to the abolition of the Arbitration Court is coming from the officials of the federated trade unions who are afraid that they will lose their jobs. The Labour party is not united in its opposition to the bill, as I shall show by a quotation from an article which appeared in the Pan-Pacific Worker of the 2nd April, 1928, by Senator Arthur Rae, who was elected as a Labour representative at the last election. Honorable members opposite may snort derisively, but Senator Rae is a fully accredited Labour man. His article was headed " The curse of compulsory arbitration " and it contained the following paragraph : -

quote.para: It is impossible to estimate the moral harm which has been done to the Australian working class by its hasty and ill-considered acceptance of arbitration as a solution of labour's problems.

speech.para: On the loth May, 1928, the Australasian Council of Trade Unions passed a resolution in which it expressed its "full satisfaction " with the character of the issue of the Pan-Pacific Worker in which ' the article by Senator Rae appeared. Here again the Labour party is found to be speaking with two voices. Which voice are we to believe?

We have heard a good deal about the mandate which the Government received at the last election. I contend that at least some honorable members of the Labour party received a mandate from the people to support this bill. Among these are the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin), the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Anstey), and the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Makin). These honorable members advocated an affirmative vote on the referendum proposal, but the negative vote on the subject in their electorates showed a majority, in each case, of more than 20,000. Consequently, I cannot see from where the kick of the Opposition is coming. The people refused to give additional industrial power to the Commonwealth in 1926, and it would be useless for us to take another referendum on the subject. , The prestige of the honorable members whom I have mentioned must have suffered a great deal through the adverse vote given in their electorates on the referendum proposals. I have a definite mandate to support this bill, for my electors returned me on a platform which provided for the abolition of the court. As a matter of fact, the Government is seeking to do exactly what the people directed it to do, namely, evacuate the field of industrial arbitration. The High Court has indicated clearly that the awards of the court cannot be enforced. This ought to be a sufficient justification for the action of the Government. I sincerely trust that we shall make it possible for the States to manage their own industrial affairs. This will lead to the workers of Australia being paid all that they can earn. If a man can earn ?15 or ?20 a week he should be paid it.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6. IS to S p.m. (Friday.)

talk.start.para: . - I protest against the procedure adopted by the Government in endeavouring to force the bill through this House. We have been sitting continuously for two days and a night, although by no stretch of imagination can the measure be regarded as urgent. No evidence has been adduced in support of the claim for urgency advanced by the Government. The bill is designed to repeal some fifteen statutes and to amend almost as many more. It has never been submitted to the people. The Government had given no indication whatever of its intention to introduce the measure until it was mentioned in the press, following the conference of Federal and State Ministers. At the last election, not the slightest hint was dropped that such legislation was contemplated. No member of this House, and nobody outside it, thought that such a bill would be considered during the life of the present Parliament. On the contrary, there was a statement in the policy speech of the Government that it would support the present arbitration system. As indicated by the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell), no legislation of that description was suggested by the Government after the election. When Parliament went into recess prior to Easter, no member, apart from the Ministry, at any rate, thought that before we met again such a bill would be brought before us.
- Not even the members of the Cabinet.

- I am referring to the rank and file of the Ministerial party, who, we are assured, are not caucusridden, but free to express their individual opinions. The Government's consultation with the rank and file of its loyal supporters, who follow it so slavishly, consisted in sending them telegrams - urgent telegrams, I believe - informing them that it had decided to do this thing. In the words of the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell), the announcement came to him, as it must have come to the other members of the party, as a bolt from the blue. Then, a further consultation, if I may describe it by that term, occurred in the party rooms. The Ministerialists were told what the Government intended to do. The Prime Minister brought the measure forward, and he now seriously appeals to the House to discuss it in a non-party spirit! After sitting for many hours continuously, honorable members are still discussing it, although it has never been submitted to the people, and not a scintilla of evidence has been produced in justification of the claim that it is urgent.

speech.para: The conditions in the industrial arena are the same now as they were twelve months ago, except that in the last year the Government has continued to blunder in that sphere, as it has done for the last four or five years. The whole history of the legislation and administration of this Government in industrial matters has been one of bungling. I rather think that a recapitulation of its record in that respect would not be relished by honorable members opposite. The Government said it did not believe in agitators and other undesirable persons, and it brought forward a deportation bill to enable it to send two men out of the country. These persons were seized and placed on Garden Island; but eventually the Government had to compensate them for wrongful arrest. Then it declared, " We are going to see . that the laws of this country are obeyed " ; so it amended the Arbitration Act, and provided for penalties.

talk.start.para: - That is nothing like a fair representation of what has been done.

- I am relating facts, and, despite the protest by the Attorney-General, I shall continue to do so. Then the Government proceeded to give effect to the legislation it had passed, and certain unions and union officials were fined. Holloway was fined under the provisions of one of the statutes introduced by this Government. I think that he had to pay ?50, or go to prison for six months.
- That is not so.
- The ?50 has not been paid.
- There was an alternative of imprisonment in the Holloway case.

- I understand that that was so. If a defendant refuses to pay a fine, what is done further? I have no desire to dwell at length on these matters; but the John Brown case is fresh in our minds. The Government said that it had a prima facie case against that gentleman, who is still at large, and may still be seen at race meetings with his glasses slung over his shoulder. The public may say of him, " There goes a man who, according to the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, has broken the law " ; but he still goes on, and the Government persists in its statement that it stands for the enforcement of the awards of the Arbitration Court.
- " John Brown's body lies a-mould'ring in the grave, but his soul goes marching on " !

- I have made a preliminary survey of the circumstances under which we are invited to discuss this measure. I have listened to the battle-royal between representatives of recognized industry and organized capital.
- There are no representatives of organized capital here.
- The susceptibility of the Attorney-General is very tender. Evidently the all-night sittings are getting on his nerves. I am quite prepared to agree to the postponement of the debate.

speech.para: As a representative of the pri-mary producers I ask myself where they come in. Where are their champions, who were sent here to represent their interests? With the exception of one speech, we have heard nothing from them during this debate. I shall put the case as I see it, and as one who has been returned again and again by the farmers in 'my constituency, I shall make a brief survey of the position of the primary producers of Australia under the present federal arbitration system and the tariff regime; I couple these two matters because they are inter-related. That fact was recognized by those responsible for the original introduction of compulsory arbitration' legislation. Sir Edmund Barton, Australia's first Prime Minister, stated -

quote.para: The grant of interstate free trade, which follows the adoption of a uniform tariff, is likely, in many respects, to be crippled unless the Commonwealth has power to deal uniformly with the conditions of employment throughout Australia. The conditions of employment and the price of articles are inseparably interwoven, and these conditions and prices are also inseparable from the nature of the tariff, whether it operates externally only, or externally and internally among the States.

speech.para: Mr. Alfred Deakin, when Prime Minister, in a memorandum presented to Parliament on the 13th December, 1907, said -

quote.para: To restrict the powers of the Commonwealth to the mere imposition of duties, while conditions under which the manufacture of protected articles is carried on differ so widely in the different States, would be to permit discrimination and discord. . . .

Effective and useful as State industrial laws have in many cases proved, their operation is circumscribed by State boundaries, and it can hardly be claimed for them that they either do, or can, secure uniformity in the conditions of manufacture throughout Australia. No authority but the Commonwealth Parliament can do this.

speech.para: In a further memorandum, presented on the 28th October, 1908, Mr. Deakin remarked -

quote.para: As the power to protect the manufacturer is national, it follows that unless the Parliament of the Commonwealth also acquires power to secure fair and reasonable conditions of employment to wage-earners, the policy of protection must remain incomplete.

speech.para: I do not think that that view 13 opposed in this House. The official organ of the Victorian Country party, an organization to which the Postmaster-General (Mr. Gibson), the Minister for Markets and Transport (Mr. 'Paterson), and other honorable members in the corner party belong, stated in a leading article last year -

quote.para: Never before in the history of this country have the primary industries been in the parlous position that they are in to-day.

speech.para: Consider the position of the wheat-growing industry throughout Australia; I refer particularly to South Australia, Victoria, and New South Wales. The growers in my own constituency and in northern Victoria have never been in a worse predicament than that in which they now find themselves. Last year the Victorian Parliament was compelled to pass a Postponement of Payments Act in order to relieve the settlers who were in financial difficulties on account of the drought. The position in that State to-day is worse than it was last year, owing to the continuance of the drought. That may be said also of South Australia, where the wheat-growers, with the exception of those in the southern and more favoured parts, are in a desperate position, and a moratorium or some other form of relief alone will save hundreds from being driven off the land. The New South Wales Cabinet is considering a proposal for the consolidation of the settlers' debts in order to prevent many in the western parts of their State from being forced to abandon their holdings. We may be told that these things are due to seasonal conditions, and not to legislation. But seasonal conditions are an integral part of the economic problem of primary production. In any case, the distress does not obtain only in the drought-stricken areas. The soldier settlers and others engaged in the canned fruits industry are in difficulties, and the report of the Development and Migration Commission shows that those people are confronted . with a hopeless economic prospect.

talk.start.para: - The jam fruits industry is worse.

- The honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Mcwilliams) is in a position to speak with authority upon that industry. The dried fruits industry also is in difficulties. The dairying industry, owing to legislation and organization, is, for the time being, in a fairly good condition. The wool industry is faced with declining profits and a stationary or increasing cost of production. This is a serious national problem, having regard to the fact that the exports of wool, wheat, meat, butter, and fruit alone keep the Commonwealth solvent. No means can be devised by this or any other Government that will solve the problem of keeping the national finances in a sound state unless we export about ?30,000,000 worth of goods more than we import in order to pay our indebtedness overseas. So in considering the economic problems of the country the first and vital factor is the position of the primary industries. Last week several members of the Victorian Parliament journeyed into the new Mallee district to study the conditions of the settlers. Many of them were representatives of city constituencies, and had no practical knowledge of the conditions of the man on the land. I quote this letter, which was published in the Argus above the signature of ten representatives of different parties in the Victorian legislature -

quote.para: Sir, - As the result of a special invitation we have visited the new Mallee in the electorate of Mr. Allnutt, M.L.A., during the last five days, and gained an intimate insight into the conditions prevailing in that area. While realizing that the weather, especially the terrible duststorms, was exceptional even in this part of the State, we feel that the circumstances thoroughly warrant the request that we are making in this letter.

The new Mallee is now experiencing its third successive year of drought. Many settlers and their families are living in bag humpies, and others in tin huts under conditions which would be considered serious in other parts of the State, but are appalling in the Mallee. Four children in one family in a two-roomed shack had to be taken away to hospital in the midst of the great duststorm on Saturday. Despite hard work in clearing the land and sowing crops the rain has failed the settlers. Still battling cheerfully against adversity, they are continuing bravely with their task, but they have been unable in most cases to do anything to improve the living conditions' of their families. For the last two years the majority of the women and children have been living on Government sustenance. They have not been able to leave their Mallee huts even for a night. Hard work and cruel weather conditions have sapped their energy and vitality in a manner that cannot fail to enlist the sympathy of those who live in more favorable circumstances. There is no prospect of an improvement in their position for at least eighteen months. All the rain in the world could not save this year's crops.

speech.para: The writers concluded by appealing for funds to get the women and children out of that area for a few weeks in order that they might recuperate. The drab picture they painted is unfortunately only too true, and I draw to it the attention of members of the Opposition, who battle so loyally - rightly so - to improve the conditions of those whom they represent. The wage-earners in the secondary industries are not the worst remunerated. Much lip loyalty is paid to the pioneers, but their reward is to work long hours under the worst conditions for a less return than is paid to those engaged in any other industry. And the people who are slaving under conditions approaching starvation read in the newspapers this sort of thing -
Sydney, Thursday.
The Lustre Hosiery Company was fined ?3 by the Chief Industrial Magistrate for having neglected to provide Mary Nolan, an employee, with morning tea.

I have no objection to the workers having morning tea, but the circumstances indicated by that paragraph are in striking contrast to those of the primary producers. The colossal losses in connexion, with soldier settlement are due, not alone to Government bungling, but also to the fact that men were directed into an industry in which the conditions are worse than in any other. As a farmer, I have often thought how strange it is that when the Government wants to settle migrants or soldiers it places them on the land. Why does it not create factories and find employment for them there? Always it puts them on the land, as tens of thousands of soldiers who fought and suffered for this country have been settled. The reward of their sacrifice is a raw block of scrub. I met a neighbour on a sandhill one day who, after three or four years of drought, had nothing to show for his hard, work and privations but a letter from the Soldier Settlement Board stating that his indebtedness far exceeded the value of his block. Looking about him he said, " Sometimes I wonder who won the war:" Mr. White. - Have not thousands of men been put into other industries?

talk.start.para: - The Repatriation Department did not put as many men into secondary industries as were placed on the land.
- Is not the honorable member making out a wonderfully good case for the repeal of the Arbitration Act ?

- What are the Government's reasons for proposing that step? The Attorney-General stated the most important when he said that the purpose of the bill was to abolish dual controlof industry, from which nearly all our industrial evils result. How can he say that the abolition of the Arbitration Court will abolish dual control? The inference from his statement is that there will be only one controlling body in industry. That may be true of an industry peculiar to one State, but it is absurd to say that there will be only one control of industry throughout ' Australia. There will be six different bodies, and sometimes they will be attempting to control the one industry.
- There are seven now.

- The most the honorable member claims is, that whereas there are now seven controlling authorities, if this bill is passed there will be only six. But the Attorney-General says there will be only one.
- Hear, hear!

- No evidence has been produced in support of that extraordinary statement. The champions of the bill say that the abolition of the Federal Court will benefit the producers, the workers, and the manufacturers, and will reduce the cost of production. But how ? What will be reduced ?
- It will reduce the expensive overhead.

- The overhead, whatever it may mean, is surely not sufficiently great to permit of a substantial reduction of the cost of living and production throughout Australia. The Government states that wages will not be reduced, and that there will be no chaos in industry, because regulation by a State authority will continue. To say that this policy will reduce the cost of production is one thing; to show in what way it will do so is another. The Commonwealth Arbitration Court is linked up with the tariff policy of the Government. If the Government had said that all sections of the community must make sacrifices, and had brought forward a proposal for a general tariff reduction, the workers would have been less suspicious than they are ; but with the record that the Government has in regard to industrial matters, what else can it expect, when it does not propose to touch even one stone in the temple of the tariff, but on the contrary intends to add one or two more, and in addition to wipe away the particular tribunal which safeguards the workers of this country? There is not one gentleman on the front Government bench who knows anything about industrial matters. They have not been through the hard school of experience in which I and other honorable members were trained. They do not understand the psychology of the workers of this country. They overlook the fact that the sweeping away of this structure will not have the effect of destroying the federal character of the unions. The tendency throughout industry is to merge into larger bodies. The federal character of the labour unions has been developed and strengthened within recent years, and that development will continue in the years to come. If this measure becomes law, chaotic conditions will result from State tribunals endeavouring individually to regulate federal industries in opposition to federal industrial organizations. There will be -six different authorities.
- Instead of seven.

- The Attorney-General says that there will be only one, but now one of his supporters admits that there will be six. The primary producers, as well as the Labour organizations, believe in industry being federally controlled. My friend, the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser) also holds that belief. He has upon the notice paper the following motion : -

quote.para: That in the opinion of this House steps should be taken to induce the States to -agree to an amendment of the Constitution, which would permit of an Australian organization, with complete sectional control of internal and external marketing of each rural product by the producers of such commodity.

speech.para: It is not often that the honorable member and I are in agreement, but we agree in this matter, and I propose to support that motion. The wheat-growers of Australia are to-day clamouring for a federal organization. What is the objection that is raised by those who oppose the organization of the wheat-growing industry? It is that a compulsory pool in one State will be ineffective because of competition from other States. That is what the Labour unions say. In the dried fruits industry there is now before the courts a case concerning the seizure of fruit under the authority of certain State acts. The basis of the recommendation made by the Development and Migration Commission in regard to that industry was that there should be federal control and amalgamation of packing sheds. That commission inquired also into the canned fruits industry, and the basis of its recommendation was that it should be organized on a federal basis, and that there should be an amalgamation of the canning factories at Shepparton, Kyabram, Mooroopna, and Leeton. Wherever one turns, one finds that State control of primary industries is ineffective, and that almost to a man the primary producers are federalists.

Let it not be thought for one moment that I am in favour of the maintenance of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court as it exists at present. In the past I have criticized that court and the tariff policy of the Government. The real issue before this House is, not the existence of the court in its present form, but Federal versus State control of industry. When a choice has to be made between State and Federal control, I unhesitatingly choose the latter. The regulation of industry is admittedly a difficult problem, which is puzzling the best brains in. the civilized world to-day. Human nature being what it is, it is difficult to say whether any really satisfactory solution of the problem is possible under our present social system. While we have production for profit, it seems to me that we must have difficulties. In the last analysis we cannot compel a body of men to sell their labour, which is the only article they have to sell, at a rate that will not give them a reasonable return and ensure decent living conditions for those who are dependent upon them. On the other hand, can we rightly compel a man to keep his business open if it does not pay him to do so? It appears to me that our best course would be to have conciliation rather than arbitration legislation, and to provide machinery whereby both sides could endeavour to settle their problems in an amicable, peaceful way. I would give to any Government the necessary powers to maintain law and order, so that in the event of any serious conflict it could take steps to protect the interests of the community. It is wrong to wrangle and abuse each other, because we cannot make things perfect. We can only do our best. My sympathies have always been with the workmen of this country. I am and always have been one of them. I represent a primary producing constituency, if anything a conservative, not a radical, constituency. I believe in organization, and have been in the thick of every fight to organize the primary producers. I came into this House as a representative of organized farmers, who considered that they were not getting fair treatment from either of the two big parties. I still think that no political party will look after the interests of the farmers so well as one of their own making. I advised the farmers to send their own men . to Parliament to safeguard their interests, to support measures rather than men, and not to identify themselves with any other party. Some honorable members who sit on the Government side of the House were elected on that policy. It is still my policy, but it has ceased to be theirs. There are some farmers who say, " If you can only keep the dreadful Labour party off the Government benches, peace and prosperity will reign." I can honestly say that whenever the primary producers have organized with the object of shaking the middlemen off their backs or of improving their conditions economically, it has been not the workers, but those who represent the big business interests in this country, who have opposed them. We have said that, if there is to be pricefixation in respect of what we use in production, if others are to fix prices for us, we will fix the price of wheat. We therefore set out to organize the wheat pool. Who fought us? Not the Labour unions, but those who believe in maintaining the usual trade channels.

talk.start.para: - It would not be amiss if the honorable member mentioned the word " arbitration " now and again.

- I am dealing with an important aspect of arbitration. The economic aspect is very pertinent to the issue before the House. For years past the representatives of the manure companies have sat round a table and fixed the price of manure. The farmers decided to form their own co-operative manure company, and they set out to do it. Who fought them? Not workers' unions or the trades hall ; but the manure combine.
