The chairman of the Phosphate Co-operative Company, the honorable member for Echuca (Mr. Hill) is not in the chamber. I pay him a tribute for the good work that he has done as the. chairman of that company ; but he could tell those on the Government side a rather embarrassing story of the efforts of vested interests to prevent the co-operative company from starting in Victoria. When that company was established the price of superphosphate was immediately reduced by over ?1 a ton. To-day the manure interests have amalgamated, and it will now be a fight to the death between the organization of capital and the farmers' co-operative company. We have always had to fight when we have set out to emancipate ourselves economically. I give, still another illustration; as we failed to receive a fair deal from the press, we started a paper of our own. Some ?170,000 or ?180,000 of the farmers' hard-earned money was used in establishing the Morning Post in Melbourne. We said, " This will be our organ, and in it we shall give expression to our opinions." The other day I received a letter from a liquidator returning me 3s. or 4s. for ?1 shares. Who boycotted and eventually killed that newspaper? Not the workers' unions or the trades hall, but the Nationalist organizations in combination. That is my justification for the stand that I have taken ever since I have been in this Parliament.
- Does the honorable member suggest that there are "basher gangs"?

- I am suggesting nothing. The subject of " basher gangs," of " a seething mass of maggots," " running sores " and " f angless snakes " and similar nauseous expressions I leave to the dignified members of the Government. I hope that this measure will not be passed; but, if it is, I hope that the House will agree to the amendment which the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) proposes to move in committee. The people should be consulted. The Government has no mandate for the abolition of the federal arbitration system. It is rather extraordinary that a government that is usually so strong on mandates should do a thing like this without a mandate. How often has the Government in the past endeavoured to justify its actions by declaring that it has a mandate. The very fact that it had a mandate seemed to justify it in expecting the Opposition to raise no objection to any legislation that had been mentioned by Nationalists on the hustings. The right honorable member for North Sydney said that the Government's action in withdrawing the prosecution against John Brown would lose the Nationalist party tens of thousands of votes. The passage of this measure will have the same effect. Government members proudly proclaim the fact that they receive the vote of a large section of the workers of this country. That is true. They would not be on the treasury bench to-day had they not, during the last election, received the votes of thousands of organized workers, who not only voted for them, but also worked for the Nationalist cause. What will those men, and women, too, say when they find that their representatives in this chamber are assisting to pass legislation the operation of which will affect them adversely? The people of this country never for one moment dreamt that the Government, which claimed their support under the plea of the maintenance of law and order, would set about abolishing the federal arbitration system, thus dealing a deadly blow to the organizations to which they belong and to the industries from which their bread and butter is won. I suggest that the Government would be well advised, before passing this far-reaching legislation, to consult the people of Australia.

.- I have listened with great patience to a long debate, in the course of which the leaders of both sides fully supported by the rank and file of their parties have presented their views to this House. It is my lot to follow the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart). That honorable member and myself represent adjoining constituencies. For the most part he, like myself, is returned by the aid of the farming community. He takes his stand on this measure alongside the Labour Opposition. I take my stand alongside the Government, because I consider that this measure is a justification of the action that I took, together with the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Gregory), three years ago when it was almost political heresy to talk of the abolition of the central compulsory arbitration system. The honorable member for Swan and myself, during a sitting in Melbourne, fought a strenuous and prolonged fight against the combined parties in this House, and we succeeded finally in defeating the proposals in the country. I may say that my constituency was the only one in Victoria that recorded a majority vote for the proposals advocated by its representative in Parliament.

speech.para: I have listened conscientiously to this debate, endeavouring to find the main points of difference. I find that the compass has been boxed in the course of the debate. What members of the Labour party can explain away the vote cast at the referendum to grant full industrial powers to the Commonwealth when down they went like skittles in front of their constituents? The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Scullin) had at the former election a majority of over 20,000, yet at the referendum he had a deficit of 10,000, which made him 30,000 votes to the bad. The Prime Minister had a similar unfortunate experience. But the honorable member for Swan and myself were at least supported in our constituencies, for* the votes we cast and the views we expressed on that occasion. I have been a keen observer of the effect of the central compulsory system of arbitration on the economic and public life of Australia. It is useless for the Opposition to say that this legislation will pull down the temple of Labour. We are not to he carried away by cant and sob stuff. We can think for ourselves. We are here to do good for Australia. We have had 25 years experience of federal arbitration, yet, to-day, the financial and economic position of Australia is deplorable. Honorable members opposite talk of the high social standard of the people. Who enjoys it? It is not the tens of thousands of returned men, especially those on the land. We have more unemployment in our midst than- ever before in the history of Australia. The men who are workless cannot enjoy our high social standard. There is no clear money in industry now. The man on the land to-day is confronted with heavy production costs but little clear money. The man in business has little clear money to-day. The wage-earners are receiving high wages but they have no clear money. The purchasing power of money is not what it used to be. Our boys and girls who are reaching maturity have little opportunity to launch out on careers. Never before has it been so difficult to obtain employment. We are to-day suffering a severe depression, notwithstanding the past run of good seasons that we have had and the enormous sums that we have borrowed. To-day the economic and industrial life of this country has reached its worst stage. During the last fourteen years Australia has borrowed and expended ?800,000,000. Fourteen years ago the Commonwealth had no public debt, but the State debts amounted to ?320,000,000, borrowed over the whole period of responsible government, and the average rate of interest on them was ?3 32s. 6d.

To-day the aggregate public debt of the Commonwealth and the States is ?1,115,000,000, on which interest at an average rate of 5 per cent, is being paid, the annual interest bill being ?55,000,000, or an amount greater than the value of our annual wool clip. In 1924 our pension bill was ?3,200,000, but to-day it is in the region of ?19,000,000. Wool prices are approximately 33 per cent, lower than they were last year; the wheat harvest promises to be poor, and in the district represented by the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) the outlook is anything but promising; indeed, there is no certainty of a good - harvest in any portion of the agricultural belt in Australia. In these circumstances, the time has arrived for the Government to examine, completely and fearlessly, our financial and economic position. While we are here debating the manner in which industrial disputes should be settled, and the means by which rates of wages and living conditions can be adjusted, we are touching only one phase of the economic conditions of our country. It is necessary that we should engage in a much closer scrutiny, to ascertain the direction in which our general national policy should be amended.

We are not in a position to maintain false standards which now exist on borrowed money. I do not care what honorable members opposite may say, I am not afraid to assert that, while seeking to maintain these standards, we send representatives to the Mother Country, where there are 1,250,000 people unemployed. We tell the people there, in effect that they should adopt our standards, and pay the wages which our workers are receiving and at the same time we coolly ask if we can borrow another ?50,000,000 to maintain our conditions. This cannot continue. We had a severe rebuff a few days ago in connexion with the issue of Treasury bills in London for a period of twelve months, when we could borrow only at ?6 3s. per cent. The Commonwealth is reaching the limit of its borrowing capacity, and I am glad that the Government has at last realized that a Commonwealth compulsory arbitration policy is economically unsound. " Our federal arbitration policy has been in operation for 25 years, and has failed -even the workers. The Australian wage earner has a perfect right, in return for honest service, to enjoy sound economic conditions, and to receive a fair margin in the matter of remuneration to enable him to maintain his wife and family in comfort. I do not advocate the reduction of wages as the first necessity in a general economic overhaul. With the good times we all went up together and we must all come down together. In 1914, when this nation undertook heavy war activities, we incurred an enormous war debt. The conditions which prevailed at that time were responsible for the heavy expenditure of loan money. Huge contracts were entered into, almost regardless of the consequences. After the first year or two of the war, we experienced wonderful seasons, with high prices for our primary produce. Extensive borrowing of money caused an inflation of prices, the effect of which is still being felt, and whilst other countries have been writing down we have declined to do so. Like the ostrich, we are seeking to hide our head in the sand, while the rest of our body is still exposed. We cannot carry on our national work on a false basis, and the sooner we face the actual facts, the better it will be for the people. I am glad this measure has been introduced, as it may be the means of improving our economic position. Some honorable members have said that, when the measure becomes operative, there will be six authorities controlling industrial arbitration. There will be a separate authority in each State but one. But these authorities will not be in conflict. The State authorities will have sovereign powers within the State boundaries. It may be necessary to establish a coordinating authority in order to ensure fairly uniform conditions and to remove anomalies, but that is a matter for the States. I do not think there will be any overlapping. Who can be a more jealous custodian and guardian of the States' rights than the States themselves? Can a central authority be more solicitous for the interests of the people within a State than a State authority? The honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin) said he wished the Commonwealth and State arbitration systems to prevail. I can only surmise that he knows that the State of which he is one of the representatives is anxious that the control of- its industrial affairs should be in its own hands. Tasmania, which does not possess the resources of the mainland States, was once a happy and contented, if not altogether prosperous, community. For years, Tasmania controlled her own industrial situation in a satisfactory way. It was not until the Commonwealth's Conciliation and Arbitration Act came into operation, that she began to feel thud after thud, and eventually found that she could not stand up to the burden. This forced the Government of that State to come, cap in hand, to the Commonwealth for a financial grant of ?300,000 or ?400,000, in order to maintain her position under the new system.

talk.start.para: - Tasmania is only getting back money to which she is entitled.

- For years Tasmania had to carry the burden of developing the State under federal arbitration awards without federal assistance. Western Australia and South Australia have been compelled to approach the central authority in the same way. The conditions experienced by the States I have mentioned have, they claim, been imposed upon them by the legislation of the federal authority. A federal industrial authority is too costly, too cumbersome, and too slow, and many workers are tired of the Commonwealth arbitration system. Some honorable members opposite say that the workers will rise in open revolt when the industrial machinery is in the hands of a State authority, but in Queensland and . New South Wales the industrialists have been taking advantage of the opportunities offered by the State tribunals. I am not opposed .to rivalry and competition. I do not want Australia to be controlled under a system of unification. We have a diversity of ideals, of climate, and of soils, and there should also be diversity of control; with the States legislating in their own interests and working out their own economic life. I do not believe that a National Parliament in Canberra is the best informed body to deal with the industrial life of the whole of Australia. On the contrary, I find that the system, under which we are operating is too cumbersome and too costly, and that we are too far removed from the people of the States. The State authorities can exercise better control and supervision over those things, which are dominating factors in our national life. I do not wish to traverse th'e arguments which have been adduced by honorable members on both sides of the chamber, but I welcome the opportunity to try out a new system under which, I hope, every industry in Australia will receive a fair deal, and every workman will be able to receive a fair wage, so that they and those dependent upon them will feel that there is a prospect of a bright and prosperous future.

.- It must be evident to a majority of the. Australian people that this measure, which is undoubtedly the most important that has ever been placed before this Parliament, has been introduced- at the instigation of the big financial interests; not only in Australia, but overseas. I have listened with a great deal of interest to the speeches of honorable members, and particularly to that of the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers), who has not spoken in this chamber since the 22nd March. Prior to that date, the honorable member had something to say on almost every subject which came before the House for discussion. The honorable member for Wannon, who said that there had been a good deal of " sob-stuff " used by honorable members on this side of the chamber, also referred to the question of unemployment; but I should like to ask the honorable member what he or the Government which he is supporting has done to solve the unemployment problem. The Government has aggravated the situation by allowing immigrants to come into this country when there is a large army of unemployed, many of whom are starving. When the position of the coal industry was under consideration, on the 22nd March of this year, the honorable member for Wannon said that any one possessing a spark of humanity could not disregard the earnest appeal which had been made by the honorable member for Hunter. He said -

quote.para: I appeal to the Prime Minister to set his inquiry afoot. We, in this chamber, stand for the people of the nation and not for a privileged few. If the coal-owners have closed their mines merely to put their business on a better profit-earning basis, they arc doing an injustice to the nation, for coal is an essential daily commodity. This is not a chamber to be moved merely by sentiment. We must weigh the facts and hold the scales of justice evenly. I appeal to the Prime Minister to take action to have this matter cleared up.

speech.para: What action has the honorable member for Wannon taken to assist in that direction? When the motion of want of confidence was launched by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore), he was absent; but when a division was taken at 7.30 a.m. after an all-night sitting he did not assist those for whom he had previously pleaded, but supported the Government in its action in withdrawing the prosecution against J ohn Brown. Such men should not speak of sob-stuff, because when the "hard word" is put on them, they are like snails and crawl into their dugouts. There is another individual to whom I have listened with considerable interest and amusement, the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green). He said that he never heard anybody from this side of the House, although we advocate the retention of the Arbitration Court, state why we supported the timber workers when they broke an award. I personally support the timber workers' refusal to comply with that pernicious award. It was meted out to them by an old-age pensioner, a fossil from Queensland, who was, and still is, receiving a pension of ?1,000 a year from the Queensland Government.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member is entitled to criticize the principles embodied in judgments; but must not use terms which in any way reflect upon the judiciary.

- I contend that this judgment was an unjust one. It was founded upon an amendment of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration - Act which this party strenuously opposed. A conference was held between the representatives of the timber workers and the timber merchants in Melbourne, and it was agreed by the parties that an inquiry into prevailing conditions was necessary; that it would last at least six months. Judge Lukin conducted an inquiry - and he promulgated his decision within two weeks. Putting it very mildly, I contend that it was indecently unfair for a man receiving a pension of ?1,000, and a salary of ?2,500 per annum, which works out at approximately ?70 a week, to determine that workers in the timber industry should receive only from ?3 10s: to ?4 10s. a week. .1 fail to see that justice was done, and, so far as the Lukin award is concerned, I shall support the action of the timber workers every time an opportunity presents itself for me to do so.

speech.para: When dealing with the proposal of the Federal Government to vacate the field of federal arbitration, I must primarily consider the position of the organization which is in a large measure responsible for my presence in this chamber. That organization has very clearly defined views on the subject. It has declared against the methods of the court, probably impelled to do so by the legal entanglements that have always delayed the hearing of claims, and by the failure of the tribunal to deal adequately with all aspects of the coal industry. Particularly is it influenced in its decision by the withdrawal of the prosecution against John Brown, who broke the very award under which the coal miners worked. It is further influenced in its decision by the attitude of this Government in standing by and allowing the coal barons of Australia to continue to break that award and to go scot free. If the workers break an award there is a different story to tell. I refresh the memory of honorable members by recalling the history of the early miners' leaders, some of whom were jailed for periods of from six months to two years for infringing the laws of the country, and refer particularly to the Peter Bowling strike. The right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) knows something about that. Those men were taken away from their homes in leg irons, and put into gaol because they were mine union leaders. Yet John Brown and the rest of the coal-owners go scot free. The honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) mentioned the incidence of strikes in the coal industry, and declared that the coal miners do not obey awards. I ask him to give me an instance.

talk.start.para: - Oh, he does not know anything about awards.

- No, he talks a lot of bunkum. That is not to be wondered at, as he appears to come from a place where they have plenty of sheep - and goats. The coal-miners are always prepared to work under their awards, but they have not been allowed to do so. I have tender recollections of my father and my elder brother, with their fellow-workers in and around old Lambton, being confronted with Gatling guns. The New South Wales Government under the instructions of Sir Henry Parkes, was responsible for that callous action. Is that the system to which honorable members opposite desire . to return? Is that the open economic ring? Is it the desire of honorable members opposite to go back to the practices of 1888? If it is, they may rest assured that they will get what they are looking for.

speech.para: I am convinced that the granting of arbitration awards by the Federal or State Courts is governed by the economic strength of the unions concerned. The coal-miners' organization is peculiar in this respect. It was inaugurated by men who migrated to Australia determined that the conditions which prevailed in the mines in Great Britain should not prevail here; that there should be no exploitation and sweating of child labour in mines, or the employment on the mine surface of women. Those stalwarts founded an organization composed of the best elements of the incipient trade union movement in Australia. That union gathered to itself a tremendous economic strength, which gave it the capacity to fight for what it considered to be equitable wages and conditions. And it would have continued to progress in that direction had it not been for the callous action of this Government and the Government of New South Wales, who deliberately ranged themselves behind the coal barons. The coal-miners were carrying on their fight strictly within the law of the country, and, although harassed and baited by the coal-owners, for eighteen months they refused to break the law. Then the coal-owners, becoming desperate, took matters into their own hands and broke the award. That is now history, and I do not propose further to dilate upon the facts. I am convinced that in supporting those coal barons in an illegal action this Government provided another nail for its coffin and this fact . would be demonstrated if they faced an election on this issue.

History has shown that nothing tangible can be accomplished by the workers unless backed up by strong organization. That applies particularly in the industrial field, and it has always been found by the unions that the industrial tribunals set up by parliaments will grant no more than the applicants are strong enough to demand. The workers, not only in the mining industry, but iu all industries, are beginning to realize that only in effective organization does their salvation lie. The miners do not expect me to adopt a selfish attitude on this matter; they realize that they have comrades who are not in a position to win concessions from the employers by their own efforts through lack of organization. The Arbitration Court has provided safeguards for them, and I cannot be a. party to removing those safeguards. If they were removed, the workers would be thrown upon the tender mercies of six different' governments, which would be competing one against another in an endeavour to keep production costs at the lowest possible level. What has already happened in the coal-mining industry would happen in every industry throughout Australia, particularly if this bill is passed. The country's oversea coal trade, has suffered as the result of competition from cheap labour countries. To win back that trade, the miners would have to accept conditions equal to those of coolie labourers in other parts of the world. If the court were abolished the conditions prevailing in Australia in prefederation days would be restored. Even the wages boards, and other industrial tribunals operating in the States, have been won only as a result of agitation by organized labour, political and industrial. Giving evidence before the royal commission that was inquiring into the working of the first wages board the president of the Melbourne Shop-keepers Association, in Melbourne, callously said that no nation had ever been built up by the help of industrial legislation. He admitted that a great deal of sweating went on; but it was beneficial to the nation. " You cannot win a battle," he added, " without killing a lot of men." There has been much talk about ." basher gangs " ; but honorable members on the other side of the House have more in common with " basher gangs " than have the members of any working-class organization. Recently Mr. J. N. Grace, speaking on behalf of the council of the Retailers Association, said that he was very pleased that the Prime Minister had decided to abolish the Federal Arbitration Court, and he would like to see the other courts abolished, also. This was no time for increases of wages, or for a 44-hour week. In his judgment 48 hours a week were few enough. Moreover, he strongly objected to the shops closing at a quarter to six at night, and at twelve on Saturdays. Evidently he would like to see the shops opened for trade during church services, so that people might buy his wares during the interval when the collection was being taken up. Those who are supporting the Government in its determination to abolish the Arbitration Court would like to see a return to the open economic ring. Only last week, when I was in my constituency, I was told of the method adopted by one business man, of the " Johnnie-all-sorts type " to add to his income. Recognizing that coal is very scarce around Newcastle at the present time, he started to sell it. There are numerous falls in abandoned workings where coal may be obtained and this person employed little children, from eight years of age up to fourteen, to go down these falls, and carry out coal in their little arms under dangerous roofs, and through other dangers. It was placed in corn-sacks, for which he paid them 6d. a sack, and then sold this coal to the public at from 5s. to 7s. a sack. There we have exploitation of child labour going on even in my own constituency. This is the type of person who wants arbitration abolished so that he can have an " open go ". The coalowners want the wage-for-age scale abolished in the mines for boys, so that they can pay them by results or in other words, sweat child labour. It is absurd to say that it will be of any advantage economically to Australia to abolish the Arbitration Court. The Prime Minister said that the abolition of the court would effect a saving of some thousands of pounds a year. If it is necessary to save money, why does not the Government take its courage in its hands and ask the people for power to abolish the State governments, and to vest supreme power in this Parliament, as was promised when federation was agreed to. If this were done it would effect a saving, not of ?10,000 only, but of millions of pounds, through the abolition of costly State parliaments, and all the paraphernalia of State departments. We have been told that it is necessary to economize; but no member of the Government has ever said that the time has arrived when capital should be placed in the witness-box and made to divulge its profits; when it should be made to tell what it is getting out of the great national industries which are as vital to the country's progress as water and air are to human beings. I have never heard any one suggest that, in order to help the country out of the financial morass in which it is struggling at present, those who invested money in war loans at 6 per cent., and who are still receiving that interest on their investments, should be asked to make some sacrifice. It is grotesquely unfair that the workers should be asked to accept reduced wages when those who have invested their capital at high rates of interest are not called upon to sacrifice a penny, either in dividends, rent or interest. It is not fair. Their only cry is that the wages of the workers must be reduced. There is no reference to those who, for business reasons, said they could not go to the war, or to those who refused to subscribe to the war loans until the rate of interest was raised to 6 per cent. If those investors had been half as patriotic as the men who enlisted, they would have lent their country their money free of interest. If it is right that returned soldiers employed in the mines in my constituency should be turned out of war service homes, together with their wives and children, because, owing to the lockout, they cannot pay their instalments, it is right also, that those who exploited the country should receive no more interest on the money they put into the war loans. Action along that line would assist in getting the country out of its present difficulties. The Prime Minister extols piece-work, as does also the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green). The miners have always worked piecework; they have always been paid by results. Mention has been made of the strikes and lockouts in the coal industry. Piece-work means competition between workers; it breeds discontent, dissatisfac tion and turmoil. The troubles in the coal industry have been caused by the continual pin pricks to which the workers have been subjected by the owners and managers of the mines, who seem always to be trying to filch something from their employees. In a dangerous occupation such as coal-mining, piece-work causes many casualties. Men are forced into workings that are dangerous. If they refuse to work in such places, they have to go home, as in many instances no other jobs are found for them. The result is that many of them are taken from the mines, not to their homes, but to the cemeteries. The proportion of casualties to the number of workers employed is greater in the coalmining industry than in any other industry. Yet we hear the coal-miners described by the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) as "men who will not work." These men who have always endeavoured to do the best for the development and protection of the country want to work to-day, but they are not allowed to do so. From among the miners in my constituency and in Newcastle, two battalions of infantry and one mining battalion were sent from Australia to take part in the Great War. To-day, those of them who returned are having their pensions reduced and their homes taken from them. This is their reward. They have been taught a bitter lesson which which will not be forgotten by them or by their children. It is remarkable that the Government should desire to rush this measure through before the report of the Royal Commission on the Constitution is tabled. The employers in industry are asking for the removal of the Arbitration Court because it interferes with the conduct of their businesses.

talk.start.para: - Mr. Speaker! I call attention to the state of the House.

- I submit, Mr. Speaker, that members of the Opposition have no right to ask that the bells be rung to call a quorum when it is well known that a quorum exists within the precincts of the House. In the House of Commons it is considered sufficient that Mr. Speaker shall be satisfied that a quorum of members is within the build ing. That is also the established practice in several of the State Parliaments; I know it to be so in South Australia and Queensland. You, Mr. Speaker, are, of course, well acquainted with what May says regarding the duties and powers of the occupant of your office in relation to the formation of a quorum. In the House of Commons, when the Speaker was satisfied of the existence of a quorum in the building, he has declined to count the House. I point out, too, that although an Opposition member was addressing the House when attention was drawn to the lack of a quorum, only two members of the Labour party were in the chamber. The others are sleeping in various portions of the building, and Government supporters are expected to keep a House together. You will realize, Mr. Speaker, that it is difficult to retain a quorum in the chamber if members on one side only attend. I trust that in this matter you, sir, will be guided by the practice of the Mother of Parliaments, and set out in May at page 224; allowing the debate to continue without interruption so long as you are satisfied that a quorum exists within the precincts of the House.

- My reading of May is that Mr. Speaker must be satisfied that the number of members required to form a quorum is present in the House. Before you call upon the honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) to continue his speech you .will, I assume, satisfy yourself that a quorum is actually present in this chamber. If honorable members are walking in the gardens, or are in other portions of the building, taking no interest in the business under discussion, and some one, considering that in courtesy to the member addressing the House they should attend to hear his remarks, calls attention to the state of the House, they, I take it, must be actually in the chamber to be counted as part of the quorum. It is, I realize, a question of the interpretation of the language used in May, which I take to mean that the Speaker must satisfy himself that a sufficient number of members is actually present in the chamber. The honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Bernard Corser) complains that Opposition members have left the chamber, and suggests that they have done so purposely. I point out that honorable members on this side of the House have expressed the view that it is unreasonable and unnecessary to sit two nights in succession.
- The honorable member is departing from the point of order.

- I am only following the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser), who endeavoured to tell . you, Mr. Speaker, what you should do in this matter. I claim that I am in order in pointing out the circumstances of the case, for they are important. In the present circumstances it is the duty of the Government to maintain a quorum. The Government has called the tune, and it must dance to it. The Government has said that the sitting will be continued until the second reading has been disposed of, notwithstanding the fatigue occasioned by so long a sitting.

- This question has been raised on a number of occasions, as you, Mr. Speaker, are doubtless aware. When, in the past, attention has been called to the state of the House, Speakers have ruled that they would not allow an incessant calling together of members, and it has been the practice to allow a quarter of an hour to elapse after the calling of a quorum before the bells will be rung again.

- It is the duty of the honorable members, irrespective of party, to assist in maintaining a quorum for the conduct of public business, "and only those whom the Speaker can see actually within the bar of the House are counted by him. Regard cannot be had to those who may be within the precincts. This is shown by the following paragraph in the Constitution : -

quote.para: Until the Parliament otherwise provides, the presence of at least one-third of the whole number of the members of the House of Representatives shall be necessary to constitute a meeting of the House for the exercise of its powers.

speech.para: I would also refer honorable members to Standing Orders 33 and 34. As the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Fenton) has said, it has been the practice that fifteen minutes should elapse between calls for a quorum; calling for a quorum at more frequent intervals appears to have been considered to be in the nature of an obstruction to _the business of the House. I have taken note of the calls made during this debate, and in every instance it appeared to me that at least fifteen minutes had elapsed between them. [Quorum formed.]

talk.start.para: - The employers have fostered the agitation for the abandonment of arbitration in the Commonwealth sphere, because it has interfered to some extent with their business. But they have not been the only agitators. The Pastoral Review - the squatter's journal of the 16th September, 1921, contained an article, in which the following sentence appeared : -

quote.para: To institute successful immigration, we must first burn our Arbitration Acts and abolish the basic wage. ' ,

speech.para: The Government arid its supporters hope, that by evacuating the field of industrial arbitration, they will be able to force the workers into subjection. They anticipate that competition between the States will bring about a reduction in wages. The bill has also been introduced because the Government has been made to look utterly stupid because of its refusal to enforce the law against the employers, notably, Mr. John Brown, the coal baron.

As the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) pointed out, the people have given no mandate for the taking of this step. Otherwise, we should have heard something about it in the Governor-General's speech. The Government has stolen a march on the people. It has been consorting too much of late with men of the John Brown type. Not only the Prime Minister, but also the State Premiers, have been bluffed by this gentleman. I predicted that in %March last. The result has been that the coalmines are still inactive, and 36,000 people have been reduced to a state of destitution. The National Government is in very truth in a sorry plight over it.

The bill is part of a determined effort to smash the federated organizations of the workers. The employers hope that by this means they will be able to attack the trade unionists first of all in the weakest State. If they can secure a reduction of wages in one State, they will make similar efforts in other States. Thus they hope to force down the standard of living in

Australia. The introduction of this bill is one of the most callous and cold-blooded acts that any Commonwealth Government has committed. We have been told repeatedly that the cost of production must be reduced. We are now able to see that the Government intends that the only sacrifice to be made to achieve this end shall come from the workers. There is no suggestion that interest rates should be reduced or that profits should he limited. The workers alone are to be called upon to bear the burden. The Government would not, of course, dream of demanding a sacrifice from its wealthy supporters. It hopes that by forcing the workers to speed up their activities, production costs will be reduced and profits increased. I worked in the coal-mines of Western Australia for five years on a daily wage, and work was carried on without cessation. We had only five days' stoppage in the whole period. I know that the contract system is now in vogue in those mines, but the Western Australian mine-owners do not seem to he as avaricious as those of the northern coal-fields.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member's time has expired.
- Seeing that at least fifteen minutes of my time was taken up in the discussion of a point of order, I should like an extension of time.
- No allowance can be made for time occupied in the discussion of points of order.

- In view of the fact that I was responsible for the call for a quorum, which was decided on a point of order, and resulted in a debate which curtailed the time available to the honorable member for Hunter, would I be in order in asking for leave to move that he be granted an extension of time?
- Yes.
- I ask leave to move accordingly. (Leave refused.)

. - I do not wish to cast a vote on the second reading of this momentous measure without briefly indicating my reasons for supporting it, and also expressing my gratification at its introduction. The honorable member for Barton (Mr. Tully), speaking during the small hours of this morning, quoted from the speeches of a number of honorable members on the subject of Commonwealth conciliation and arbitration. He endeavoured to show that, in supporting this bill, a number of those honorable gentleman were recanting views previously expressed by them. He quoted a sentence or two from some remarks that I made during the second-reading debate on the amending Conciliation and Arbitration Bill, which was before us on the 23rd May, 1928. I should like, to read his quotation, ,and, in fairness to myself, continue it for another sentence or two. Throughout this debate, many of the quotations used, if begun a sentence or two earlier or continued a little further would have assumed a somewhat different complexion from that suggested. On that occasion, I followed the honorable member for "Wannon (Mr Rodgers), who said he believed that the central system of compulsory arbitration was an absolute failure. He also maintained that the Commonwealth Arbitration Court had not succeeded in bringing about industrial peace, and he apparently agreed with those who have stated that the court really tended to promote industrial unrest. After referring to the honorable member's remarks, I said -

quote.para: However, there are to-day tens of thousands of workers in Australia who are satisfied with the existing system, and are abiding by the awards of the court. After all, only a few unions - important ones, undoubtedly - come into conflict with those awards. I certainly think - and I am sure the honorable member for Wannon will agree with me - that a system which for the last 24 .years has been working satisfactorily from the point of view of tens of thousands of workers must be continued,

speech.para: That is where the honorable member's quotation of my remarks ended; but I went on -

quote.para: And that the main duty of those who believe in arbitration is to try to improve it wherever that can be done. I have no knowledge of the intentions of the Government, but I personally think that this should be regarded as the last attempt to place that system on a sound basis; and should it fail I do not think that any one would cavil at the Government if it endeavoured to find some other means of obtaining industrial peace in this country.

speech.para: I certainly think that the honorable member for Barton might have completed my statement. I remember the occasion well. The honorable member for Hume (Mr. Parker Moloney) who followed, took me to task for expressing the opinion that I did. Shortly after that, I wrote to the secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Brisbane, and requested that I should be permitted to address the members of that body in regard to this particular legislation, with the intention of explaining to the best of my ability the object of the Government in bringing it down. They agreed to' my request, and I was shortly afterwards given the unusual pleasure and privilege of addressing them in the Brisbane Trades Hall, when a number of representatives of other unions were also present. I shall always retain the happiest recollections of that meeting. I have never been present at a better-conducted gathering. I reiterated the statement that I had made in this House, and not long afterwards I again submitted myself to the suffrages of the people of Brisbane, who did me the honour of returning me with a majority of 5,000 votes. I have no hesitation in supporting the bill before the house.

Much has been said about the lack of a mandate for the introduction of this legislation. Once again, I would remind honorable members that the Prime Minister, on the 3rd July last year, stated in Perth that unless we got away from the spectacle of strikes proceeding concurrently with awards of the court, the whole system of arbitration would have to go. "When he delivered his policy speech in October, 1928, he made it plain that the Government was prepared to consider any alternative to our present industrial arbitration laws, which would enable the ends they were designed to secure to be more satisfactory achieved. During the debate upon the Transport Workers Bill in February this year, he repeated the warning, and, lastly, on the 17th May, with special reference to the strike that was proceeding in the timber industry, he issued a final and most definite warning. On other occasions, also, he indicated to the people the action the Government would consider it necessary to take, should the industrial conditions remain as they were. Surely that was definite enough. Honorable members who argue that the Government had no mandate for its action have not seriously attempted to support their contention.

I have listened most carefully to the speeches delivered on this hill. I was struck by the remarks of the honorable member for Macquarie (Mr. Chifley). From his point of view, it was a most able speech, and well delivered. It was free from exaggeration. But I cannot agree with many of the views he expressed, particularly in his contention that this legislation would in any way reduce the dignity of the Federal Parliament; in fact, I think it will raise it. Not long ago, certain honorable members opposite complained that, by bringing down the Financial Agreement Bill, the Government was doing all it possibly could to diminish the powers of the States. So it appears that, whatever action the Government takes, some honorable members on the Opposition side must oppose it.

I was impressed by the speech delivered by the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin). But I could hot follow his arguments. I think that he is the only member who has spoken on this hill who definitely favours a dual control of industry. The honorable gentleman pointed out that the Commonwealth is a very large area ; that some men might be engaged in a certain industry, say, at Longreach, in "Western Queensland, while other men might be employed in the same industry at Normanton. It is quite possible, and probable, he said, that federal awards made in Melbourne or Sydney in that industry would not be suitable for those distant localities, and would not be acceptable. I quite agree with that; but it supports the legislation that the Government has brought down.

talk.start.para: - He said that there were, other industries that required uniform legislation throughout the Commonwealth.

- Yes ; and I think that reference was made to that fact by the Attorney-General in his speech in this chamber. At 'the present time the members of the "Western Australian Branch of the Timber Works Association have broken up the union and formed a new one, with the object of applying to the State court for an award. Whether it can do so or not is, I believe, a matter that has not yet been decided by the High Court. The Prime Minister, and also the Attorney-General, indicated very clearly to the House and the country the reasons why this measure was brought down. Honorable members on both sides have constantly referred to and quoted the late Mr. Justice Higgins' awards and writings. The Attorney-General, in his speech, said that the fundamental principle underlying the bill was found in the words of Mr. Justice Higgins, in his book A New Province for Law and Order -

quote.para: If there is to be regulation, and there must be, it should como from one authority.

speech.para: I think that it. will be admitted, if a review is made of the history of Commonwealth conciliation and arbitration, that the Government led by the Prime Minister has made the greatest possible effort to insure its effective working. That is my opinion, and I am sure it is shared by the majority of the people of this country. Three years ago the Government, recognizing the chaotic conditions that have been brought about by overlapping arbitration awards, took a referendum of the people, and invited them to grant further powers to the Commonwealth ; but that request was refused. I shall not say more about that, because constant reference has been made to the referendum, and the reasons for its failure. Then there followed a comprehensive overhaul of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. . I maintain that everything possible was done to make amendments of the law that would be acceptable .to those engaged in industry. The Government consulted organizations of employers and employees, inviting their assistance and co-operation ; suggestions were asked for, and everyeffort made to make the whole scheme of compulsory arbitration more acceptable to those engaged in industry. Particular effort was made in the amending bill to ensure the observance of awards. But since it was passed, little more than twelve months ago, the waterside workers and the timber workers have struck against awards of the court. Both strikes were definite refusals to obey the industrial laws of the country. No government, whether Nationalist or Labour, could leave matters as they are at present and expect to retain the confidence and respect of the people. It appears also thatso further improvement of the existing laws is possible. The present state of affairs cannot continue, and there remains no alternative but to evacuate the field of industrial arbitration in favour of the States. That is the course which the Government is proposing. It is misleading to say that the Commonwealth's retirement from this field will leave the worker and the fair employer without protection. To say that is to cast a grave reflection on the parliaments of the States. After all, more workers are operating under' the awards and determinations of State authorities to-day than under the awards of the Commonwealth Court, and the Attorney-General has clearly indicated that there is no legal limit to the power of a State authority to deal with disputes, so far as they affect employers and employees within the boundaries of that State. The people have been assured by the Prime Minister that it is not the intention of the Government to allow industrial relationships to come again under what has been termed the law of the jungle. Such a step is not contemplated for a moment by the Government. All honorable members recognize that a return to conditions which would enable the unscrupulous employer to take an unfair advantage of his employees would be a retrograde and unthinkable step.

The bill makes definite provision for all awards and agreements registered in the Commonwealth Court to remain in force for a period sufficient to enable those interested to transfer to the industrial jurisdiction of the States. It is unnecessary at this stage to say that the Government, and those who support it, stand definitely for an adequate basic wage, approved working conditions, and as high a standard of living as is economically possible. If the workers have a grievance against this legislation - and their representativesprofess that they have - they must place the blame upon those of their own leaders and members who for a considerable time have held the Commonwealth Court up to ridicule, and wilfully and deliberately undermined the principle of federal compulsory arbitration. Thereby they have done untold damage. Twenty-five years ago, the people were urged to accept a system of compulsory arbitration, and were led to believe that it would usher in an. unbroken era of industrial peace, based upon judge-made industrial law; that all decisions of the court would be obeyed, and that if breaches occurred penalties would be enforced. But to-day we have reached a state of almost hopeless industrial confusion, and industry is wellnigh paralysed by clashing awards. One of the most serious disabilities under which the Federal Court labours is its inability to enforce its jurisdiction. The majority of the people are sick of existing conditions, and tired of a law under which one factory alone is subject to 38 different awards and wages boards determinations. The campaign against the principle of compulsory arbitration has been proceeding since 1927, and it has been organized by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, which claims to represent a large number of the unions. How many it does represent not even the Attorney-General has been able to ascertain. During this debate frequent reference has been made to the PanPacific Worker, which is issued by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions and the Pacific Relations Committee, and claims to represent the views of a large number of unions throughout the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: - No.

- The Pan-Pacific Worker is the official organ of the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, and its astounding views on compulsory arbitration have done untold damage during the last couple of years. I understand that honorable members opposite repudiate that journal.
- It does not speak for Labour at all.

- Then the claims of the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, which publishes the journal, that it represents a large number of unions must also be repudiated by honorable members opposite. They must take into account the harm done to the ordinary unionist by the poisonous matter that is published in this journal. lt is not denied by any honorable member supporting the Government that the Federal Court has rendered very great service, hut to-day the financial and economic position of the country is such that burdens must be removed from industry. Opponents of the bill have said that the object of the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General is to reduce wages and lower the standard of living. I repudiate that absolutely. There are other burdens that can be removed from industry, and amongst the heaviest are the tremendous expenditure in connexion with arbitration, and the uncertainty arising out of dual control. These have done more than anything else to retard the further investment of capital in this country. There is plenty of money available for investment in industry if a feeling of certainty in regard to the future can be established.

speech.para: To overcome the existing evil of dual control three courses are open. The first is an appeal by referendum to the people for a grant of increased power to this Parliament. The suggestion has been made inside and outside this House that, notwithstanding previous refusals, the Government should have again appealed to the people. Possibly the real attitude of labour generally to the 1926 referendum proposals was expressed by a union secretary, who said that an extension of the Commonwealth power was desirable, but should only be supported by the workers when a Labour government was in power. That contention had a lot to do with the failure of that appeal. We must realize that the determination of the jurisdiction of the Federal Court will enable the States to set up whatever machinery is required by the various industries. Many of them will be able to devise their own machinery for the settlement of grievances and the fixation of wages and working conditions. The repeal of the federal legislation will also relieve organizations of employers and employees of the cost inseparable from the present system, will result in more expeditious settlements, and will enable matters which are at issue to be dealt with without necessitating the artificial creation of disputes. The fact that the existence of a dispute was a condition precedent to the functioning of the court has been one of the most prolific causes of trouble. Furthermore, industrial relationship will be entirely removed from the atmosphere of litigation, and employers and employees will be encouraged ' to come closer together for the settlement of their differences. That will be perhaps the greatest advantage that will accrue from this legislation. There is also absent now a sense of finality, and that must tend to uncertainty. It, to a greater extent than any other factor, is responsible for the condition in which industry finds itself to-day. A return which has been issued by the court shows that eight industrial organizations were involved in an expenditure of over ?26,000 in connexion with their representations to the court; while a financial statement of the Australian Railways Union shows that in six years the costs of that organization in connexion with arbitration proceedings exceeded ?9,000. Over ?6,500 was spent by employers in the building trade to obtain a determination as to whether the builders' labourers' case should have been adjudicated upon by a Federal or a State tribunal. With the exception of the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin) - who, I repeat made a very able speech - honorable members opposite are prepared to admit the defects of divided control. I cannot conceive how they can base their opposition to this measure upon a real desire to retain the Federal Court. Members of the Labour party have urged that there should be a further development of the Industrial Peace Act, which they opposed at every stage, and which labours under exactly the same constitutional difficulties as those that beset our Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Any system of industrial arbitration or regulation must be doomed unless it is supported by those who are engaged in industry. The whole of the industrial legislation that has been introduced by this Government has been misrepresented repeatedly, and that misrepresentation has gone a long way towards preventing it from operating successfully. Those who .have been responsible for such misrepresentation cannot escape the charge of making use of the industrial weapon to secure political control.

I support the bill without hesitation, because I honestly believe that it will do much to improve our industrial relations. I am quite convinced that it will not in any way act detrimentally to the workers of this country. If I thought for one moment that it would do so, I should not support it. I feel quite confident that it will bring about a better position in industry than that which exists to-day. If it does that, we shall have gone a long way towards improving the conditions of the people of this country.

talk.start.para: . - I feel sure that every honorable member listened with pleasure to the contribution to the debate that has just been made by the honorable member for Brisbane (Mr. D. Cameron). Naturally, however, I cannot agree with many of his contentions. For example, he complained that there is a lack of investment of capital in Australia owing to industrial unrest. That is not borne out by the latest figures that have been issued by the Government Statistician, which show that the total production of all industries in Australia last year was valued at ?450,000,000, an increase on the previous year of ?35,000,000. Those figures refer to primary as well as secondary industries, and although one is not prepared to admit that conditions are as good as we should like them to be, they are, nevertheless, not so bad as they might be.

speech.para: The honorable member also said, that certain union secretaries had opposed the referendums submitted to the people by this Government, because they were put forward by an anti-Labour Government. I shall not say whether that was or was not their reason. I do know, however, that when the Fisher Government in 1911 and 1913, submitted to the people proposals for an amendment of the Constitution, in the direction of enlarging the powers of the Commonwealth in relation to industrial matters, the attitude which he has accused these union secretaries of having taken up, was adopted by Sir William Irvine, the predecessor of the present Prime Minister in the Flinders seat. Speaking in the Commonwealth Parliament he said -

quote.para: Certainly our Constitution should be amended. We should have larger industrial powers. We should have larger powers over trade and commerce. We should have larger powers over corporations. But because there is a Labour Government in office at the present time, and they are submitting these referendums, I feel disposed to oppose them.

speech.para: There are many unions whose members would not be able to obtain a proper recognition of their claims were it not for the existence of the Federal Court. The flour milling industry is established in every wheat-growing State, and there is a considerable export of flour from Australia. I have received the following communication from the Federated Millers and Mill Employees Association -

quote.para: In the flour milling industry to-day (July. 1.920), we have men - not one or two, but several of them - who not so many years ago worked twelve hours a day for six days a week, alternating weekly day and night shift. One week from 6 a.m. to (i p.m. daily and the other from G p.m. to G a.m. daily. Fancy men being required to work all night in this trade, from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. each day, for 72 hours a week. That time was bank to bank. The time occupied in going to, preparing for, and coming from their work, would come out of their own time - the other twelve hours of each day.

These conditions have only been ameliorated principally by class organization and action, and directly by country and city branches amalgamating as a State, and States federating as one organization, and improving members' conditions through the channels of the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Court.

State branches have been told by arbitrators and judges of State industrial tribunals that claims, although proved, could not be granted on account of interstate competition - the employers' main argument.

speech.para: It is not a very healthy industry at the best of times; but working for twelve hours during the night must have a deleterious effect upon the health of those who engage in it. That was the state of affairs which existed until the men organized on a federal basis and obtained an award from the Federal Court. I have also received a communication from the union to which I have belonged for very many years, the printing industry union. I have placed in the possession of the Prime Minister, a petition signed by over 4,000 employees in that industry in Victoria, and I believe that similar petitions have been forwarded from New South Wales and other States, appealing to the Government not to proceed with this legislation. This union has almost 34,000 members throughout the Commonwealth, and so far as production is concerned, it stands fourth on the list of industries in Australia. [Quorumformed.] Its total return amounts to just on ?12,000,000 per annum. I could cite instance after instance of members of unions having endeavoured to obtain recognition under State jurisdiction. The communication reads -

quote.para: INTERSTATE COMPETITION

During the hearing of applications for State awards by State unions within the printing industry, employers invariably gave evidence before the State tribunal to show that interstate competition existed, and that if the conditions of the States were not approximated, one set of employers would have an advantage against another.

In certain States, legislation within the field of industry which was beyond the jurisdiction of State industrial tribunals resulted in giving one State an advantage over another, and this was always the subject of complaint by representative employers. When the Federal Court heard and adjudicated upon the printing industry claim, it was recognized by both employers' and employees' organizations that uniform conditions would obtain for the first time in the history of the industry.

speech.para: Nearly all the industries in Australia have first tried to obtain State awards, but ultimately have been driven to the jurisdiction of the Federal Court. The State arbitration legislation is not uniform, and because of that, an industry in one State is sometimes given an advantage over a similar industry in another State. The late Mr. Justice Higgins said that nothing caused more irritation in industry than varying conditions of labour and employment in the different States. I have not the slightest hesitation in saying that there is less irritation, and more satisfaction, and harmony existing under Federal awards than under State awards. The time is long over-due for the granting of wider powers to the Commonwealth Parliament, and the establishment in the States of what might be termed provincial parliaments. That, I believe, is the -consensus of opinion throughout Australia. I had a very striking illustration of that on Saturday evening last at a large public gathering in my constituency. This subject was mentioned by the proposer of the toast of the Federal Parliament, and he complained bitterly that we have in Australia too many parliaments, which were costing the taxpayers enormous sums of money. I am also of that opinion. It is time that we gave this National Parliament the powers that we thought it would have, when federation first took place. Those who took some part in persuading the people of Australia to adopt the Constitution Bill did not, for one moment, believe that the State Parliaments would continue to function for any considerable period in their present form. I, myself, would have* opposed federation had I not thought that the Federal Parliament would be the supreme Parliament of Australia. The great leaders of that day were favorable to an extension of the powers of the Federal Parliament; but the present proposal of the Government to transfer the Commonwealth powers of arbitration to the States is belittling this Parliament and the Federation of which we all should be stout defenders.

The speeches on both sides of the House have been couched in somewhat bitter language, but the lead was given from the Government benches. When the Prime Minister was introducing the bill, he made use of personalities which might very well have been left unsaid. The Attorney-General attacked trade unionists, and others who are really excellent citizens. Although the Prime Minister indulged in strong language, he made one plea to which I have no objection. He said -

quote.para: I appeal to honorable members to approach the consideration of the bill in no party spirit, but with a sincere desire to do the best for the nation.

speech.para: Had that spirit animated honorable members during the debate, there would have been a better atmosphere in this chamber. As so much criticism has beer indulged in, it will not be amiss if I follow the example of other honorable members. For some considerable time the Federal Government has been seeking to alter the industrial system of Australia. The Industrial Mission that was sent to the United States of America was composed of representatives of both industrial parties. At the time I thought that the mission was justified as an indication that we were reaching out to the other countries to try to obtain some knowledge of their methods. Not satisfied with that, however, the Government invited the " Big Four " here, and they made certain recommendations. Then this Parliament passed the Crimes Act and the Transport Workers Act, and amended the Arbitration Act. All these things have been done with a view to drastically alter the industrial conditions of Australia. Mr. Hugh Grant Adam, associate editor of the Melbourne Herald, accompanied the Industrial Mission to the United States of America ; but he did not keep close to the arranged itinerary. He stepped into the by-paths of American industry, and saw how industries were conducted, and how workmen were treated. He kept apart altogether from the plan mapped out by those who were conducting the delegation through the various industries of the -United States of America. He said that the Australian delegation was about the fifth delegation that had paid a visit to the United States of America to investigate its methods of conducting industry, that every one of the delegations .saw the same institutions and industries, and travelled the same route. They were taken to the show places, and, consequently, did not get a true indication of American industrial methods. Let me quote a few paragraphs from Mr. Hugh Grant Adam's book, An Australian Looks at America, since it contains some valuable information that might be of interest to honorable members. He said -

quote.para: The argument I heard was, " Co-operation between labour and capital makes a country industrially prosperous. America is industrially prosperous. Therefore America has co-operation between labour and capital." America is enjoying many of the conditions that might be expected to result from the enthusiastic co-operation of labour in the business of profit-making. Labour works hard, at great speed, and for long hours. It does so because the pace is set by the employers, and it has no alternative but to keep up that pace or get out. That is the extent to which labour co-operates with capital in America. This co-operation has been brought about by the weak position of the individual worker, in the absence of labour organization. The demand for skill has been reduced to a minimum, and there is the constant menace of a surplus of unskilled workers, drawn mostly from low-standard countries, to whom the wages paid in America represent great wealth. This situation, like many others in American industry, is bound to be profoundly effected when the results of restricted immigration make themselves felt upon the quality and quantity of the labour supply.

speech.para: In another place he says -

quote.para: I do not believe that America has reached any more intelligent, any more democratic, partnership between labour and capital than

Australia has, despite all our records of industrial disputes. If labour in America must attain at least the recognition that it already receives in Australia before there can be such a partnership, America will be very lucky indeed if its revolution is a peaceful one.

speech.para: Again he said -

quote.para: One conclusion that I formed early,- and in which I remain unshaken, is that I would not like to see the Australian worker in the position of the American worker. If I had to believe that it was necessary for the Australian worker to accept the conditions that exist in America before Australia could become a prosperous industrial nation, I would have very grave doubts of the wisdom of pursuing prosperity.

speech.para: I have heard the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Prowse) say in this House that, if we followed American principles more, indulged in piece-work, and adopted their methods, Australia would be in a much better position than it is at present. I have heard the ex-member for Wakefield, when dealing with this very subject, telling us how necessary it is for us to adopt the methods of America. Mr. Hugh Grant Adam has seen the industries of America, and from what I can gather from his book and other publications, I do not think that it would be desirable for Australia to adopt the American methods of conducting industry. The greatest asset of any country is its human beings, and anything that will tend to make our people happier and to improve their conditions of living should have the support of every honorable member, no matter what his political colour may be. In America elderly persons are seldom seen in factories or workshops. The managers of such institutions, when asked the reason for that, will point to the grave-yards, and say, " They have gone there - men of 40 and 45 years - they are old men." We do not want such conditions to exist in Australia. The representatives of different political parties in this chamber have, at times, perhaps inadvertently, been responsible for utterances which may have had a damaging effect upon the country; but I resent the remarks of honorable members, opposite, who repeatedly say that Australia is a land of strikes. The two most progressive countries industrially are the Commonwealth and New Zealand, in each of which a compulsory arbitration system is in operation and they have fewer strikes than any other country. A conference was held in New Zealand last year consisting of employers, employees, university professors, students of economics and others, which considered five subjects, on four of which the conference reached a unanimous decision. The conference discussed at length the arbitration system of New Zealand, which has been in operation since 1894, but did not come to any definite conclusions. Professor Fisher, a member of the conference, in dealing with the prevention of sweating, and the prevention of strikes, said -

quote.para: This, one of the original objects of the court, has apparently been attained. Sweating is unlikely to be a serious evil in a rapidly developing country, but unless proper control is exercised on principles analogous to those which justify the Factories Act, it is always likely to crop up in isolated sections of industry. The Arbitration Court properly exercise a useful influence in checking any such tendency, but if it were decided to abolish the court it would not be difficult to devise other machinery for the same purpose.

item.para: Prevention of Strikes.- Here the court is alleged to have failed. New Zealand is no longer a country without strikes. It seems, however, unreasonable to condemn the court because it does not succeed in preventing every possible breach of the law. Even the most efficient courts seldom do that, but we do not propose on that account to abolish them. It is very common to exaggerate grossly the losses inflicted by strikes, and it is quite a mistake to suppose that New Zealand is a country peculiarly afflicted by them. In Great Britain, Germany, and the United States of America, strikes' are much more numerous and much more violent than they are here. Statistics of wages lost arc not a satisfactory measure of the damage to the workers concerned, if, as often is the case, the work, which otherwise would have been done during the strike periods, is merely postponed and not entirely lost.

speech.para: What is true of New Zealand is true of Australia. According to a memorandum submitted by the Premier, another conference was to be held, which, I believe, concluded its deliberations a week ago. Mr. Justice Fraser, who for nine years has been president of the New Zealand Arbitration Court, and who is assisted in the work of the court by a representative of the employers and employees, recently reached Melbourne. In an interview with
Mr. JusticeFraser, the Melbourne Herald reports ;

The methods by which industrial peace are preserved in the Dominion were explained today by Mr. Justice Fraser, New Zealand's only arbitration judge, who is visiting Melbourne. " As a system," he said', " arbitration was introduced" in 1894. There have been very few changes in it since. Following a series of complaints about its operation - some urge the abolition of the court- the Government summoned an industrial conference last year to thresh the matter out. There were 25 delegates from each side of industry, and, after a talk they approved of the system." "The court," said Judge Fraser, "consists of one judge, with Supreme Court status and two nominated members, representing the employers and the employees. They hold office, for three years. It has jurisdiction over the whole dominion.

I cannot agree with the view expressed by the honorable member for Brisbane (Mr. Cameron), who said that the Government had made every effort to secure peace in industry, Although the Prime Minister has made belated attempts to bring the parties together, there have been numerous occasions on which he has declined to intervene. When the Federal Parliament was sitting in Melbourne, the then Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Charlton) unsuccessfully appealed to the Prime Minister to assist in solving a difficulty with which the country was confronted. The late Mr. Deakin, when Prime Minister, and also the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes), when holding that office, also acted as mediator between contending parties to an industrial dispute. A gentleman occupying the important position of Prime Minister should use his personal influence in an endeavour to assist in preventing industrial chaos, but this the right honorable gentleman has declined to do.

The honorable member for Brisbane also quoted an article contributed to The Pan Pacific Worker by Senator Rae - probably before he was elected to this Parliament - antagonistic to the principle of arbitration, and suggested that that gentleman was expressing the views of the members of the Labour party. The members of the Labour party are pledged to compulsory arbitration, which is a plank in the party's platform. The honorable member also ' accused honorable members on this side of the chamber of opposing the Financial Agreement Bill. I have stated on numerous occasions that I am in favour of the powers of the Commonwealth being extended, but I was opposed to the per capita payments to the States being withdrawn before the Constitution had been amended. If the statement to which the honorable member for Brisbane has referred had been made by an accredited official of the party he would be justified in quoting it; but it is unreasonable to select an expression of the opinion of one individual and to say that it conveys the views of every member of the party of which that person is a member. In connexion with the attitude of the Attorney-General (Mr. Latham), a representative of the Australasian Council of Trade Unions states -

quote.para: Mr. Lathamis challenged to deny that the Australasian Council of Trade Unions approached him, on behalf of the trade union movement, with a request that he should amend the existing Federal Conciliation Arbitration Act, with a view to the appointment of conciliation committees and commissioners.

speech.para: Provision was made in the amending act of last year for the appointment of these committees and commissioners, but so far only one conciliation commissioner has been appointed throughout Australia. That is the Ministry's contribution to the work of conciliation.

talk.start.para: - The appointment of those conciliation commissioners depends upon the parties.

- Notwithstanding the claims of the Government, only one conciliation commissioner has been appointed. The feeling is fairly general throughout the community that the Government's appointments to the Federal Arbitration Court have been, to put it mildly, unfortunate.
- That simply illustrates the biased mind of the honorable member.

- It does not. I can mention a number of honorable members opposite who hold similar views. [Quorum formed."] I know that the legal fraternity in Selborne Chambers and elsewhere were astounded when this bombshell fell and the Government made its appointments.

speech.para: The Bruce-Page Ministry has never lent its ' aid to the promotion of har mony between the partners in industry. When the Australian seamen's dispute occurred in 1925 representatives of the trade union movement interviewed the Prime Minister with a request that he should intervene. Mr. Bruce referred the delegation to the Commonwealth Shipping Board, in whose hands, he declared, the matter rested so far as it concerned the Commonwealth Line.
