Finally, Mr. Lang, then Premier of New South Wales, arranged an interview with Sir William Clarkson, of the Commonwealth Shipping Board. Sir William acted on his own initiative and the Commonwealth Line, notwithstanding the fact that the Government had refused to intervene, made a satisfactory agreement with the Australian Seamen's Union. Despite the opposition of the Government, representatives of the trade union movement were thus able to bring about peace in industry in that particular case.

I shall not enter into a general discussion upon the waterside workers' dispute of 1927, but I may mention that the Attorney-General, who acted on behalf of the Ministry in the matter, absolutely refused to lend any assistance. When interviewed by Mr. Crofts, the secretary of the Australasian Council df Trade Unions, and urged to bring the parties together, Mr. Latham said " The waterside workers are not going to get away with all that they think they can." If that was the attitude of the Attorney-General in that case, one must conclude that he is another of those who threw a spanner into our industrial machinery. The occasion was an important one, and the possible consequences so serious that the Attorney-General should have mediated in the matter. And when the Australasian Council of Trade Unions was on the eve of settling the waterside workers' dispute in 1928, the Government introduced its reactionary and obnoxious Transport Workers Act, so aggravating the trouble.

During his second-reading speech on this bill the Attorney-General, becoming irritated by interjections, intimated that the. timber workers had been humiliated and defeated. He gloried in their defeat, and demonstrated his undoubted bias. The facts indicate clearly that the timber workers of Victoria were fully justified in fighting for a principle. The terms of the settlement set aside Judge Lukin's award so far as wages and working conditions are concerned. They also set aside the decision of the full arbitration court on the matter of hours. It was agreed by the employers that the industry should be investigated by a fully qualified accountant of at least ten years standing. The terms of that settlement were effected by the present chairman of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Sir Robert Gibson, who presided over the conference and conducted it in such a gentlemanly fashion that results were achieved that are a credit to all concerned. They further provided that the accountant was to inquire into the ability of the industry to work under a 44-hour week. Until the inquiry was completed the employers, were to put into a trust fund wages equivalent to the difference between a 44 and 48-hour week. This sum will go to the workers if the decision is finally in their favour. The timberworkers came out of that trouble very well. The results achieved show conclusively that if any prominent public man, whatever may be his political views, makes an endeavour to bring about a peaceful solution of industrial difficulties, the probability is that his efforts will be successful. But the Prime Minister refused to render assistance.

It is generally known that the Government found the money for the expenses of the Commonwealth Industrial Conference, which is generally known as the Industrial Peace Conference. That conference unanimously carried a resolution intimating to the Bruce-Page Government that the penal sections of our industrial legislation were not conducive to peace and harmony in industry The Government has used those sections to harass and humiliate the workers. Yet John Brown, the coal baron, has been allowed to go scot free. And he is still flouting the laws of the Commonwealth. The Government, taking refuge in its coward's castle, is too weak-kneed to bring John Brown and the other offending coal barons to heel. The Prime Minister intimated that the Government would see that' the law was obeyed. Why has it failed in this instance? We know that the withdrawal of the John Brown prosecution and the abandonment of federal arbitration have caused differences in the Ministry, and very serious differences between two prominent honorable gentlemen opposite. The Attorney-General told the Prime Minister that if the Government withdrew the John Brown prosecution it would have to abandon the field of federal arbitration altogether. Although the Prime Minister intimated that he desired some proposals to be submitted to him, he did not give any indication that he had in his mind the abandonment of federal conciliation and arbitration. His apparent desire was that the existing Arbitration Act should be made more effective. His announcement to the Premiers' Conference in May last, therefore, came as a shock to representatives of both the employers and employees on the Industrial Peace Conference. That conference needed a little more Commonwealth money to complete its labours. That was denied. Now this bill comes as a bolt from the blue. The facts show conclusively that the Government has not behaved in a manner conducive to peace in industry. It is held suspect in regard to industrial matters, and I do not blame any individual or union for being bitterly antagonised by its action.

The withdrawal of the prosecution against John Brown dissipated the trade unionists' last shred of confidence in the sincerity and good intentions of this Government. When I think of such men as the late Mr. Justice Higgins, Mr. Alfred Deakin and Sir Edmund Barton, and compare them with those who are supporting the Government in the action in which it is now proposing to take, it makes me wonder whether there is any one on that side of the House who has remained true to the great principles of federation. Mr. Justice Higgins took a prominent part in the conventions which assisted in drawing up our Commonwealth Constitution, and he was one of the earliest members of the Commonwealth Parliament. The Constitution which he helped to draw up was not perfect ; it was permeated too much by the spirit of State rights, and not enough by that of National rights. Yet, very early in the life of the Federal Parliament, Mr. Justice Higgins, then Mr. Higgins, indicated his readiness to do what he could to obtain for this Parliament a larger measure of control over industrial affairs. Speaking on 28th June, 1901, he said - We feel that these problems, especially the problems of the tariff, are so inextricably intertwined with legislative attempts to regu-. late wages, hours and conditions of labour that we cannot properly fulfil our functions in the one respect without having power to deal with the other. With free trade between the States, it will not work to let one State have one set of laws regulating wages, hours and conditions of labour, and to allow another State to have another set of laws dealing with these subjects within its boundaries.
Sir EdmundBarton, Australia's first Prime Minister, in supporting Mr. Justice Higgins, said -

quote.para: The grant of interstate free trade, which follows the adoption of a uniform tariff, is likely in many respects to be crippled unless the Commonwealth has power to deal uniformly with the conditions of employment throughout Australia. The conditions of employment and the price of articles are inseparably interwoven, and these conditions and prices are also inseparable from the nature' of the tariff, whether it operates externally only, or externally and internally among the States.

speech.para: A memorandum presented to Parliament on December 13th, 1907, by the then Prime Minister, Mr. Alfred Deakin, contained the following statement: -

quote.para: To restrict the powers of the Commonwealth to the mere imposition of duties, while conditions under which the manufacture of protected articles is carried on differ so widely in the different States, would be to permit discrimination and discord. . . . Effective and useful as State industrial laws have in many cases proved, their operation is circumscribed by State boundaries, and it can hardly be claimed for them they they either do, or can secure uniformity in the conditions of manufacture throughout Australia. No authority but the Commonwealth Parliament can do this.

speech.para: In a further memorandum presented on October 28th, 1908, Mr. Deakin said-

quote.para: As the power to protect the manufacturer is national, it follows that unless the Parliament of the Commonwealth also acquires power to secure fair and reasonable conditions of employment to wage-earners, the policy of protection must remain incomplete.

speech.para: I do not think that any honorable member here, whether free-trader or protectionist, will repudiate the sentiments uttered by those three gentlemen. This Parliament imposes tariffs to encourage manufactures and provide employment for workers. Having done so, we should be recreant to our trust if we did not keep to ourselves the power to regulate the conditions of employment of those engaged in such industries. I know something of the hopes which lay nearest Mr. Alfred Deakin's heart, having been associated with him in a number of undertakings. When a minister issues a memorandum it represents the result of careful study, and is intended for the guidance, not only of those of his own time, but of those who come after him. If Parliament passes this bill, it will depart from the great principles, of federation laid down by the eminent jurists and parliamentarians who set us such a splendid example in the past. What will become of the employees in State instrumentalities? Recently Sir William MacPherson, the Premier of Victoria, informed a deputation representing the Government employees, that the most he would do for them was to provide some kind of a board to deal with their working conditions. He was averse, he said, to allowing any arbitration tribunal to lay down wages and conditions for State employees. I contend that employees of State instrumentalities should have the same right as other citizens to enter any court in the land. We all know the treatment meted out to the Victorian railway employees by the Government of which Sir William Irvine was head. I said at that time that a future parliament would reverse what he had. done, and results proved me to be right. I agree with the honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Anstey), that if we, on this side of the House, considered only our own political interests, we could not do better than to allow this bill to be passed, because it would arouse such indignation throughout the country that the defeat of the Government would be inevitable. We cannot, however, refrain from asking Parliament not to pass a measure which would inflict a great injustice upon a large section of the community. The great body of unionists are abiding loyally by the awards of the Arbitration Court, but because a few of them have not done so, the Government proposes to wipe out federal arbitration altogether. It would be just as logical to say that, because a few persons do not respect the civil and criminal laws of the country, those laws should be repealed. I stand firmly for the principle of federal control of industry, for increased powers for the Federal Parliament, and for the widening of our powers to deal with industrial matters. Our arbitration legislation, far from being abolished, should be amended so as to remedy its defects, and increase its usefulness. I oppose this bill, and I hope that either during the second-reading stage or subsequently we shall be able to prevent the passage of a measure which I am certain would he detrimental to the best interests of the community as a whole.

talk.start.para: . - I listened for many hours to the speeches delivered on this important subject, and, unquestionably, some of them were of very high merit. Perhaps the most meandering, as well as the least constructive speech, was that delivered by the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes). I was greatly surprised that a gentleman of his experience did not have some assistance to offer the House with which he professed to be in sympathy. Almost every sentence of his speech revealed his vindictive jealousy of the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce). Mr. Hughes remarked that, at the recent Premiers' Conference, the Prime Minister referred to the high cost of living in Australia; he continued, " The Prime Minister has been in power for six years, and only now has he found that out." That remark took my mind back to a time a few months after the right honorable member for North Sydney had run his course in the public esteem, and was replaced by the present Prime Minister. It may be well to recall that Mr. Hughes was the gentleman who advised the Governor-General, the King's representative in this country, to send for Mr. Bruce. I cannot forget the occasions when, in this chamber, the ex-Prime Minister has revealed the jealous spirit within him. Honorable members who were in the House in 1923 will remember the introduction by the Bruce-Page Government of a bill to amend the Old-age Pensions Act, by which the weekly payment to pensioners was increased from 15s. to 17s. 6d. per week. Certain anomalies in the then existing act were also to be removed, making the weekly pension equivalent to ?1. The then Leader of the Opposition, Mr. Charlton, moved that, instead of 17s. 6d. a week, the pension should be ?1 a week. That amendment was supported by the right honorable member for North Sydney, notwithstanding that it was a motion of want of confidenec in the Government. Had any other honorable member on this side of the House delivered a similar speech and voted as he did, I should not have taken any notice of it, and should probably have forgotten it long before this, but I could not forget that Mr. Hughes had been in- office for six years, during which time he could have made the pension ?2 a week had he so desired. Yet he was prepared to put out of office a government which did not do something which he himself had failed to do when he had the opportunity. A little later certain ordinances relating to land policy in the Northern Territory were under consideration in the House. Again the Leader of the Opposition objected, and urged that that land should be controlled by an act of Parliament. The Opposition made out a very strong case. The ex-Prime Minister, still full of jealousy, agreed with the Opposition, nowithstanding that the ordinances to which he objected were drafted by a member of his own Cabinet, and that, during his regime, similar matters were governed by ordinances, and none by act of Parliament. Remembering those occasions, and the jealousy of the right honorable member for North Sydney, I was not impressed by his speech on this bill. It contained nothing constructive.

speech.para: I heartily support the bill, on the ground that the Prime Minister submitted it to the State Premiers at a recent Premiers' Conference. It is designed to effect economy. The vexed question of the cost of living does arise ; it is, indeed, a potent factor in this connexion. Yet the right honorable member for North Sydney sneered when it was mentioned, and wanted to know what the cost of living had to do with the bill. He inquired whether the bill would insure to the primary producers a greater return for their wheat, their butter, or their cheese. I regret that the right honorable gentleman is not in the chamber to hear my remarks. He must know of the vicious circle, which has resulted in the higher cost of living in Australia. It is not so much a matter of what the primary producers receive for their produce as what they have to pay for everything they buy. The rising costs of production are putting Australia into an insular position. Much of the existing unemployment has its cause there.

I compliment the Government on having asked the British Government to send to this country those four economists who recently visited Australia, and in an impartial manner examined our economic situation. Their report dealt, among other things, with the question now before the House. On page 13 of the report the " Big Four " said -

quote.para: But all measures designed for the increase of Australia's wealth production and power of absorbing new population tend to be defeated if there are strong forces within her which operate so to raise her costs of production that she cannot sell her products in the markets of the world, and is restricted within the limitations of her own home market." Here we approach the most vexed, and the most important of all Australian questions, that of the combined effects of the protective Customs Tariff and of the legislative enactments, both of the Commonwealth and of the States, for the fixing of wages and conditions of labour, which wo will call, for brevity, the arbitration acts.

speech.para: The British Economic Commission regarded that matter as fundamental. Again, on page 20 of its report, the commission stated -

quote.para: Most vexed and most important of all Australian questions is that of the cost of production with its effect upon export industries and of the combined effects of the Tariff and the arbitration acts.

There is ground for the common complaint of a vicious circle of increased prices due to the tariff, and of increased costs of labour due to arbitration awards, and it is urgently necessary to break the vicious circle without lowering the standard of living, i.e., real wages.

speech.para: I remind honorable members opposite that the Labour Premier of Western Australia regards this question in the same light as does the Prime Minister. The honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Fenton) should heed the remarks of Mr. Collier.

talk.start.para: - I am not prepared to follow him in everything, merely because he is a Labour Premier. I regard him as a champion of State rights.

- In the West Australian of 2nd August, under the heading, " Cost of Production, Need for Decrease, Mr. Collier's Views," the following statement is attributed to Mr. Collier, in his speech on the Address-in-Reply in the Legislative Assembly -

quote.para: The position in Australia to-day was serious, Mr. Collier said. The Commonwealth was literally living on its primary industries - wheat and wool. The consternation caused about a month ago when a fall in wheat occurred indicated the results that would follow any serious fall iu the price of those two commodities. With the competition of artificial wool, a further reduction in the price of - the real material threatened next year.

speech.para: The Adelaide wool sales, the other day, showed a drop of between 25 per cent, and 30 per cent., compared with the sales of the previous year. Mr. Collier continued -

quote.para: There was no doubt that any falling-off in the volume of production of wool or wheat, quite apart from any fall in price,' would create a serious situation for the people of Australia. The cost of production in Australia was too high. Australia had to compete in the world's markets. The producer of wool and wheat had no say in fixing the price of the commodity he produced. It was determined by external influences over which he had no control. If Australians were to compete with other countries they would have seriously to consider the question of lowering the cost of production.

speech.para: The right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) would have us believe that the Prime Minister's, object is to reduce wages. That was one of the things he stressed in his speech. Mr. Collier evades the issue; but says we would have seriously to consider the question of lowering the cost of production. How was it to be done? The British Economic Commission got down to fundamentals, as did also the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers) in his speech, on which I compliment him. What does it matter if the money the worker gets is less, so long as its purchasing power is greater? Lowering the cost of production will mean less unemployment, and a better chance to sell our produce in the markets of the world. Our attempt to establish all kinds of industries in Australia, by artificial means irrespective of whether they are economic and necessary to our well-being or not, has placed an intolerable load upon our primary industries. "We speak that we do know." The report of Mr. Collier's speech continued as follows : -

quote.para: When the fall in wheat prices took place, many people believed that it would be unwise for the growers to cultivate or crop as much land this year, and, in some quarters, it was suggested that there should be a decrease. But that would be a very retrograde step. The State would never surmount its difficulties by decreasing the area under wheat merely because the price fell, but it should endeavour to enable the farmer to compete in the overseas markets by reducing the cost of production. An increase in the area under crop and a reduction in the cost of production would make the position to-day, with a lower price, what it was. two years ago, with a higher price.
Sir JamesMitchell. ; Wheat will not fetch a lower price this year.
Mr. Collier.; No. But it was threatened. It was difficult to see what was the cause of the high cost of production.

debate.para: Mr. Collier.; That was a contributory cause. The high tariff was the chief cause. The tariff piled up year by year, and the primary producer, unlike' the manufacturer, was unable to pass it on.

Honorable members opposite are doing everything in their power to increase the tariff, and this is making conditions extremely difficult. I congratulate the Government upon the open-minded attitude it has taken upon this subject. It is at least trying to educate the people of Australia along economic lines. The report from which I have already quoted continues -

quote.para: He hoped that the Federal Parliament would not continue to pile burdens on to the primary producers through the customs.

Another contributory factor to the high cost of production was that many people engaged in manufacturing had not kept abreast of the world's progress with regard to up-to-date machinery. In the old world all pre-war methods of production had been scrapped in favour of more economical methods. This waB a question that Australia would have seriously to consider. He agreed with the contention of the Leader of the Opposition that high taxation diminished the amount of employment, decreased production, and affected the whole community.
So far as Western Australia was concerned, however, the prospects were very bright, and indicated that the State would enjoy one of the best seasons it had experienced for many years.

debate.para: It is apparent, therefore, that the Labour Premier of Western Australia recognizes that a serious situation confronts Australia. He must thoroughly agree with the Prime Minister that some action is necessary to overcome our difficulties. In addressing the recent Premiers' Conference on this subject the Prime Minister said -

quote.para: A critical examination of our present position leads inevitably to the conclusion that the basic cause of all economic troubles of Australia to-day is the high cost of production, and that a reduction of our costs of production is the first step that we must take to bring about a solution of our problems. A nation-wide reduction in our costs of production would effect such a transformation in our industrial and financial position as would enable us not only to absorb our unemployed in useful occupations, but also to pave the way for a progressive increase in our population.

debate.para: Having laid further emphasis on this aspect of the subject the Prime Minister referred to the overlapping of Commonwealth and State arbitration awards. He said that this would have to be prevented if we were to advance to a better economic position. He proceeded as follows: -

quote.para: However, I now invite the Premiers to state definitely whether they are prepared to recommend to their Parliaments the reference of full industrial powers to the Commonwealth. In the- absence of such concerted action on the part of the States the Commonwealth Government feels that it will be its' duty - because of its deep conviction that the present dual system of industrial regulation is retarding our national progress and preventing industrial peace - to propose to the Commonwealth Parliament the repeal of the existing Federal Arbitration legislation subject to transitional provisions, which will preserve existing awards and agreements . for a period, sufficient to enable the States to assume complete control.

debate.para: The Premiers' Conference quite definitely refused to agree to the surrender of additional industrial powers to the Commonwealth, and I do not blame it for doing so. The States ought to have complete authority over their own industrial affairs. A good deal has been said during this debate about the necessity for uniformity in industrial matters ; but it must be remembered that the standard of living in the less developed States is necessarily not so high as the standard in the well developed States. Each State must work out its own salvation. A court operating within a State is far more likely to give satisfactory awards than a court operating in some far distant place. The honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin) made out a case for the bill when he said that' there was a great difference between such towns as Northam, in Western Australia, and Longreach in Queensland. For this very reason local courts should have authority to prescribe local conditions. To provide for this is not to abolish arbitration. It is simply to make it more effective.

talk.start.para: - I do not think that there will be any industrial arbitration in Victoria.

- When I spoke to my constituents during the last election campaign, I put before them in unmistakable terms the great disadvantages to industry of overlapping awards. I said that it was costly and unnecessary to have two industrial machines running side by side. The population of Australia is not large enough to bear the burden of so much legal machinery. If we had one industrial authority in each State we should secure a more satisfactory result and inr dustry would be able to develop along peaceful lines. It seems absurd to me that honorable members opposite should desire to duplicate our industrial machinery. I believe that the rank and file of trade unionists would be content to have State courts to fix their conditions. The Bulletin of the 28th August puts the position in a nutshell in the following words : -

quote.para: The Federal Parliamentary Labour party has met and resolved that the timber strikers are acting nobly in their insurrection against the federal award. At the same time it demands that the Federal Arbitration Court shall continue to exist and hand out awards, to be treated the same way, or worse. The Commonwealth can't make its court's decisions respected unless it has power to interfere in disturbances, wherever they may arise, and has police and military forces with which to scatter insurrectionary mobs. There being no visible chance of getting the power, the obvious course is for the Commonwealth to get out of the arbitration business.

speech.para: That is a fair statement of the case.

I am not a unificationist. I do not believe that that policy would be successful in our great country, with its unwieldy and undeveloped States. Australia is much overgoverned and overtaxed. Wo can reduce the cost of government to some extent at least by voting for this bill. When the hue and cry of the Opposition has died clown a little it will be found that the thinking trade unionists will express satisfaction with the action of the Government in abolishing the Commonwealth court. It was made quite clear during the election campaign that the Commonwealth was not able to enforce the decisions of. the Arbitration Court. It, therefore, seems to me to be unreasonable to retain this ineffective instrument .of industrial control. I know that the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Fenton) would like all power to be reposed in the National Parliament; but the people are not favorable to an alteration of the Constitution in that respect. The States are at present administering our police, education and health laws and there is no reason why we should interfere with their operations. I heartily support the bill, for I think that it is a step in the direction of better government.

talk.start.para: .If the bill is passed, I fear that it will do irreparable harm to the industries of Australia, and to the workers engaged in them. It is the most retrograde proposal that has been made since the inauguration of federation. One would have expected the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister to advance substantial arguments in support of it, but their speeches were lamentably weak, and lacked conviction. The Prime Minister referred to the economic effect of the drastic change that is proposed, and the Attorney-General spoke of the estimated savings; but he did not take into consideration the enormous loss that would be incurred owing to the chaos that would result. It will still be necessary to have six industrial tribunals throughout the Commonwealth, and I believe that the new system, if adopted, will eventually prove more costly than the present dual control. The Prime Minister merely made an economic survey of the present industrial situation, which is largely due to the extravagance of this composite government in the last six or seven years. On several occasions the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have said that the scrapping of Commonwealth arbitration would be unthinkable. Speaking in this House on the Industry and Commerce Bill, on the 20th May, 1926, the Prime Minister said -

quote.para: Not for a moment do I accept the view that, because we have had difficulties, we should scrap the whole machinery of arbitration and conciliation and revert to the old system for composing our differences. Li the widest. sphere, that of international affairs, efforts are being directed towards the ideal of having disputes arbitrated upon by an arbitration tribunal. If that can be attempted, even in the international sphere, it is obvious that it can be achieved in the much smaller sphere embraced by the industrial affairs of one nation. If the Commonwealth Government scrapped the Arbitration Court, our. troubles industrially would merely be accentuated.

speech.para: I agree with that view, and consider that the reasons advanced by the right honorable gentleman hold good to-day. The Attorney-General, in the debate on the same bill, on the 21st May, 1926, after referring to the work of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, remarked -

quote.para: It is out of all question to consider seriously the suggestion that this industrial machinery should be scrapped, and all the court's awards, the result of 20 years' work, set aside, interstate disputes being left for the future to the adjudication of sonic at present non-existent body. It must bc remembered that no single State is able to deal effectively with an interstate dispute merely by the service of a printed claim. If we wish to secure industrial peace through the medium of the law, there must be some means of dealing with these disputes on a federal basis. Therefore, the Government is of opinion that it is necessary to continue the Commonwealth Arbitration Court and to make certain improvements to it.

speech.para: Those utterances cannot be lightly dismissed by honorable members. The Government annually expends large sums of public money on various delegations, such as those sent to the- International Labour Conference at Geneva. By despatching delegations to such conferences the Government concerns itself with matters relating to international labour problems and conditions of employment. Yet it fails to exercise its industrial powers for the protection of Australian labour conditions. Judging by their utterances, one would expect the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister to be the last to suggest the evacuation of the field of arbitration by the Commonwealth.

In the last 25 years, Australian industries have forged ahead by leaps and bounds. The number of factories " has increased from 11,945 in 1905, to 22,775 in 1927, and the number of employees from 214,589 to 464,196 during the same period. A huge industrial fabric has been built up since the inception of federal arbitration, and the industries established either on a State, or an interstate basis, would be seriously affected if this machinery were swept away. In my opinion, the proposed change would result in fierce interstate competition. That is not desirable. In those industries where a business has been established in one State, and is economically supplying the requirements of the whole of Australia, there will be a temptation on the part of others to establish branches of those industries in adjoining States, largely on account of inferior conditions of employment- that may be brought about as the result of the change. This will stir up interstate jealousy, which, happily, has now diminished to a negligible quantity, owing to the disappearance of interstate customs barriers ana the uniformity of working conditions that prevails in many federal industries. If the bill is passed, there will be an entire lack of uniformity; the conditions will be ever changing owing to the varying industrial laws of the States, and the varying duration of those awards. The Prime Minister referred to the fact that the Australian Workers Union does not avail itself of the awards of the Federal Arbitration Court in Queensland. He mentioned this matter with a view to suggesting that too much importance should not be attached to the desire for uniformity. But there is no comparison between the work of members of the Australian Workers Union and employees in manufacturing industries. The product of the shearers, that is, the greasy wool, is not subjected to interstate competition, most of it being exported overseas, only 5 per cent, to 6 per cent, of it being manufactured in Australia. On the other hand, however, the output of our factories is for local consumption and subject to interstate competition.

From time to time, the Government has said a good deal as to the necessity for law and order, but, when one examines its proposals in regard to arbitration, one is inclined to the view that, after an election, that cry ceases. It is proposed to retain the industrial machinery in order to control the maritime industries; but that change would enable the Government to deal with merely the remnant of an industry. This Government sacrificed the Commonwealth Shipping Line, and that had the effect of robbing the 1,200 employees of the benefit of Australian conditions of labour. The Government intends to repeal the coastal provisions of the Navigation Act, and so to administer a severe blow to the maritime industries. Once the Commonwealth evacuates the field of arbitration, this country will be confronted with the same difficulties as those experienced in the early days of federation prior to the passing of the Act of 1904-5. Mr. Justice Heydon, during the hearing of the clothing trades case in the New South Wales Arbitration Court said : -

quote.para: The evidence that has been submitted to me in this case proves beyond any doubt that there is room for improvement in the wages and conditions of the employees in this industry, but one is forced to take into consideration the wages and conditions obtaining in the same industry in the State of Victoria. In consequence, I hesitate to concede to the employees all that I might in other circumstances. In an industry such as this there should be some form of federal adjustment of the wages and conditions.

speech.para: If those difficulties existed in 1905 they are bound to be accentuated by the tremendous development in the manufacturing industries, particularly the boot trade if the Government's proposals are carried. Mr. Justice Heydon, dealing with the case of the boot trade employees said -

quote.para: We are of the opinion that journeymen in the boot trade are skilled workers, and should receive the wage of skilled workers, and that ?2 8s. is not the wage to which they are fairly entitled. ... If our hands had been free, we should have given most of the boot trade journeymen 9s. a day, or ?2 14s. a week, with a little less to the assistant stuff cutters and the lining cutters. We have wished to see our way to do this, but we have come to the conclusion that, in common fairness to the employers (that is the New South Wales employers), we cannot do it.

speech.para: The workers will be confronted with those conditions immediately they are obliged to seek awards from State tribunals. In both the clothing and boot trades there are unscrupulous employers. In the former particularly, sweating may return and the conditions now enjoyed by the workers will be broken down.

The Government's proposal is extraordinary, and one is forced to seek the motive for it, in the same way as we sought the motive for the withdrawal of the prosecution of John Brown. Honorable members on the Government side have been at considerable pains to defame the fair name of Australia by exaggerating the number and extent of industrial disturbances. But the Attorney-General, speaking on the Arbitration Bill on the 21st May, 1926, said-

quote.para: We have strikes, and some of them are serious - more particularly transport strikes, the effects of which are far-reaching, because they extend considerably beyond the persons immediately involved in the dispute. But other countries have their strikes and lockouts, too, and it is unfair to represent Australia as being particularly and specially afflicted by strikes.

speech.para: I am in accord with that statement. Those who exaggerate these troubles in order to justify their support of the bill are not good Australians. Many strikes have been more or less justified. The Attorney-General stated that the average time for which unions desiring to approach the court had to wait, had been eight months. Delays of that sort are sufficient to cause dissatisfaction and restiveness on the part of the workers. Although they have to wait the greater part of a year to have their plaints heard by the court, the employers, the rackrenters, and the sellers of the daily necessaries of life, are able to get an increased price for their commodity without any delay and without recourse to any authority such as the workers have to submit to. Those increases have to be paid by the workers, and men who are receiving the bare means of subsistence are aggravated and goaded into revolt when they have to wait a considerable time for redress from the Arbitration Court. These delays could have been minimised if the Government had seriously addressed itself to the removal of many anomalies that hinder the functioning of the court. When this measure is stripped of all pretence and veneer, one is forced to the conclusion that it is part of a well thought out plan, which has been developing since the end of the war, to break down the conditions of the workers. The Employers Federation and the Single Purpose League have openly expressed their determination to do everything within their power to destroy the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. In that endeavour they have been supported by the wealthy interests, and the Government has consistently aided them by appointing various investigatory bodies whose opinions would be likely to coincide with those of the opponents of federal arbitration. The British Economic Mission was a body of independent British business men who, on the initiative of the Prime Minister at the Imperial Conference in 1926, were nominated by the British Government to report upon economic and industrial conditions in Australia. Dealing with the tariff and the Arbitration Court, the "Big Four" said-

quote.para: Wo have been strongly disposed to the view that the combined operation of the tariff and of the arbitration acts has raised costs to a level which has laid an excessive and possibly even a dangerous load upon the unsheltered primary industries..... We have felt much force in the oft-repeated complaint that successive increases in the tariff which affect prices and the cost of living, following upon, or being followed by, successive advances in the cost oflabour as the result of decisions under the arbitration acts have involved Australia in a vicious circle of ever ascending costs and prices, and that this condition of affairs is crippling Australia's progress and her power of supporting increased population. There lies no task before the Australian people more urgent than that of in some way breaking the vicious circle and of bringing down costs of production, as is being done in the other industrial countries of the world. . . .

speech.para: Those gentlemen gave a lead to the Prime Minister, who is disposed to take more notice of the opinion of imported experts than of the judgment of captains of industry within the Commonwealth. The report of the mission referred to the Tariff Board's annual report for the year 1925-26 : -

quote.para: Our views have merely been strengthened by our study of the reports of . the Commonwealth Tariff Board, who, we observe, in their report for the year 1925-26, say that they are - strongly of the opinion that the industrial unions of the Commonwealth should be induced to realize the critical position into which the Commonwealth is drifting and the absolute necessity for preventing the wages gap from becoming still wider between the United Kingdom, the Continent of Europe and the Commonwealth.

speech.para: It is obvious that the minds of the Government appointees on the Tariff Board and the members of the Economic Mission were running on parallel lines. The report of the mission continued -

quote.para: A change in the method prevalent in Australia of dealing with industrial disputes appears to us to bo essential, and we hold that there should be a minimum of judicial and governmental interference in them except in so far as matters affecting the health and safety of persons engaged in industry may be concerned.

speech.para: Honorable members will see that these gentlemen gave a direct lead to the Prime Minister to propose the legislative changes that are contained in the bill. They urged a reduction in the cost of production, and I interpret that to mean a drastic cut in wages. It has been said ' during the debate that had the industrial proposals of 1926 been carried the Government would not be proceeding with this measure.

The honorable member for Warringah (Mr. Parkhill) and other ministerialists have charged the Labour party with having been responsible for the defeat of the industrial powers referendum in 1926. When that honorable member and the Prime Minister were speaking, I reminded them that the opposition to the referendum proposals came not only from certain sections of the Labour movement, but also from the wealthy interests, particularly those represented by Sir Arthur Robinson and Sir Owen Cox. Had the people conceded to this Parliament power to regulate and control corporations, it would have been possible to pass a general company law to control private companies which represent over 70 per cent, of the capital invested in Australia. During the referendum campaign, the Federal Union - that being the name of the organization, formed by the wealthy interests to oppose the Government's proposals - stated that, in an effort to get at the possibilities behind the referendum proposals, it had obtained an opinion from a very prominent Melbourne barrister, now on the Supreme Court bench. The questions asked were as to the powers of Parliament over ordinary trading companies should the trade and industry amendment be carried. Among the questions and replies were the following: -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Could the Federal Parliament legislate in regard to the ordinary daily activities of all companies and corporations other than those specially excluded ? - Yes.

item.label: (b)
item.para: As to their methods of buying and selling? - Yes.

item.label: (c)
item.para: As to the percentage of rate of divi dend? - Yes.

item.label: (d)
item.para: As to capitalization of profits, provision of reserve funds, &c. ? - Yes.

item.label: (f)
item.para: If Parliament were dissatisfied with the decision of an authority, could it extinguish such authority and create another? - Yes, by repealing the statute creating it.

speech.para: As a fairly reliable estimate places the companies as distinct from private individuals in possession of 70 per cent, of the business of Australia, it will be seen bow drastic are the powers asked for.

It will be seen that Sir Arthur Robinson and the wealthy group which he represents were " wise " to the far-reaching importance of those proposals. They were defeated, not as a result of the opposition of industrial labour, but entirely as a result of the united opposition of the capitalistic press and the wealthy and influential supporters of the National party. The Government dares not again submit the proposals to the people. Those interests which make it a practice to contribute to the funds of the National party no doubt subscribed on the occasion of the last election on the understanding that similar proposals would not again be introduced, and that the Government, therefore, would not appeal to the electors to grant to the Commonwealth further powers to deal with industrial matters.

For some months the royal commission which was appointed to inquire into amendments of the Constitution has been engaged on that work, and its report will probably be presented to the Governor-General to-day. A proposal such as this ought not to have been brought forward until that report was in the hands of the Government, and this Parliament and the people of Australia had had an opportunity to consider the recommendations that it contains. The Government, however, has shown itself unwilling to adopt that course. It has displayed an indecent haste in connexion with this measure which is not warranted merely by the rejection of the proposals that were placed before the people in 1926. Under the Constitution certain industrial powers were granted to the Commonwealth Parliament. They have been in operation for 25 years, and should not be taken away or allowed to remain latent without the approval of the electors. The Government should take the earliest opportunity to refer this important matter to the people and allow them to make a pronouncement upon it. It would appear that the work of our nationbuilders in the early days of federation is to be undone by a number of pygmies, who are either members or supporters of the Government. It is regrettable to find honorable members opposite willing to facilitate this scheme. The Government has expressed a desire to bring about industrial peace. ' How can that object be achieved when they propose to so alter the industrial laws that industrial warfare is inevitable ? For six years they have mishandled industrial matters and manhandled labour leaders. They have made themselves the laughing-stock of the country.

The honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Prowse) has expressed his determination to support this measure on the ground that the Prime Minister submitted the matter to the State Premiers at the conference which was held in May last. I contend that the proposals did not receive the mature and lengthy consideration that was warranted. The conference dispersed three days after it met. When the Prime Minister announced his proposals the Premiers unanimously said they were opposed to the handing over of further powers to the Commonwealth, but would warmly welcome the evacuation of the industrial field by the Commonwealth. The Premier of. Victoria was most anxious to see the Commonwealth retire from this field; yet he is now asking this Government to defer action so that he may consider what industrial machinery is necessary to take its place. If this measure is passed the workers of Australia will' be thrown to the wolves. No undertaking has been given by the various State Governments that the interests of the workers will be fully protected. The Sydney Baily Guardian yesterday referred to the long delays that have been experienced by the Teachers Federation in New South Wales, in having their claim' adjudicated upon. It is headed, " A Long Job," and reads -

quote.para: When the Premier makes his second-reading speech on the bill substituting conciliation committees for industrial courts, he had better skim lightly over the. record of the recent Teachers Conciliation Committee, under the chairmanship of. blind barrister Mcwilliam.
The teachers lodged their claim in June, 1926. Fruitless conferences with the Public Service Board Occupied many months, and about the middle of 1927 the claim went to the conciliation committee.

After over two years' continuous wrangling between representatives of the teachers and the department - the latter backed up by the Public Service Board - the conciliation committee has issued an award for male teachers, and reports its inability to arrive at any compromise on the subject of women teachers' salaries!

speech.para: There are 9,000 State public servants involved. From what I have read, it will be seen how difficult it is to induce the State Parliaments, with their reactionary upper houses, to provide machinery for the efficient and speedy handling of industrial matters. We should hesitate to give the State Parliaments this power, because there is the grave danger of different workers being excluded from the schedule to industrial acts. In the days when there was a wages board system in New South Wales; the clerical workers were excluded from the act, and men who were engaged in clerical occupations could not obtain redress from either the State Arbitration Court or the wages board. During the last few months the Premier of Queensland, Mr. Moore, and the Premier of New South Wales, Mr. Bavin, have stated that either the rural worker's award will be repealed or the rural workers will be excluded from the operations of the State award. That is a very unsatisfactory position. How does the Government propose to protect the workers 'excluded from the benefits of the State Industrial Acts?

I believe in an extension of the powers of the Commonwealth, and I sincerely trust that this proposal of the Government will be defeated. I confidently believe that at the first available opportunity the electors will dismiss from office this blundering and incompetent Government. I greatly resent the methods that have been adopted by the Government to break down the opposition to the bill by compelling honorable members to remain here continuously for so long a period. I hope that honorable members opposite will display their independence and instead of being influenced by party considerations will do what is iu the best interests of the country. I trust that the motion for the second reading of the bill will be negatived and that thus the interests of the Australian workers will be protected.

talk.start.para: . - I again protest emphatically against the manner in which the business of this House is being conducted. If a snap-shot could be taken of this Parliament at the present time and presented to the people it certainly would not have its powers extended. To compel honorable members to remain here continuously for 48 hours is a cruel act, the responsibility for which lies at the door of one who would appear to be drunk with power. There is no necessity for it. The House could have adjourned at 11 o'clock last night, and could have completed its business to-day in time to allow honorable members to catch their trains. i have not been able to discern any stonewalling during this debate. I sincerely hope that there will be an amendment of the Standing Orders, and that the time allowed honorable members for second-reading and other speeches will be considerably curtailed.

speech.para: I regard this as one of the most important measures that have been before this Parliament, mainly because it affects the greater portion of our industrial life. For that reason it deserves our grave and earnest consideration. We want industrial peace. If there is one State in Australia that has been gruelled and crucified by strikes, it is Tasmania. I listened attentively to the speech of the honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James), and was considerably moved by his description of the sufferings of the miners who are locked out. My State is locked out for about four out of every six years. Once the cooks, the stewards, the firemen, the engineers or the waterside workers go on strike Tasmania is cut off from the mainland.

talk.start.para: - Will the passage of this bill prevent that?

- if this bill, when passed, is put into operation immediately, I am afraid that a strike will occur and again isolate Tasmania from the mainland. The honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin), in his able speech, pointed out the disabilities under which Western Australia was suffering. He said that its only connexion with the eastern States consisted of railway and water carriage. Tasmania has no railway to connect it with the mainland, but is dependent entirely upon water carriage. The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. West) was also afraid that the repeal of the coastal provisions of the Navigation Act would tend to destroy the mercantile marine of Australia. I contend that that act is a millstone round the neck of Tasmania and is doing more to injure that State- than anything else. The Navigation Act has built up the biggest monopoly in Australia, because the greater portion of its mercantile marine is owned and controlled by the Inchcape combine. Tasmania is suffering severely from lack of transport facilities to the mainland, and her semiisolated position has been brought about largely by the operation of the coastal provisions of the Navigation Act.
- The honorable member heard the late Mr. Kingston say that the United States of America protected its mercantile marine right round its coast.

- The operation of the Sherman Act absolutely killed the mercantile marine of the United States of America. During the war 75 per cent, of the American troops had to be carried overseas in British vessels. We have now practically driven the Australian mercantile marine off our coast.

speech.para: Tasmania has had a bad spin lately. We have had a poor crop of fruit.- The berry fruit that has been grown is so small that it is practically unsaleable. The potato crop is rather poor and on top of that we have had the most devastating flood that has ever occurred in Australia. Tasmania is staggering under this load, and I believe that if a maritime strike occurs during the coming tourist season it will be a knock-out blow to that State. The introduction of this bill is exceedingly important at this time. It is a drastic and far-reaching action. If this legislation is passed and proclaimed immediately it will cause, I fear, serious industrial trouble. In any case this measure should not be put into operation until it has met with the approval of the people. A certain period should be given to allow State courts to be established, and some of them must necessarily have a semi-federal control. They must be vested with certain federal jurisdiction. I cannot see any objection to the bill being suspended until it has received the approval of the electors. I am taking this stand solely in the in terests of Tasmania. I may be called parochial or provincial, but I believe that Tasmania will prosper if industrial peace is ensured for some time to come.

I blame the Government for the present industrial position. If John Brown and Hollowayhad been imprisoned for defying the federal law, the coal-miners lockout and the timber workers' strike would have ended in less than a week. A few months ago I helped the Attorney-General to caulk the leaks in the Arbitration Act so that the law might be administered fairly in respect of all sections of the community affected by it. Now we are suddenly asked to wipe out the Arbitration Act, and to throw the onus of arbitration on the States. I have no objection to that. I have never favored extension of federal powers at the expense of the States. I am a federalist, but not a unificationist. . The only way that we can secure a strong national federation in Australia is by retaining the sovereign States each complete in itself, each operating within its own circuit, without transgressing or intruding upon the rights or functions of the other. I join . issue immediately with those who say that Australia can be governed better from Canberra than from the different capital cities. At one time Australia was governed from Sydney, and State after State was formed, because of the people's desire for independence. It would be a retrograde step to have one central authority with power to govern the whole of Australia. Tasmania is in a serious position. I frankly admit that I view with great apprehension the possibility of this measure suddenly becoming operative. I attended the conference of Commonwealth and State Ministers held in Canberra in May. I heard the Prime Minister's proposal concerning the Commonwealth Government's suggested arbitration policy, and also the reply of the State Premiers. The gentleman most emphatic in his refusal to accede to the request of the Prime Minister was the Premier of Victoria (Sir William McPherson), who even before this measure has passed its second reading stage is asking that even if it is passed it shall not become operative until the 30th December, 1930.

talk.start.para: - Did the honorable member see the Prime Minister's reply to that statement?

- No, but I understand that it was to the effect that the date on which the measure should become operative would -rest with the States. Under our arbitration system we have been building up for- nearly a quarter of a century two big armed camps - organized labour on one side and the employers on the other. When we consider the Government's action in this connexion I am reminded of an able article written by a German military officer who had toured India, and who, after describing the racial hatred which existed in that country, said that Great Britain had acted as umpire so long between the conflicting interests there that if her influence were suddenly removed, Moslems and Hindoos would, be at each others throats within a week. Although two great armed camps have been built up in Australia during the period I have mentioned, we are now asked without the slightest warning to sweep away the authority which has controlled them. It is not safe -to follow the course proposed by . the right honorable gentleman. It is exceedingly dangerous to the State which I represent. The section of industrialists who are to remain under federal jurisdiction is responsible for 95 per cent, of the strikes which have led to Tasmania's isolation. If any of the maritime organizations object to this measure coming into force they will take immediate action. If only 16 marine cooks - such as those who refused to work some months ago - decide to disregard the award of the Maritime Industries Court, Tasmania will again be isolated from the mainland. As a representative of Tasmania I cannot incur that risk.

speech.para: While I intend to support the second reading of. the bill to enable it to reach the committee stage, I shall assist those who are endeavouring to postpone its proclamation until it has been fully considered and by doing so to avert the danger of an industrial upheaval. This is not a party question, but it is one in which the political, industrial, and even the social interests are vitally involved. We should be guided by the biblical injunction, " Come let us reason together."

talk.start.para: - That is what should have been done.
- I think it is a great pity that efforts were not made in that direction before this drastic piece of legislation was brought before Parliament.
- The object of the bill is to create a better feeling.

- It may be. I have never imputed improper motives to my political opponents, to my friends, or to neutrals. The object of the bill may be as the honorable member suggests, but the circumstances in which it has been introduced do not support that view. I know nothing that would tend more to ensure a period of industrial peace than the withholding of the proclamation of this measure until it has been referred to the electors for their decision. Such a course would give Tasmania practically two and a half years of exemption from industrial disputes, and I would willingly do almost anything politically to give Tasmania such an exemption. Whatever the system of arbitration be, it should be clearly defined. Any party which accepts arbitration should obey its awards. If arbitration has been killed, it has been by the deadly knife thrusts of Mr. Holloway and Mr. Duggan, who are prominently associated with the trade union movement in Victoria. I know not what their motives were; but when an award of the court was given it should be accepted by both parties. The men I have mentioned are largely responsible for the Government's drastic change in policy.
- They, and those who who have acted similarly are largely responsible for the measure.

- When a decision was given in connexion with the waterside workers' case I said then, as I do now, that the provision in the award for a second " pick-up " was unnecessary ; that it was injurious to the morale of the men and of practically no benefit to the ship-owners. In that case the men should have accepted the award of the court, and immediately appealed against it. I have been given out "leg before wicket" when I knew I had "played the ball." In arbitration the advice of an Irish cricketer to his son is particularly appropriate. He said, "When the umpire says you are out, my boy, remember you are out even if you are not out." Unless each party is prepared to accept the awards of the court our arbitration system becomes a farce and a sham. I believe that practically every member of the political Labour party in Australia is in favour of observing awards of the court.
- There are many who are not.

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - I am merely expressing my own opinion.
- Does the honorable member include Mr. Holloway and Mr. Duggan ?

- They are industrial not political leaders. Reference has been made to the enormous advantage of a common rule under which the rates of pay in a particular industry would be similar in all States. That is all right in theory, but is unfortunate in practice. The system of semi-mass production in Sydney and Melbourne has been the means of practically smashing Tasmanian industries. The best customers of the big Melbourne manufacturers are the Tasmanians, and particularly those in that portion of the State represented by the honorable member for Darwin (Mr. Bell). We have been told that it would be of great advantage if men, say in the boot trade, in all parts of Australia were paid the same wage. But there is a reverse side to the picture. The larger States, such as New South Wales and Victoria, with the aid of a high protective tariff, have built up large and important industries on a mass production basis, and their methods have made it practically impossible for smaller manufactories in other States to compete with them.
- Does the honorable member suggest that the workers of the smaller States should accept lower wages ?

- The workers from the smaller States are drifting more and more into the already overcrowded cities of Melbourne and Sydney. That is not a good thing for the smaller States, and it is a serious disadvantage to Australia generally. I was asked my opinion on a statement made some months ago by the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Gullett). I expressed the opinion then that mergers had been responsible for the greatest and cruellest combines that exist to-day in the United States of America. One of the worst things that could happen to Australia, and to its industry, is the creation of these so-called mergers, which are simply combines. Assisted by the protective walls of a high tariff, they are able to kill competition and to have the public and the worker alike at their mercy. I am distinctly opposed to the popular idea that it is necessary to merge big industries into combines in order to obtain mass production. There is nothing more adverse to the interests of the consumer, and of the workers, than the banding together of these great organisations, which relentlessly exercise their powers.
- Regulation by the central authority will prevent that.

- Never during the last 25 years has there existed a British authority which has been successful in preventing monopolies from taking complete advantage of their position. I do not know a monopoly that can be trusted. The State of Tasmania has experienced a very fair sample of the operations of one. A shipping monopoly has secured complete control of the trade between Tasmania and the mainland. It has increased freights and fares at its own sweet will, and it refuses, to give Tasmania an adequate service unless the authorities submit themselves to blackmail. It is well that somebody should ventilate these matters. The federal authority has the impression that it is establishing an Australian mercantile marine. Actually it is building up a monopoly which has a strangle-hold on an isolated State entirely dependent on seacarriage for its transport. I believe that I have made my position plain. Inconsistent, some may say: I do not mind. Parochial if you like. I do not mind. I am viewing matters to some extent from the position of Australia, but largely and wholly from that of my own State.

speech.para: I repeat, a strike at the present time would sap the very life blood of the State of Tasmania. I am afraid that if this measure is put into operation suddenly and it precipitates a strike, Tasmania will be in a perilous position. Honorable members who are not residents of an island State can have no conception of what industrial unrest means.

talk.start.para: - Let the honorable member vote against the bill.

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - No; I have a better method. My vote against the second reading would be futile. I believe that it is better in the interests of all concerned that a fair and reasonable- time should elapse in order that the matter may be considered. There is no need to rush it into operation. Its effect may be embarrassing, and even injurious, to the mainland States; one blunder will again cut off my State. Do honorable members know what it means to be cut off from the mainland ? The honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) made a passionate plea on behalf of his miners, and I am greatly in sympathy with him. He has pleaded eloquently on behalf of men who have been two or three months out of work. But I have seen men who have worked for twelve months, gather their harvest, and then have to cast it into the sea because the State of Tasmania has been deprived of its sea transport. No sugar has been available in Tasmania, although, on the Sydney wharf, thousands of tons awaited transport. Surely there is not an employer, an employee or a member of Parliament, either State or Federal, who is not prepared to do something to prevent that, happening again. I believe that the best way to secure industrial peace, pending the time when the measure can be put into complete operation, is to suspend its activities until it has received exhaustive consideration. It is worth trying. Honorable members talk of the cost of a referendum being ?100,000. How many hundreds of thousands of pounds does one strike cost the community of Australia?
- Is the honorable member urging that the measure should be submitted to a referendum ?

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - I am in favour of the bill being held in abeyance until the electors have decided its fate by referendum, which would be infinitely preferable or at a general election. In the meantime the State courts could operate. And here I caution the Government that the whole thing will not be as simple as it appears.
- Does the honorable member suggest that the State courts should be built up before the referendum is taken?

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - I reply deliberately, yes. The questions placed before the electors at the referendum should be simply whether they favour, on the one hand, a purified Federal Arbitration Act, or, on the other, the State courts. I notice that the Premier of Queensland (Mr. A. E. Moore) has initiated an intensely practical idea: that all the State Premiers should meet and formulate a common rule to govern the courts which are to be established by the States. Let us have those amalgamated State courts, and let us submit the proposal to the people. I am prepared to abide by the result. I did in the matter of the State debts. I told the electors that the agreement was a mistake, but submitted myself to their decision, which I accepted. This law is to be operated too suddenly, and the battle axe has been used unnecessarily.
- How is the referendum going to prevent strikes ?

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - The referendum will decide which system we are to 'adopt. Whatever system is adopted must be adhered to. I have said that if the Government had put Mr. John Brown and Mr. Holloway in gaol the strikes and lockouts would have been over in a week. It is impossible to run an arbitration act according to "Raf- ferty rules." We cannot have arbitration and conciliation unless it is understood that both sides will honour the arrangements entered into.
- If John Brown had been convicted, he would only have been fined; he would not have gone to gaol.

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - If that is so, the sooner we alter the law so that we may send to gaol wealthy men like John Brown who flagrantly defy the law the better it will be for the country. I shall support any amendment in committee which will have the effect of postponing action under this bill until the matter has been fully considered, and which will prevent what, to my mind, constitutes the greatest danger - namely, a widespread industrial upheaval. We are now within a few months of the time when, by some devilish device, the usual strike will occur to disrupt Tasmania's tourist traffic, and. to interfere with the marketing of her fruit crop. I am not prepared to risk an industrial upheaval merely for the sake of rushing this bill through Parliament, before full time has been allowed for its consideration. To me, industrial peace in my State means more than any political party. Let us take counsel together on this matter. There has never been any industrial question before any Parliament, State or Federal, which has caused such . uneasiness in the minds of trade unionists as this one has. I have never been able to subscribe to the view that the rank and file in the Labour movement are opposed to the wishes of their leaders. If they were, those leaders would not be in office very long. Call it cowardice if you will, but in order to secure two or two and a half years immunity from industrial trouble in my State I am prepared to go a long way in the taking . of political risks.

.This subject has been discussed from every angle, and there is little left for me to add. I shall endeavour, however, in the course of my remarks to throw some new light upon the motives which, I think, have actuated the Government in bringing this measure forward. Before embarking upon that phase of the subject, however, I wish to make some reference to the last speaker, and particularly to the suggestion that the States should be afforded an opportunity of putting into operation machinery to take the place of the existing federal industrial legislation.

talker.party: REV TAR; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917; CP from 1920; IND from 1928
talker.name: MCWILLIAMS, William
Mr McWILLIAMS

talk.start.para: - I did not ask for time to put it into motion.

- Well, the honorable member asked for time in which the States might get the necessary legislation ready. That sounds very well, but if the honorable member possesses the political acumen with which his long experience should have provided him, he must have been talking with his tongue in his cheek. He must know that in five States out of the six comprising the Common wealth there is a leg-rope upon the popular branch of the legislature - namely, a legislative council. He must know that those legislative councils will oppose any proposed legislation designed to give the workers an opportunity of justifying their claims to be treated as human beings, as they have been under the present system of federal arbitration. It is true that if arbitration is scrapped now it will be restored by a future Labour government, and it is inevitable that, in the course of time, a Labour government will again bo in power in the federal sphere. The system of federal arbitration is no new thing. It is a natural development of our social and industrial life. After 25 years' experience, however, there are still in this country, and in the House, some who would wish to see Australia back to pre-Federation conditions. The honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Mc Williams) spoke of the doings of conferences of State Premiers. I remember that at such a conference, held many years ago, it was decided by the Premiers of the six States that uniform action should be taken regarding six different matters, but such action was never taken. By means of these conferences they sought to achieve something which only a supreme federal parliament can properly achieve. Throughout Australia to-day conferences are being held between the heads of different institutions for the purpose of achieving uniformity of action throughout the whole Commonwealth. Yet, there is no one on the Government side with sufficient courage to tell the people that the natural corollary of such events is to invest this Federal Parliament with supreme legislative power throughout the whole of Australia. It is a case of " pull devil, pull baker " between the six States in an endeavour to determine which shall fare best at the expense of the others. Every year there takes place a transference of high Government officers from the administration of one State to that of another. Some time ago we in South Australia took Mr. Bellamy, an hydraulic engineer* from Tasmania. We, in our turn, lost a civil engineer, Mr. Veale, to Victoria or New South Wales, I forget which. This competition for the services of efficient men costs the taxpayers money. We should aim at closer organization, and a more unified form of government. The honorable member for Franklin knows very well that what he advocates would put back the clock a long way. In pre-arbitration days sweating conditions prevailed in many of the industries in South Australia under the old go-as-you-please system. I could tell stories of the heartless exploitation of men and women who received no protection under the law. I was a part of the system then, and I know what it was like. When the Labour party grew powerful enough in South Australia to be reckoned with, and to press for the introduction of ameliorative legislation, there was still the opposition of the Legislative Council to overcome. The Labour party was faced with the opposition of the Liberal party, the same party that, in the federal sphere, is now called the Nationalist party. Why it is so called, I do not know, except that the name was bestowed upon it by its founder, the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes). It would more fittingly be called the Conservative party. As a result of -the pressure brought to bear by the Labour party in South Australia, a system of wages boards was eventually established there. I have had experience of them, having sat upon one for some time. When the legislation providing for the establishment of these boards was introduced, the Legislative Council insisted that they should only be appointed to deal with such industries as Parliament agreed they should apply to. This meant agreement by both Houses. It was further stipulated that the provisions should have force only within a radius of ten miles of the city of Adelaide, the only exception being that Gawler was included. A long time elapsed before the system was extended throughout the whole State. Another provision was that the boards should not fix any wage, no matter what the workers' ability, higher than that paid by " a reputable employer " in South Australia.

speech.para: The word "reputable" was torn to shreds. Wages boards. were not allowed to make awards which prescribed higher rates of pay than those operating in Victoria. It was also provided that a man appointed a member of a wages board had to be actively engaged in the indus- try for at least three months prior to his appointment. That meant that no one but an active worker in the industry could be appointed to the board. In other words, the man had to face his boss across the table. I had that experience. The representatives of the employees submitted a log of wages which they considered reasonable. The increases sought were not staggering; but we knew that they would not be accepted without question. The employers also submitted a log. The chairman said that he would not split differences ; either one log or the other would be accepted in its entirety. The employees' representatives held another meeting, and decided to submit a new log which embodied the Victorian rates for the industry. The case concerned hardware assistants, the nature of whose work was the same in South Australia as in Victoria. The bosses asked for a rate 2s. 6d. a week lower. The chairman of the board had been appointed by the Government because the parties to the dispute could not agree on the appointment of a chairman. The decision of the chairman was in favour of the log submitted by the bosses. When I asked him by what process of reasoning he had arrived at that decision, he replied that he had given his judgment as a man of the world. I do not know what he intended to convey; but he gave no reasons for his decision. I mention this experience particularly for the benefit of the honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Mcwilliams) who said that the States should get ready for the transition period. We shall get very little from the States ; and what we do get will not bring about uniformity.
