There will still be overlapping, and variations in the margin for skill, if the control of industry is to be left to State tribunals, in which the influence of the Legislative Councils will predominate, then all I can say is " God help the workers." Another effort should be made to obtain for the Commonwealth the power that it should have, and I feel sure that if an appeal were made for that power the people would grant it. It is time that we owned up that the . logical result of federation is unification.

The remarks on this bill have been many and varied. By some speakers the Government has been roundly condemned, but so far, it has not answered the charges made against it. Although the speech of the right honorable gentleman for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) did not contain the sound reasoning of some of the other speeches that had been delivered, it contained one great truth. The right honorable gentleman said that the Government's proposals so staggered the electors, that they would reject them if given the opportunity. I am convinced that the right honorable member was right in that statement. Another great truth was expressed by the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) who said that the Government's proposal came as a bolt from the blue, not only to the Nationalist Party, but also to the people of . the Commonwealth. The honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) stripped the Government naked in regard to this bill. We are told that its passing will reduce the cost of production. If the honorable member for Fawkner was cross-examining a witness who made a statement like that, his next interrogation would be - " How will it reduce costs?" I ask how this bill will reduce costs if wages are not to come down ? The onus of showing how production costs can be decreased without a reduction of wages rests on the Government. The Prime Minister, addressing the Chamber of Manufactures in Sydney, said that overhead costs should be reduced. He urged greater standardization and more mergers. There is nothing illogical in what he said. He was really recommending something along the lines of the One Big Union. If unification is good for industry, it is good for the Commonwealth; but, in adopting it, we should not isolate ourselves from the heart of the Commonwealth and try to govern this country from a spot in the wilderness.

Dealing with the withdrawal of the prosecution against Mr. John Brown, the honorable member for Fawkner said that, while he could not justify the Government's action, he would not vote for the motion of censure because he was satisfied that the Prime Minister's motive was pure. The honorable member also condemned the Government in respect of the measure now before us ; but he did not say one word about the motive underlying its introduction.

talk.start.para: - In the censure motion the gravamen of the charge was that the Prime Minister's motive was dishonorable. I could not endorse that.
- The honorable member justified his action in supporting the Government by saying that he believed it was actuated by right motives.
- I did not support the withdrawal of the prosecution. I merely said that I could not support the Opposition in alleging a dishonorable motive for the act.

- The honorable member for Fawkner will agree that, when a case in the court has to be determined, not on known facts, but on the circumstances connected with it, one of the first things is to seek the motive. In the absence of a motive, and where the facts are not known, it is difficult to get a conviction on a serious charge. I expected the honorable member to seek the motive underlying the introduction of this measure. He said that the Government had no mandate to bring forward such legislation; that the Nationalist party's platform provided for arbitration; that" neither prior to nor during the election campaign had any intimation been given to the electors that such a proposal would be brought forward. He stripped the Government bare of everything, and yet he did not pursue his reasoning to the point of asking for the motive.
- It does not matter in this case what the motive is.
- It matters a great deal to the people of this country.
- On this occasion I propose to vote against the Government because I think it has acted wrongly. The motive does not matter.
- It is evidently a case of the Government being convicted per se.
- I thought that the honorable member for Adelaide, of all men, would appreciate the difference.

- I accept the honorable member's explanation. In this 'case he did not care what the motive was; he knew that the Government was in the wrong. But I shall endeavour to show the motive underlying the Government'* action. The speech of the Prime Minister when introducing the bill suggests a motive. The right honorable gentleman said that because the Arbitration Court had been defied in some instances, our arbitration legislation should be scrapped. That motive is too thin. Would he scrap the criminal law because sometimes it is broken? Laws are made because there are -violators of laws. When laws are made, it is assumed that there will bc law-breakers. The apparent motive underlying this legislation can, therefore, be set aside. It does not explain the Government's volte face. It has been said by some honorable members opposite that members of the working class have criticized the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, and that, therefore, the court should, be abolished. But that is very poor reasoning; it certainly does not justify removing from 750,000 people the protection which they now enjoy.

speech.para: The Prime Minister showed clearly, though he did not actually declare, the real object of the Government in introducing this bill. Nearly half of his speech had to do with financial affairs, and it might have been delivered more appropriately in a budget debate than in a debate on arbitration. The right honorable gentleman said -

quote.para: The Government believes that the existing financial and economic position of Australia renders necessary a measure of this kind, and that the bill is a real contribution towards the solution of the economic problems confronting us.

speech.para: As the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) bluntly asked, " How will this measure do anything to solve the economic problems that confront us?" I repeat the question. Neither the Prime Minister nor his supporters have given a reply to this inquiry. The question should be answered.
That quotation came from the beginning of the Prime Minister's speech. Here is one from near the end of it -

quote.para: The passing of this legislation will free industry from many of the embarrassments from which it lias suffered iu the past.

speech.para: Again I ask how this measure can do anything to free industry from its embarrassments? If the Prime Minister were in the chamber I daresay that he would say something about the overlapping of awards, and the dual control of industry; but that is not a sufficient ex- planation. The workers of this country have fought hard and long through the various Commonwealth and State Parliaments to set up and perfect their industrial machine and they will resist every effort that is made to reduce their wages and lengthen their hours of work.

In my opinion, the object of the Government is simply to cut down wages and lengthen the working week. I may be told that that is a wild assumption, but the Nationalist party has been consistently working to this end for a long while. The thin edge of the wedge was inserted by Sir Henry Barwell six years ago in South Australia, when he fought a State election on the slogan "Wages must come down. We must get back to the old law of supply and demand, and the old policy of freedom of contract." That is exactly what this Government is working for. In the opinion of the Government, industry is embarrassed because the worker of to-day is not in quite the same position as the slave of yesterday. The employers desire to revive the old policy of piece-work, which enabled them to press every ounce of energy out of their young, strong and vigorous employees. Some of the men with whom I worked 40 years ago under the piece-work system are to-day in a pitiful plight now that they are old men.

talk.start.para: - The Government wants to get back to. the old policy of " Rafferty rules."
- It seems to me that that is so. Here is another extract from the Prime Minister's speech -

quote.para: Now, as the ledger cannot be balanced without the imposition of more taxation, which will increase the cost of production and thus further hamper the development of our great industries, we must endeavour, by increasing our national prosperity and stimulating industry, to enlarge the field over which our taxation is spread.

speech.para: That paragraph reminds me of the man who, having delivered his speech, asked, " Gentlemen, am I sufficiently ambiguous." The Prime Minister's speech was ambiguous from beginning to end, and he cannot complain if there are many interpretations of it. What does the right honorable gentleman mean by enlarging the field of taxation? Does he intend to spread it over the field of secondary production? It must be remembered that this measure affects almost exclusively those engaged in secondary production. The Government desire, it would seem, is to make one man do the work of two; but it forgets that by so doing it will increase our army of unemployed and cause us quickly to reach the saturation point.

The honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Fenton) quoted some interesting opinions on this branch of the subject. In my opinion, the cry for more production is wrong. We already produce too much. I cannot see how the scrapping of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court and the evacuation by the Commonwealth of the field of industrial arbitration can do anything to stimulate industry. Again, with the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart), I ask, "How can this policy improve our economic position?" Honorable members opposite must know very well that if this bill becomes law a great deal of discontent will be caused in the community. It is quite likely that the growth of bolshevism will be encouraged. It is certain that unemployment will increase. I know very well from experience that hungry men are angry men.- They are also desperate men. It is not a good thing for the country that the wives and children of men who are willing to work, but cannot get it, should be left on the verge of starvation, while the shops and factories of the land are crammed full of merchandise.
The Prime Minister went on to say -

quote.para: In 1013, the year before the Great War, Australia's production was valued at f 22 1, 000,000. Taxation that year amounted to ?23,000,000 or 10.4 per cent, of the value of production.
In 1927-28 the value of production had increased to ?450,000,000, but taxation had increased to ?88,000,000, or 19.6 per cent, of the value of production.

speech.para: What has that got to do with the Arbitration Court? The Prime Minister should have proved that the workers were responsible for the huge increase in taxation from 10 per cent, to 19.6 per cent. The value of production in 1913 was ?221,000,000, and' in 1927-28 it amounted to ?S80,000,000- a fourfold increasebut the taxation per head of the population had not doubled. I shall show the reason for the increase in taxation. It does not mean that the worker has " gone slow," and it is not due to high wages. In an address given by Mr. Wickens, the Commonwealth Statistician, before the Industrial Peace Conference in Sydney on the 19th February last, and reported in the Economic Record of that month, he said -

quote.para: With this analysis of our population before us, let us turn to the tangible results of their efforts during that portion of the present century which we have under review. Let us take first the value of their production. The total value of primary and manufacturing production combined was estimated at ?114,600,000, or ?30 per head of population, in 1901, as compared with ?446,900,000, or ?73 per head of population, in 1920-27. These figures indicate that the total value was nearly four times as great in the later as in the earlier year, and the value per head of population nearly two and a half times- as great. The change in price levels during the period is, of course, an important factor in this matter, and since, on the average, the prices involved were some 81 per cent, higher in the later than in the earlier year, the total production in 1926-27, on the basis of the 1901 prices, would have had a value of approximately ?247,000,000, and the production per head would have been ?40. These figures indicate, roughly, that the total quantity produced in primary and manufacturing industries in 1926-27 exceeded that in 1901 by 110 per cent., and that the total quantity per head produced in 1926-27 exceeded that in 1901 by 33 per cent.

speech.para: Does the Prime Minister expect the people to believe his doleful story about the condition of affairs in Australia in face of those figures ? I shall quote Mr. Wickens a little further, so that the details of production will be placed in Hansard alongside the statements by the Prime Minister -

quote.para: I have already indicated that, taking values only into account, the total from all sources for 1926-27 was four times as great as that for 1901. This ratio, of course, differs in different industries. Thus in agriculture and in pastoral industry the total value for 1926-27 was rather more than four times as great as that for 1901. In dairying and in forestry and fisheries the ratio approached five, and in manufacturing it exceeded five. In mining, however, there was little change, an increase in value of only 9 per cent, being recorded. It must be noted here that for the purpose of those returns manufacturing value represents the value added in process of manufacture; that is to say, it is the value of output less the value of raw material and fuel used, thus obviating duplication. With the single exception of mining, the value of the production of the various branches of industry has increased solidly during the period under review, the agricultural and pastoral industries representing the smallest proportionate increase and manufacturing the largest. Until 1019 the pastoral industry occupied the position of chief producing agency, and was usually responsible for some 30 per cent, of the total value of Australia's primary and manufacturing production. From 1.921 onwards, however, the manufacturing industry lias assumed the lead, and now represents more than a third of the total.

speech.para: That is an absolute contradiction of most of the arguments advanced by the section represented by honorable members opposite, which always complains that the workers " go slow " and that production costs are too high. The facts that I have adduced lead me to ask what justification can be found for the bill. Mr. Wickens also dealt with the agricultural industry, and I shall quote sufficient to show that the Prime Minister's remarks were not in accord with the facts regarding activities in our primary and secondary industries. Speaking of wheat, Mr. Wickens said -

quote.para: In the last eight years of the last century the average production of wheat per annum was 31,000,000 bushels, and the maximum for any one year 41,000,000 bushels. In the last eight years of the present century the average yield per annum was 133,000,000 bushels and the maximum 105,000,000, approximately a fourfold increase in quantity in each case.

speech.para: The records of this country read like a fairy tale; but, when the party opposite sets out to attack the working classes, statements are made that are not borne out by the facts. Mr. Wickens referred to sheep in these terms -

quote.para: During the ten years from the season 1916-17 to the season 1926-27 the total quantity of wool produced per annum increased from 630,000,000 lb. of greasy wool to 924,000,000, but slipped back in 1927-28 to about 900,000,000. A tentative estimate for the season 1928-29 is 950,000,000, which, if correct, is the record wool production for Australia.

speech.para: The Prime Minister has made specious misrepresentations of the facts in an attempt to justify the scrapping of our arbitration machinery. Regarding cattle, Mr. Wickens stated -

quote.para: A peak of over 12,500,000 cattle had been reached in 1894, followed by a persistent decline to 7,000,000 in 1902, a rise to 11,750,000 in 1911, a decline to 10,000,000 in 1915, succeeded by a rise in 1921 to 14,500,000, the highest cattle figures ever recorded. Since this latter date there has been a continuous decline until the latest figures indicate a total of no more than 11,500,000. This latter decline is due to a large extent to the relatively unprofitable character of cattle raising in some Australian pastoral areas in recent times, owing to the unsatisfactory state of the oversea market.

speech.para: Again, I say that any unsatisfactory conditions that may give cause for comment are not due to any " go slow " movement, to short hours, or to high wages. The Statistician goes on to say -

quote.para: In what may be termed the dairy and farmyard group of industries we have again a predominant item. This time it is butter, and the position which it occupies is an important one, representing as it does some 40 per cent, of the total value of the output of the group, and amounting in 1926-27 to nearly ?20,000,000. Eggs and poultry have a wholesale value of upwards of ?10,000,000 per annum, and milk consumed as such of upwards of ?7,000,000. In 1901 the total production of butter in Australia was 103,750,000 lb., and for the year 1927-28 it has increased to 280,000,000 lb. Cheese, concentrated milk, bacon, ham, and pork are other increasingly prominent items in the dairying branch of production. The production of cheese increased during the period under review from 11,000,000 lb. to 20,000,000, and ham and bacon from 32,000,000 lb. to 73,000,000.

speech.para: Mr. Wickensproceeded to deal with the manufacturing industries. He went over the whole gamut of production before delegates who would understand the significance of the figures he quoted, and in the face of those statistics I cannot understand why the Prime Minister should be such a dismal Jeremiah. The right honorable gentleman said that " the passing of this legislation will free industry from many of the embarrassments it has suffered in the past." Mr. Wickens, to the Peace in Industry Conference said -

quote.para: Coming next, to the manufacturing industries, we have a much more pleasing story of growth.

speech.para: Dealing with the wages in the secondary industries he said -

quote.para: In the matter of salaries and wages of employees, the total paid in 1907 was ?18,300,000, and in 1926-27, ?90,600,000, representing about ?78 each in 1907 per annum and ?202 each in 1920-27. Those wages represented on the average about 55 per cent, of the value added to raw materials in the process of manufacture.

speech.para: In other words nearly half the added value was available to pay the cost of rent, fuel, light, and miscellaneous expenses, and profit. Mr. Wickens continued -

quote.para: This added value increased from ?33,000,000 in 1907 to ?162,000,000 in 1920-27, or allowing for change in price levels, by about 180 per cent. We have thus, on all hands, evidence of a remarkable increase in manufacturing industry during the twenty years for which comparable data are available.

speech.para: I turn now to an important passage in this illuminating lecture-

quote.para: Comparing from different dates the estimates of Australian private wealth referred to earlier, it is of interest to note that the estimate of 1903 gave an average per head of population of ?252, that of 1915, ?327, that of 1921, ?397, that of 1923, ?420, and the latest made for 1925 gave ?478.

speech.para: Each of Mr. Wickens' statements gives the lie direct to the Prime Minister and they were made authoritatively before a body which the right honorable gentleman had brought into existence with a view to bringing about peace in industry. Yet he and his supporters have had the audacity to attack the workers and to rob them of their right of appeal to the courts of the land. It is useless to say that the workers and the Arbitration Court are ruining industry. If that is true the judges are not worth their salt. They hear the evidence and declare that a man is worth ?4 5s. a week, shall work only 44 hours weekly, and shall enjoy this and that condition. The worker depends upon the judgment of the court; he cannot order the boss to pay him what he asks. If the worker does at times say bitter things when he is treated as John Brown is treating his slaves he is more than justified, because he is driven to do so by desperation while the ruthless employer acts in cold blood. The Prime Minister said in regard to the finances of the Commonwealth -

quote.para: The position is extremely difficult because of the growing feeling of uncertainty as to the trend of affairs.

speech.para: That is a specious argument to be advanced by a man whose training should have given him a full knowledge of the finances of Australia. I should be able to apply to him a word that would describe what he is when he makes such misstatements.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member will not be allowed to do so.

- I quite understand that the word I would like to use is not parliamentary, but it will be used elsewhere. The following table taken from the Year Booh shows the financial position of the banks operating in Australia, and is very significant -
- Order ! The honorable member's time has expired.

.During the 44 hours of debate on this measure the industrial position of the Commonwealth has been considered from every angle. Whilst the case for and against the bill has been stated with a good deal of eloquence and occasionally with vehemence, the debate has been conducted with remarkable good temper, having regard to the circumstances of this sitting. One cannot deal with the matter as he would wish to do without repeating what has been said by other debaters. I have no desire to occupy a great deal of -time at this hour of the morning, but my constitutents will expect from me a statement of my reasons for supporting the measure.

speech.para: The Commonwealth system of conciliation and arbitration has been in operation for about 25 years and nobody can deny that it has had a fair trial. Because the Government and honorable members supporting it spoke in favour of the amending, arbitration act last year, and are now about to vote for the abolition of the federal arbitration system, it is unfair to charge them with inconsistency. Circumstances have arisen during this year which compel us to realize that this Parliament has no alternative but to repeal the Arbitration Act which has given satisfaction to neither employers nor employees and has been defied openly by one side and to a lesser extent by the other. Those honorable members on the ministerial side who have declared that the Government has no mandate for the introduction of this bill overlook what has happened during the last twelve months and the attitude of the unions and their leaders towards the arbitration court. Prior to the award in the timber workers' case the court had never reduced wages or increased the working hours. When that occurred the prophecies of many, who claimed to understand the attitude of the workers, that as soon as the court refused them what they demanded they would flout its awards, were verified. First, the union went on strike in defiance of the court; next, other unions rallied to the support of the strikers, and then the labour leaders throughout Australia endorsed that attitude of oppostion to and defiance of the court. In fact a general boycott of the court was established. The leaders of unionism in Australia have advised their followers to defy the court. Many instances of this have been given by other speakers during the debate, but I will confine myself to one. On the 9th February this year 30 of the federated unions after the three days' conference at Melbourne unanimously passed the following resolution : -

quote.para: That all unions now before the Federal Arbitration Court bo urged not to proceed with their plaints or to appear before the court officially.

speech.para: Herein we have a deliberate boycott of the court organized by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions with the avowed intention of compelling the judiciary to enforce a 44-hours' week. It was frankly claimed by the union leaders responsible for the resolution that if all the unions agreed to the course a death-blow would be dealt to arbitration. No Government who allowed such a position to continue would be entitled to the respect and confidence of the country. In addition to the open defiance of the court, men who are willing to work under the award of the court were maltreated. The Stateswere either unable or unwilling to protect them. When a law is made specifically to protect certain people, and they defy it, if we are powerless to enforce it we should abolish the law.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member suggest that, under this bill, the Commonwealth will be in a position to enforce an award of the proposed committees ?

- In addition to repealing the present arbitration law the Government proposes to set up what are called industrial committees, to deal with maritime industries. According to the Attorney-General, the Commonwealth has full powers with regard to trade and commerce. Some honorable members have asked why other industries cannot be similarly dealt with. The reason advanced by the Attorney-General is that they cannot be dealt with under the trade and commerce powers." Under the trade and commerce powers which the Commonwealth now possesses, it can enforce the awards made by these maritime industrial committees. The honorable member for Fawkner suggests that the Commonwealth is powerless to enforce awards. I draw attention to what happened during the last strike in the maritime industry. The Commonwealth then took action which settled that strike in a majority of the ports of the Commonwealth within a fortnight. I have never been satisfied that the present system is a good one. It is cumbersome, slow in operation, and costly, and has promoted strife rather than peace. Some honorable members opposite have said that it costs unions many thousands of pounds to have their cases heard, and they complain that it will cost them many more thousands if they have to approach a State tribunal. The Commonwealth Court should not be so costly. We want a simplified procedure. If the system has become unworkable, and we are powerless to institute a better one because of our constitutional limitations, the Commonwealth should vacate this field. Having reached the stage that neither side wants it and both sides defy it, the Government would not deserve the support of any section of the people if it did not take action such as that now proposed.

speech.para: During the course of the debate the hon- 'orable member for Franklin (Mr. Mcwilliams) made certain statements with respect to the effect of strikes on Tasmania. I regret that I feel impelled to correct him in certain respects, because Tasmanian members have the reputation of speaking with one voice regarding matters that affect ' their State. I agree that Tasmania has suffered tremendously as a result of strikes on the mainland, because it is dependent entirely on transport by sea ; but I remind my honorable friend that for years we have not had a strike which affected Tasmania to any great extent, because of the firm action taken by this Government against those who were holding up the transport service between the mainland and Tasmania.

The honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Mcwilliams) has told the House that although he intends to vote for the second reading of this measure he will support any amendment to postpone its operation until the people have an opportunity of being consulted either by referendum or election. It is his right and privilege to vote as he thinks fit,' but I cannot see eye to eye with him. He says that he will do anything to help Tasmania. I represent a Tasmanian constituency and I would go as far as the honorable member in helping to assist that State to progress by improving the transport facilities to the mainland, but I fail to see how Tasmania is to be assisted or strikes prevented by deferring the operation of this legislation for two years. Every strike that has occurred has been in defiance of an Arbitration Court award. I, therefore, cannot understand the argument of the honorable member for Franklin that we shall assist Tasmania by continuing the present system of arbitration. The honorable member said that the ' industries on the mainland benefit to the detriment of industries of Tasmania. He made a statement that I am bound to contradict. He is unfair to Tasmania when he says that there is practically no industry operating to-day in the State because of the operation of awards and the luring of its workers to the mainland. It is not often that I quote figures, but under the circumstances, let me say, that in 1902, there were 420 factories in Tasmania employing 7,466 hands; in 1909, 544 factories, employing 9,322 hands; and in 1927, 767 factories employing 11,694 hands. According to those figures the position of Tasmania in regard to its industrial activities, is not, as the honorable member for Franklin has stated, gradually becoming worse. As a matter of fact there has been a steady increase in both the number of factories and employees. During the last two years the position of Tasmania has improved tremendously. Our exports, both primary products and manufactories, have increased. I do not give the figures showing the progress of our primary and mining industries, for I take it that the honorable member for Franklin (Mr. Mcwilliams), when he said that practically every factory of importance had closed down, excluded the mining industry. We have in Tasmania a wonderful industry in the Electrolytic Zinc Works, which employs some thousands of hands in Hobart' and on the west coast of Tasmania. The industry has progressed steadily for years. In my own electorate there is, as well as the Electrolytic Zinc mining fields, the Mount Lyell Company, the only copper mine in the Commonwealth that is operating successfully to-day. The enterprise has been a success only because of its efficient management and the fine type of employee at the mines. It was able to continue its operations even when the price of copper fell to ?60 a ton. The only valid argument in support of a Federal arbitration system is the necessity for uniformity of awards. "We know now that that is practically impossible of achievement, because the Federal Arbitration Court has no power to insist upon it. One serious difficulty is that only those who are cited before the court come within the ambit of its awards. I should like to' see Australia return to the conditions when a certain amount of collective bargaining took place between those engaged in industry. The workmen were .then more satisfied with' their wages and conditions of employment, but unfortunately they have been compelled by the union to which they belonged to go on strike because of some little dissatisfaction existing, in one of the other States. That happened in the case of a strike of the waterside workers. The dispute arose over a trivial question concerning the pick-up, and as a result an attempt was made to hold up the whole of the shipping of Australia. In that case, fortunately, the dispute did not extend to Tasmania. "Work continued on the wharves in Tasmania, and when the men were called out they refused to cease work and continued to handle the products of Tasmania. Because of that strike on the mainland, thousands of men were thrown out of employment in other industries, though they were perfectly satisfied with their conditions. If the effect of the establishment of a common rule is to compel men. who are willing to work, to throw down their tools and bring about chaos in industry, then I prefer control of industry by the States instead of by the Commonwealth. Not long ago there was a strike of timber workers on the mainland. The timber workers in Tasmania were perfectly satisfied with their conditions and they continued to work until such time as the labourers on the mainland refused to handle Tasmanian timber. As a consequence, the mills had to close down. Isolation is sometimes a good thing for a country. The isolation of Tasmania prevents the poison that is manufactured on the mainland from being instilled into the minds of the workers. I am a great believer in the law of compensation, and the compensation for the isolation of the workers on the "West Coast is that they are separated from the influence of labour leaders on the mainland.

During this. debate much has been said about the number of strikes that have taken place in Australia and the number of working days lost as a result. I do not intend to compare the position of Australia with that of Canada or any other country as has been done by other speakers because that does not affect my argument. Strikes have taken place' in Australia despite the favorable conditions of employment and the existence of tribunals established for the settlement of disputes. When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was speaking on this bill I interjected that unemployment in Australia was mainly caused by strikes. Unemployment is the direct result of strikes, which cause a lack of confidence on the part of those who control capital. As the honorable member for Brisbane (Mr. D. Cameron) has truly said, there would be plenty of capital available for enterprise in this country if those who control it had a reasonable assurance that conditions of employment would remain unaltered. Unfortunately there is no such assurance.

There is no guarantee of any security; those wishing to invest capital in industry are always faced with the possibility of operations being suddenly suspended. If Australia is to prosper and our people are to be successful, the investment of capital to enable our industries to be developed should be facilitated. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore) referred to the prevalence of unemployment which he inferred was largely due to the maladministration of the Government. The unemployment has been caused mainly by a succession of strikes which have affected employment in not only the industry particularly concerned, but also those dependent upon it for supplies. It is true that we will always have unemployment in varying degrees; that must be expected as our prosperity is governed largely by seasonal and other conditions. Although production has not been satisfactory during the last year or two, the general conditions are such that the number of unemployed in Australia at present should be considerably less than it is. I admit that some employers adopt an unreasonable attitude which has the effect of disturbing the industrial balance, but the main cause of a good deal of the unemployment which prevails must rest with the representatives of organized labour, who very unwisely direct the men to disregard the award of a tribunal which was brought into existence for their protection. It is idle to repeat that when wages are inflated the cost of living increases in many cases out of proportion to the higher rates. No one is foolish enough to think that industry will produce more than is put into it. What is needed in Australia to-day is that a little more of the sweet spirit of reasonableness should be displayed by all engaged in industry. The employers' interests have to be protected and the rights and privileges of the employees, without whose assistance industry cannot prosper, should be safeguarded. If the employers will provide reasonable working conditions and the employees will give an honest day's work for the money the court awards, production will increase and peace in industry will be assured. It is the selfishness of both the employer and the employee that causes many of the difficulties with which we are confronted to-day. I support the proposal which the Government has somewhat unexpectedly submitted, but which I am sure will meet with the approval of not only its supporters in Parliament, but the people generally. In the ordinary course of events, it will be a little over two years before we have to again face the electors, and when that period has elapsed I believe that the conditions in industry in Australia will be such that the action of those who are supporting the Government will be fully justified.

talk.start.para: .- I desire to associate myself with the protest uttered by the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) against the action of the Government in compelling honorable members to work unreasonable hours to discuss a measure of great national importance. It has been claimed by many honorable members opposite that the Government has received a mandate for the bill now before the chamber, but I am convinced that whatever interpretation is placed upon the remarks of the Prime Minister in opening the political campaign prior to the last elections, it cannot

speech.para: Be suggested that he even hinted at the abolition of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The Prime Minister has said that the cost of production must be reduced, but he has not given the slightest indication of how that can be done. Apparently the only way to achieve his objective is to lower wages. Last night the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers) practically apologized for the present high standard of living in Australia. I am proud that our standard is higher than it is in many other civilized countries, and I shall use every power at my disposal to prevent the workers in this country from being compelled to work under conditions less favorable than those which now prevail. During the debate statesmen such as Barton, Deakin, Kingston and Higgins, have been mentioned, all of whom studied the question of the Commonwealth powers and responsibilities from every viewpoint. The utterances of these and other eminent men which have been quoted, suggest that, in their day, it was never contemplated that any Government would legislate in this way.

The honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) strongly criticized the Government for taking this drastic step without consulting the electors, and said -that the Prime Minister had " stolen a march " upon the people. In my opinion, the Government and the Prime Minister are synonymous terms. The right honorable member for North Sydney, who has seen our arbitration system develop to its present stage, has said that the Prime Minister had been recreant to his trust; that he had betrayed the people and that he was now submitting a reactionary and craven policy. I regard the measure as a pusillanimous piece of political perfidy. On the 21st May, 1926, the Attorney-General, Mr. Latham, said -

quote.para: I say it is out of all question to consider seriously the suggestion that this industrial machinery should be scrapped, and all the court's awards, the result of twenty years' work, set aside, interstate industrial disputes being left for the future to the adjudication of some j i resent non-existent body. . . .

If we wish to secure industrial peace through the medium of the law, there must lie some means of dealing with these disputes on a federal basis, and, therefore, the Government is of opinion that it is necessary to continue the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, and to make certain improvements to it.

speech.para: I suppose honorable members -supporting the Government in this instance are also of that opinion. lt would appear that when the Prime Minister changes his mind his supporters also change their minds! Certainly there are a few exceptions. The right honorable gentleman has a squad, which he has trained thoroughly in the art of changing step. But he also has a small awkward squad who do not change step as readily as the others. Should a war again break out and honorable members opposite volunteer, the sergeantmajor will have little difficulty in training them to change step. The Prime Minister manages his team well. He cracks his whip, and they promptly respond. I admit that there are a few recalcitrants, who cause the right honorable gentleman no little perturbation.

During his second-reading speech the Treasurer (Dr. Page) stigmatized the Opposition as cowards,' and claimed that all the courage was possessed by honorable members opposite. The honorable member for Bourke (Mr. Anstey) replied very effectively. But I shall also examine this accusation of cowardice, and . see where it really applies. It should be the desire of the Government to bring disputing parties together, but the Prime Minister has been noticeably lacking in this respect. I have recollections of the Treasurer as a private member having referred to his present leader as a man who would paralyze industry and lead Australia to ruin, if he were given the chance. Shortly afterwards a bait labelled " Commonwealth Treasurer " was dangled before him, and, metaphorically speaking, he swallowed hook, line, bait and sinker. I admire the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) for relinquishing office and refusing to sacrifice his principles. Then the honorable member for Henty (Mr. Gullett) referred to the Treasurer as the most tragic Treasurer that Australia had ever seen. He, too, was taken into the fold. The Prime Minister is, indeed, an adept at collecting a team and in stifling criticism.

Now let us examine the courage of the Government and of honorable members opposite. When the waterside workers broke the law, they were gloriously courageous. They were prosecuted with the utmost rigour of the law. But when John Brown, the coal baron, broke the law, the courage of the Government failed. It baulked at the first stiff hurdle. John Brown is still brazenly defying the law, and the Government, by its attitude of impotence, ineptitude, and inaction, is aiding and abetting him in his continued flagrant defiance of it. Yet the miners, their wives and their children, are permitted to suffer the pangs of hunger. Here is an occasion when the alleged strong man, the courageous Prime Minister, could take action. Instead, he skulks behind the reserve forces, afraid to face the music. So much for the men of courage.

The honorable member for Wimmera, at the invitation of the Government, gave a resume of the bungling tactics of the Government in handling industrial matters. The Federal Court of Conciliation and Arbitration is about to be jettisoned. One honorable member likened the tribunal to a ship that is not worth patching up, that is brought into port leaking and with its sails in shreds. Another honorable member pertinently interjected that it was probably not the ship, but the crew, that was at fault. I agree that it is the fault of the crew. Although the Government knows that the Federal Arbitration Court is operating satisfactorily, it proposes to scrap it. Its courage has failed ; it is about to relinquish the substance and grasp at the shadow.

In his second-reading speech the Prime Minister hoped that honorable members would consider the matter in a non-party spirit; from a national point of view. Until quite recently he was a believer in coercion in industrial matters. But he made the statement in connexion with this proposal, that -

quote.para: We have come to the conclusion, as a result of recent experience, that we cannot prevent strikes and lockouts by the provision and infliction of penalties.

speech.para: And immediately his followers changed step and fell in behind him. The Prime Minister used coercion on his followers. He told them, in effect, that if this measure is not carried, the only alternative is the holding of a general election. He is neither consistent nor courageous.

Now let me examine the so-called cowardice of honorable members on this side of the chamber. They, urge the prosecution of John Brown, and even censure the Government for withdrawing it. They stand for human rights, the rights of the miners working in the mines, and of their wives and children. Can that be classified as cowardice? Honorable members on this side are opposed to the reduction of existing awards and to an increase of hours. They stand against moral degradation and economic degeneration. So that the Treasurer is unable to substantiate his charges of cowardice.

The honorable member for Darwin (Mr. Bell) stated that federal arbitration should be abolished because its awards were totally ignored by one side, and partly disobeyed by the other. That is not a fair, statement of the position. I can remember, some years ago, that when there was trouble in the mines owned by John Brown, that individual said, in effect, to the miners, " Very well, I can close down the mines and sit back. I know who will starve first." Should a man who adopts such a truculent and unworthy attitude be allowed to continue the ownership of those mines ? Should he be allowed to continue arrogantly and flagrantly defying the law? A strong, courageous leader would not countenance the continuance of such a state of affairs.

When I spoke on the censure motion dealing with the withdrawal of the prosecution against John Brown, I instanced the strong action that was taken by the late President Roosevelt, of the United States of America, when he satisfactorily settled the great coal strike which occurred in that country in 1902. After a great deal of trouble, President

Roosevelt got the parties together. The men were out on strike for higher wages, but he induced both parties to agree to a conference under threat of carrying into effect some drastic proposals if they refused. The arbitration commission was formed, and both sides to the dispute were bound to abide by its decision. In the meantime the men went back to work. Contrast that with the situation existing during the present lockout on the New South Wales coal-fields. There is a commission sitting, it is true, but neither side is bound to accept its decision. In fact, the miners have already said that they will not hold themselves bound by any decision arrived at, and they are, I think, justified in adopting that attitude. Here is a report of the proceedings of the commission when the parties were discussing whether or not the owners' books should be produced.
Mr. JusticeDavidson said: "Nobody has the right to know how much it costs a colliery company to mine coal or how much profit a company is making."

Seeing that the miners' rates of pay are based upon the profits derived from the coal mines, it is of vital importance that they should know what those profits are. John Brown is still flagrantly defying the law, the miners are still out of work, and their wives and families are suffering. If we had a man here with the resolution and ability of President Roosevelt, such a condition of affairs would not be allowed. If the honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) were at the helm this trouble would have been settled long ago. Exception was taken to his actions while he was in office, but at least he obtained results, and that is more than can be said of the present administration. As the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) truly said this afternoon, industrial legislation in Australia has been bungled. Not long ago we were told by members of the Government that the rank and file of the unions were bossed by the union officials, and that legislation was necessary to give the rank and file control of their organizations. Amendments were made in the Arbitration Act to ensure this being done. Further industrial trouble occurred shortly afterwards. The union officials gave instructions to the men that they were to go back to work, but the men refused. Then the Government said that the union officials did not have proper control over the rank and file, and that it was necessary to pass legislation which would give them that control. Accordingly the Transport Workers Act was passed. That is a glaring instance of the legislative bungling perpetrated by this Government in connexion with arbitration. The Government has not only bungled arbitration, but has failed in every other sphere of activity as well. The Minister for Customs was right when he said that the present Treasurer was the most tragic Australia had ever had. When this Government took office there was a surplus of ?7,400,000; to-day there is a deficit of ?5,000,000. It has been truly said of the Treasurer that he may be a good surgeon, but that, as a Treasurer, he would bleed Australia white. In the Federal Arbitration Court there are registered 143 unions with a membership of 7 64,000, and of these 407,000 are working under awards. Twenty-eight employers' organizations are registered in the court, and there are 16,400 employees of these organ.izatons

No one on either side of the House contends that our arbitration system is free from defects. It remains true, however, that the great mass of workers registered in the Court are working amicably in accordance with the terms of their awards. Yet it is proposed to scrap this tribunal in favour of something that may be set up by the States. If this is done those unions which are now organized on a federal basis will be disintegrated. At the same time that the Government proposes to do this, it is encouraging the formation of big business mergers. If the working classes are to meet these mergers on a basis of equality, they must be organized on a federal basis. Some of these mergers are not only federal but international in character. The honorable member who preceded me referred to the timber workers' dispute. He admitted that he did not know a great deal about it. At any rate, when I asked him a question relating to the dispute he did not answer it and I assumed that he did not know very much about the subject. It is true that the timber workers did disobey an award of the Federal Arbitration Court because they considered that award unjust. How was that award arrived at ? When the Arbitration Act was last amended a clause was inserted to the effect that before any new award was made, or existing award varied, the economic effect of such new award or such variation of an existing award should be taken into account. An effort was made to give effect to this clause when considering the timber workers' award, and an inquiry was alleged to have been made into the books of firms engaged in the timber industry. We were told that the books of only ten firms were examined by an accountant, although there are over 1,000 firms engaged in the industry. On the strength of that examination it was alleged that a profit of only 2.2 per cent, was being made by the employers, and as a result tie working week was lengthened, and wages in some cases reduced.

talk.start.para: - That applied only to city workers. Most of the mills are in the country.

- The award issued by Judge Lukin provided a wage' of ?3 a week for bush boys of 19 years of age. If the honorable member has had any experience of the bush he must know that the average bush boy of 19 years of age is a big, hefty fellow, physically as good as he will ever be. Yet his wage is fixed at ?3 a week. What would the average employer do if he received an application for a job from such a bush boy, and from a middle-aged married man with a wife and family to support. He would have to pay much more than ?3 a week to the married applicant, so it is only natural that he would give the job to the boy. The workers allege that the inquiry into the profits of the timber industry was not a fair one because the books of only ten firms were examined, and the names of those firms were kept secret. Does any honorable member contend that a fair estimate of the average profits of an industry can be arrived at by examining the books of ten firms out of a total of 1,000?
- It depends on the percentage of the total turn-over represented by the business of those ten firms.

- Suppose the butchers in a small town are engaged in cut-throat competition to secure trade, and an accountant examines their books to find out what their profits are. Would it be fair to say that their profits represented the average profit of the butchering trade throughout an entire State, and on the strength of the finding regulate the wages for all employees engaged in the industry ? It is . true that the timber workers broke the award, and I do not stand for that. This party has always stood for the maintenance of law and order.
- What has the honorable member's party done to get the strikers back to work?
- What has this Government done to get the miners back to work in the coal-mines? I await the honorable member's answer.
- The Labour party should take the initiative.

- The Attorney-General claims that the Transport Workers Act has brought peace to the water-front. The honorable gentleman should not be too certain that permanent peace has been secured there. I liken the position on the water-front to a quiescent volcano - the more protracted its state of quiescence the more violent the eruption when it does come. In the Victorian Parliament recently a question was asked regarding the cost of providing police protection on the water-front. The answer was such as to make one think. Peace will not be secured by such means. As soon as the police protection has been removed the eruption will come.

speech.para: The Prime Minister said that his Government had come to the conclusion, as a result of recent experience, that it could not prevent strikes aud lockouts by the provision and infliction of penalties. At least he has learned the lesson which history teaches - namely, that coercion has never been conducive to industrial peace. It never will be. The way in which the minds of honorable members supporting the Government change with every change of the Prime Minister's mind leads me to adapt the well-known lines of Shakespeare to make them read -

quote.para: Why, man, he doth bestride the Commonwealth Like a Colossus; and they, petty men,
Walk under his huge legs, and peep about To find themselves dishonorable graves.

speech.para: I speak, of course, in a political sense only-

quote.para: Now, in the names of all the gods at once,
Upon what meat doth this our P.M. feed,
That he is grown so great?

speech.para: Honorable members opposite say that peace and prosperity in industry can only be maintained by keeping the Labour party off the Treasury bench. Let me contrast the position of Australia under a Labour Government with its state to-day under a so-called Nationalist Government. In an interview recently Mr. Wickens, the Commonwealth Statistician, said that in all countries during periods of depression the natural birth-rate decreases and the death-rate increases. He added that that had been the position in Australia for some time. He also said that the number of migrants entering a country was an index to its prosperity. Statistics show that the record year for migrants entering the Commonwealth was during the regime of a Labour Government. In one year over 90,000 migrants came to Australia. The next best year in this connexion was also during the term of office of the Fisher Government when about 63,000 migrants came here. During 1928-29 only 17,000 migrants came to Australia. If the statement of Mr. Wickens is correct those figures go to show that there was greater prosperity in Australia when a Labour Government was in office than exists today under a Nationalist Government.

talk.start.para: - Yet honorable members opposite still say that too- many migrants are entering this country.'

- They should be kept out while there is so much unemployment here. During the regime of the Labour Government to which I have referred migrants came to Australia of their own accord and at their own expense. There was no need for the Government to offer inducements to bring them here. Nevertheless, it was blamed for not chartering special ships for that purpose. Such was the prosperity of Australia under a Labour Government than exists now. Labour has been tried in Australia, and it has not been found wanting. The present Government has been fruitful in promises, but barren in results. Its administration has resulted in unprecedented poverty, depression, strife and unemployment. I was pleased at the stand taken by the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) in connexion with this bill. Both he and the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mi-. Hughes) learned the dignity of labour in a hard school.

speech.para: One criticism of the Federal Arbitration Court is that it operates in a legal atmosphere,- but a study of this measure shows that it, too, will flourish in a legal atmosphere. It is true that it provides for the establishment of committees; but every determination made by a committee whose chairman is not a judge must be referred to the Chief Judge, who may, or may not, allow it. If the chairman of the committee is a. judge the determination need not be sent on to the Chief Judge. A judicial atmosphere pervades the bill. The right honorable member for North Sydney suggested that industrial disputes should be settled by men with practical industrial experience. This legislation does not do that. I am sorry that the honorable member for Fawkner did not have time to complete his speech. He said that if time had permitted he intended to refer to the moral and spiritual aspects of this industrial question. A quotation from An 'Autogbiographyby Theodore Roosevelt, an ex-President of the United States of America, might supply that which the honorable member for Fawkner would have given us. The following extract is from page 512 of the autobiography -

quote.para: A democracy can bc such in fact only if there is some rough approximation to similarity in stature among the men composing it . . . a simple and poor society can exist as a democracy on a basis of sheer individualism. But a rich and complex . industrial society cannot so exist; for some individuals, and especially those artificial individuals called corporations, become so big that the ordinary individual is utterly dwarfed beside them, and cannot deal with them on terms of equality. It, therefore, becomes, necessary for these ordinary individuals to combine in their turn, first in order to act in their collective capacity through that biggest of all combinations called the government, and second to act also in their own self-defence, through private combinations, such as farmers' associations and trade unions. This the great coal operators did not see. They did not see that their property rights, which they so stoutly defended, were of the same texture as were the human rights, which they so blindly and hotly denied. They did not see that the power which they exercised of representing their stock-holders was of the same texture as the power which the union leaders demanded of representing the workmen, who had democratically elected them. They did not see that the right to use one's property as one will can be maintained only so long as it is consistent with the maintenance of certain fundamental human rights, of the rights of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, or as we may restate them in these later days, of the rights of the worker to a living wage, to reasonable hours of labour, to decent working and living conditions, to freedom of thought and speech and industrial representation - in' short to a measure of industrial democracy and, in return for his arduous toil, to a worthy and decent life according to American standards. Still another thing these business leaders did not see. They did not see that both their interests and the interests of the workers must be accommodated, and if need be, subordinated, to the fundamental permanent interests of the whole community. No man and no group of men may so exercise their rights as to deprive the nation of the things which are. necessary and vital to the common life.

speech.para: The last sentence might well be made to apply to Mi* John Brown, for coal is necessary and vital to the common life. Why should one man be allowed to paralyze an industry? The following quotation is from pages 518 and 519 of the same work - . . . we must recognise the fact that today the organization of labor into trade unions and federations is necessary, is bene.ficient. and is one of the greatest possible agencies in the attainment of a true industrial, as well as a true political democracy in the United States. This is a fact which many well-intentioned people even to-day do not understand. They do not understand that the labour problem is a human and a moral as well as an economical problem, that a fall in wages, an increase in hours, a deterioration of labour conditions mean wholesale moral as well as economic degeneration, and the needless sacrifice of human lives and human happiness, while a rise of wages, a lessening of hours, a bettering of conditions, mean an intellectual, moral and social uplift of millions of American men and women.

Honorable members on this side of the chamber stand for the bettering of conditions and the intellectual, moral and social uplifting of the people; but honorable members opposite can hardly make such a claim if they support this bill. The quotation continues -

quote.para: There are employers to-day who speak as though they were lords of these countless armies of Americans, who toil in factory, in shop, in mill and in the dark places under theearth. They fail to see that all these men have the right and the duty to combine to protect themselves and their families from want and degradation. They fail to see that the nation and the government, within the range of fair play and a just administration of the law, must inevitably sympathize with the men who are struggling for a decent life, as opposed to men, however honorable, who are fighting for larger profits and an autocratic control of big business.

speech.para: Tlie main object of the supporters of the Government seems to be to aid those who are fighting for "larger profits and an autocratic control of big business." The great majority of our workmen are law7 abiding, peaceful and honorable citizens who have done nothing to deserve the treatment which the Government is meting out to them. The final quotation that I shall make from the book begins on page 520 and reads -

quote.para: I believe that the' overwhelming majority, both of workmen and employers, are law-abiding, peaceful and honorable citizens, and I do not think that it is just to lay up the errors and wrongs of individuals to the entire group to which they belong. I also think - and this is a belief which has been borne upon me through many years of practical experience - that the trade union is growing constantly in wisdom as well as in power, and is becoming one of the most efficient agencies toward the solution of our industrial problems, the elimination of poverty and industrial disease and accidents, the lessening of unemployment, the achievement of industrial democracy, and the attainment of a larger measure of social and industrial justice.

speech.para: In his second-reading speech on the bill the Prime Minister suggested that it was necessary to discourage employees from forming big organizations; but the late President Roosevelt held quite a different view.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member suggest that the trade unions wish the Commonwealth Arbitration Court to be retained?

- I certainly do. Employers and employees alike admit that there are certain defects in the system, but these could be remedied. If this bill is passed it will bring chaos into industries that are at present being conducted harmoniously. Let us not make the mistake of throwing away the substance for the shadow.

. - So much has been said on this bill by the many speakers who have preceded me that I cannot hope to break new ground. As a humble new member, I shall not pretend that I can pour out half as much wisdom as has been released during this long debate; but it ap pears to me that honorable members opposite and even some distinguished members on this side of the chamber have indulged in many irrelevancies and inexactitudes in the course of their speeches. It has been said that this necessary reform is a deplorable and reactionary attempt on the part of the Government to force the workers of* Australia back to the sweating conditions of the dark old days. Let us strip the debate of this " sob stuff " and hysteria, and look at the subject frankly.

speech.para: The object of the bill is to remedy the overlapping and duplication of the present system of industrial control. The Government is proposing to set up what will be practically federal wages boards for interstate disputes, and to leave to the State authorities the settlement of lesser disputes. Every one who knows anything about the industrial life of Victoria i3 aware that the wages board system of that State has been remarkably successful. Its one serious defect is being corrected in the scheme laid down in this bill. As the Attorney-General eloquently explained, the judges who will be chairmen of the boards constituted under this measure will be able, if they think that any decision of a board would have the effect of exploiting the public, to refer the matter back to the board.

talk.start.para: - What would happen then ?

- I have enough confidence in human nature to believe that the defects would be remedied. The representatives who will constitute these boards will not require to talk to the gallery or the press, for the deliberations will be conducted in camera. There will, therefore, be no need for any person to try to glorify his own organization. I believe that these boards will get down to bedrock quickly and do their best for the industries in which they are in- 'terested. The system will be inexpensive compared with the Arbitration Court method.
- What does the honorable member mean by " lesser disputes " ?

- It is well known that, under the present system, a comparatively minor disagreement can be quickly manufactured into an interstate dispute. In fact, a dispute must extend to more than one State before it can come before the Commonwealth Court. That method of dealing with industrial troubles is expensive. The honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) quoted some enlightening figures with the object of showing how expensive the Commonwealth Court has been to industrial organizations. Mr. Crofts recently said that it cost something like ?30,000 a year. I think that he referred particularly to the salaries paid and to other expenditure of that sort, but the system involves almost incalculable expense that has to be borne by industry. Thus enterprise is stifled by the charges that have to be met by the employer, who at any time has a difficult task, and is not encouraged to remain in industry. The fact that the amount at fixed deposit in the banks of Australia is ?33,000,000 greater than it was two years ago shows that people have not sufficient confidence in secondary industries to invest their money in them. If any man in this chamber suddenly acquired wealth, would he invest it in a secondary industry? I think not. If Labour were sincere in its statement that it is out to help the working man, what a chance there would be to make him really interested in his industry. He could even become a shareholder in it, as is the practice in the United States of America where labour is not political, but where its chief concern is to make the men contented and industrious in their employment. How it would help Australia to progress if the Labour party could induce the members of the unions to take genuine interest in the industries from which they obtain their employment.
- What does the honorable member mean when he refers to Federal wages boards?
- I said that Federal labour boards similar to wages boards were to be established in big industries.
- There is no provision along those lines in the bill.
- I was referring to disputes that have an interstate significance.
- If that were specifically provided for, it would bring more support to the measure.

- The firm of H. V. McKay Ltd. devotes a whole department to the study of arbitration awards, and that is an overhead expense to industry. One honorable member wanted to know where that expense occurred. The cost of the salaries of the officers employed in that work is, of course, passed on to industry, and the benefits of the tariff are to that extent nullified.

speech.para: I agree with the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers), who pointed out that the economic position of the country was not all that could be desired. He said there was no certainty that wages would remain at the present level. Who could promise that they would? Wages are decided by the economic position of the country. They rise to a certain level, and ultimately they must recede.

talk.start.para: - But the Government says they will not go back.

- That could not be guaranteed; they may either go up or down. If the wealth of a country is ?5 per head of the population, it is ridiculous to assert that each inhabitant can take ?6. What is wrong with Labour's policy is that it pays no regard to economics. It desires artificial standards irrespective of whether the industries can afford them. Governments cannot do everything. Much depends upon the people themselves. As Carlyle says -

quote.para: Political reform can, indeed, root out the weeds, but it leaves the ground empty, ready either for noble fruits or for new worse tares.

speech.para: We ought to have more faith in our own country and patronise our industries. How many honorable members opposite are entirely Australian in their purchases ? That is one way in which unemployment can be reduced. If all sections pull together, we shall eventually see Australia marching to her destiny with success similar to that achieved in America. It seems to me that honorable members opposite, as federal members, fear that their sphere of influence in the Commonwealth will wane considerably if this bill is carried. So long as Labour as a party advocates nationalisation, its objection to the evacuation by the Commonwealth of the field of compulsory arbitration is understandable. They believe in the nationalisation of all the services of production and in that respect they are consistent in opposing the bill. But that they should suddenly become the champions of the Arbitration Court is rather ludicrous. As the court stands at present, it has been roundly condemned by both sides. So long as its awards were favorable to Labour, they were accepted by the unions ; but when the economic situation, resulted in awards being less favorable to the workers, they declined to accept them. When they have defied the law, have any representatives of Labour told them to go back to work? Does anybody imagine that industrial disaster will result from this very necessary reform contemplated by the Government?

Much has been said by Labour about the Ministry having no mandate for the bill. With loud voices, honorable members opposite have been keeping up their courage, and declaring they would welcome an election. I can say emphatically that I at least have a mandate. It is the result of the Balaclava by-election at which I received a large majority in every subdivision. This is the only election in the federal sphere that has been fought since the arbitration, proposals of the Government have been brought forward. Labour did not care to put up. a candidate. Although there are from 18,000 to 20,000 Labour voters in the electorate, the independent Nationalist did not succeed in polling three-fourths of the Labour votes, let alone obtain any of the votes of the independents. This action of the Government was brought well to the fore at the election. The Prime Minister explained his intentions regarding federal arbitration, and he also referred to the John Brown case. My opponent, who fought very fairly, took the opposing side in the matter of arbitration, and his speeches were almost as well reported in the press as mine were, but he obtained only about 16,000 votes. So a bigger majority was gained under these circumstances by the Ministerial candidate than at the last federal election, when so worthy and illustrious a man as the Bight Honorable W. A. Watt was returned.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable member believe what he is now saying?

- Tes. And if the honorable member for Wimmera goes to the country again, the worthy candidate who opposed him last time will run him closely, and probably beat him, because of his extraordinary attitude to the Government.
- I was not returned as a supporter of the Government.

- Of course, it is hard to predict the result of an election. The honorable member for South Sydney (Mr. E. Riley) referred to my advent to this chamber as an accident. The Balaclava figures should be an eloquent enough reply. The only accident is the presence of the honorable member for Indi (Mr. Jones) who will be one of the first of the Opposition to lose his seat. The attitude of Labour is naturally one of opposition to everything that the Government does. It will embarrass capital in any way it can. The attitude of honorable members opposite is so near the border line -
- The pupil admonishing the schoolmaster!

- The pupil has been sadly disillusioned after hearing a great man for whom he has the utmost respect - the war time Prime Minister - pour forth venom and illogically oppose the very necessary reform that the Government has introduced. He submitted his amendment as a convenient way to avoid voting with the Opposition. In the same boat is the honorable member for Wimmera, a man whose political complexion before I entered this chamber I had great difficulty in deciding. He makes most inaccurate remarks. He said that the Government put ex-soldiers on the land, and not into factories; but he must know that hundreds of them have been placed in factories through the Repatriation Department. There is yet time for his enlightenment, and for him to decide definitely to move into one political camp or the other. The attitude of the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell), whom I very much admire and revere, is to me inexplicable.
- It is courageous.

- That is so. I have never known a member on the Labour side to stand up against his own party. Perhaps the lawyer's mind sees in the proposed legislation some technicalities with which he cannot agree, and, because of legal straw-splitting, he is abandoning his party. Much has been said of the trouble that will be caused by interstate competition. Competition is essential to sound business, and competition between the States is both necessary and desirable. Indeed, there is interstate competition at the present time. We cannot have throughout this great continent the economic uniformity to which honorable members opposite attach so much importance. When the abolition of the Federal Arbitration Court makes interstate competition more active, industries will migrate to their right geographical positions. In Victoria, the engineering genius of that great soldier, Sir John Monash, is engaged in the harnessing of electricity, and if, as a result of the advantages thus created, industry in that State is stimulated, that will be to the advantage of all Australia. Similarly, if Queensland can offer exceptional facilities for other special industries it should be allowed to have them and other States similarly. If honorable members will take the trouble to investigate the industries which are peculiar to the different States, they will certainly approve of this policy. I have been surprised at the manner in which the names of great men have been dragged into this debate as champions of this, that, and the other policy. Has the House forgotten the vitriolic criticism and political crucifixion of some of those men when they first brought forward the measures for which to-day they are enthusiastically commended? Arbitration, we are told by members of the Opposition, was one of the reasons for the federation of the States. It was only one of 39 reasons for federation, and the framers of the Constitution realized that it was only an experiment, although a great ideal lay behind it. That experiment is 25 years old; and the arbitration system is now rather patched and worn. Because the Government has the courage to say that the industrial mess should be cleared up, that men should not be kept in subsidized idleness by the unions, encouraged by members of the Opposition, and that the burden of overhead costs should he lifted from industry, it is bitterly assailed by the Opposition and by some of its own supporters. If time permitted, I could show that the present federal system of regulating industry does not operate uniformly. Other speakers have pointed out that there are only twelve awards of the Arbitration Court which have a Commonwealthwide application, that more

speech.para: State than Federal awards are in existence, and that more employees are under the jurisdiction of State tribunals than are under federal jurisdiction. Many of the specious arguments that have been advanced in opposition to the bill will not bear investigation. I hope that this debate will not prove to have been merely idle talk.

The dawn is now breaking. Soon the division on the second reading of the bill will be taken, and I hope that when the measure is adopted, as it will be in spite of all efforts to frustrate it, it will mark the dawn of a new industrial era. I admire the courage of my leader and his colleagues in bringing forward this legislation. If they had not done so, they would have been recreant to their trust. I have great pleasure in supporting the second reading of the bill.

talk.start.para: . - The fine federal spirit displayed by the honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. White) has cleared away some of the mists that have been overhanging this bill. The honorable member would do away with the federal ideal and reintroduce interstate competition, border duties, and all the jealous and selfish conditions that characterized the bad old days which we had hoped were gone for ever. The honorable member was more candid than some of his colleagues and verified the suspicions of honorable members on this side of the House. Although his leader has said that wages will not be reduced as the result of this legislation, the honorable member for Balaclava says that they must be reduced.
- I did not. I said that they might go up or down.

- Under a competitive system a reduction of wages is inevitable. The honorable member religiously refrained from endeavouring to explain the merits of the bill. I sympathize with him and the other members of his party who are in the invidious position of not being able to explain the legislation they are thrusting on the people. He said that the Government has a mandate for this proposal, and in support of that contention he referred to his election for Balaclava, one of the most conservative constituencies in the Commonwealth. Would the honorable member contest the electorate of Melbourne Ports as a supporter of this legislation?
