The bill is condemned by the poverty of the arguments advanced to justify it. a The statement that the Government has a mandate for it is the height of absurdity. It is well known that the Government went to the country pledged to the system of arbitration and gave no indication that it intended to wreck an industrial jurisdiction which had been built up gradually over a period of 25 years. On the contrary the Government assured the people that the Arbitration Act was to be tightened up and that it would compel obedience to the awards of the court. The Attorney-General brought his legal knowledge to bear, and as has always happened when he has dabbled in industrial affairs, the existing arbitration system degenerated from bad to worse. The Government posed on the hustings as the champion of law and order; and if it received any mandate it was to make the industrialists obey the arbitration law. Having secured a further tenure of office, itproceeded to introduce a scheme of vindictive penalties which were put into operation against the worker immediately he offended against the arbitration law; but this legislation recoiled on the Government when it was faced with the necesssity for prosecuting one of its own friends, Mr. John Brown. He had undoubtedly committed a breach of the industrial law, and the Government had either to make a pretence of prosecuting him or withdraw the prosecution against the trade unionists. The Ministers have fallen down on their job, and this bill is a frank admission of their inability to regulate the industrial affairs of the country. We have never seen a more appalling demonstration of weakness on the part of any one. Ministers have said, in effect, "We cannot legislate industrially for the people of Australia, the job is beyond us; therefore we shall surrender it to the States ". If that is stable Government, God save Australia from a continuation of it. We are told that one reason for the abolition of the Arbitration Court is the need to remove dual control of industry. There is no dual control, because if - a Commonwealth law or award is in conflict with a law or- award of the

speech.para: State, automatically the former prevails. If the Government is so anxious to abolish overlapping, why does it not address itself to the income tax laws? They represent duplication of the worst type, but there is no proposal to abolish Commonwealth income taxation because it overlaps the State taxes. Despite what has been said to the contrary by the honorable member for Balaclava, the Commonwealth Arbitration Court has established commercial equality throughout Australia. That is the object of the federal arbitration law. We have no need for parochial vendors of stinking fish; we want a united people animated 'by a. national patriotism. The arbitration law is one means of giving effect to that ideal. The court should enable industry to find its level in all the States. It is not desirable that an industry enjoying especially favorable conditions in one State should be able to compete unfairly against similar industries in other States. The Constitution provides that there shall be no discrimination between States in respect of trade and commerce, but if the, wages in one State are reduced by 10 or 20 per cent, its industries must have an unfair advantage over all competitors. The Government said that this bill will establish one authority in industrial affairs. By no stretch of the imagination can industries throughout the Commonwealth be brought under one authority because no State, notwithstanding its sovereign rights, can. extend its jurisdiction beyond its own boundaries. As industry develops and becomes more federal in character the State courts will become powerless to interfere in any dispute of interstate extent. The States are not ready for this legislation. The Premier of Victoria, Sir William McPherson, has requested the Commonwealth Government to withhold its operation for some considerable time. He has admitted that his State has no machinery to carry on the work which the Government proposes to abandon. The Premier of New South Wales has said that he will do away with arbitration. In a work entitled, A New Province for Law and Order," the late Mr. Justice Higgins told us that it was the intention not to confine this law to any particular trade or calling, but to make it national in character. The court was intended to benefit not only the workers, but also the producers. Here is an illustration of the benefits of the Commonwealth Court. It was not until 1913 that the Carters and Drivers Union commenced to function federally. Prior to that there were several serious strikes in the carting industry, but during the last thirteen years the court has prevented disputes from developing into strikes. Where is there a more striking testimony to the benefits of the court? There are transport workers all over Australia, hut this bill makes no provision for them, nor for workers in the territories of the Commonwealth. I know that there are seven or eight federal awards which are operating in the territories of the Commonwealth. This Government proposes to wipe all of those out of existence, and does not intend to provide any machinery to take their place. A federal award has never been broken in the Northern Territory. What action does the Ministry intend to take to protect the men there? The Government, in its eagerness to do something rash, will destroy the whole edifice of arbitration, and the States are not ready to meet the situation which must inevitably arise. I propose to make a few quotations to show what was in the minds of those who were responsible for the creation of this court. Mr. W. B. S. C. Sawers, speaking in the House of Representatives on the 28th June, 1901, said -

quote.para: I have always regarded it as a misfortune that the Constitution Act did not provide that the question of conciliation and arbitration, and the regulation of wages and conditions of labour generally, should be left as matters for the sole control of the Federal Parliament.

speech.para: Those views were expressed during a speech delivered on the following motion moved by Mr. H. B. Higgins : -

quote.para: That in the opinion of this House it is expedient for the Parliament of the Commonwealth to accept (if the State Parliaments see fit to grant it, under section 51, sub-section 37 of the Constitution Act) full power to make laws for Australia as to wages, hours and conditions of labour.

speech.para: In moving that motion Mr. Higgins said -

quote.para: With freetrade between the States it will not work well to let one State have one set of laws regulating wages, hours and conditions of labour in that State, and to allow another' State to have another set of laws dealing with those subjects within its boundaries.

speech.para: Senator Drake,who was Postmaster-General at the time, said -

quote.para: I am sure we all desire that, with regard to the laws relating to wages and the hours and conditions of labour, there should be uniformity amongst all the States. We can see very clearly that it will be necessarily to the disadvantage of some State or other if there is any considerable difference in the laws governing these important subjects.

speech.para: They realized that if we were to progress as a nation we must have uniform laws, so that traders and industrialists would be placed on an equal footing. Senator Sir Josiah Symon, of South Australia, said -

quote.para: I am entirely in sympathy with the principle underlying this motion. It is exceedingly desirable in the interests of trade, and in the interests of the Commonwealth, that we should have absolute uniformity, as far as possible, where the conditions are uniform, in relation to everything that affects the material welfare of each of the States composing the Commonwealth.

speech.para: It was soon after the first Federal Parliament met that the late Mr. Justice Higgins (then Mr. H. B. Higgins), who was one of the first members, submitted the motion which I have just read providing that the Commonwealth Parliament should have full power to make laws dealing with wages, hours and conditions of labour. The procedure then proposed was that the State Parliaments should grant the power to the Commonwealth. The late Honorable A. Deakin, then Prime Minister, in a memorandum presented to Parliament on the 13th December, 1907, said -

quote.para: To restrict the powers of the Commonwealth to the mere imposition of duties, while conditions under which the manufacture of protected articles is carried on differ so widely in the different States, would ibc to permit discrimination and discord. . . . Effective and useful as State industrial laws have in many cases proved, their operation is circumscribed by State boundaries, and it can hardly be claimed for then that they either do, or can, secure uniformity in the conditions of manufacture throughout Australia. No authority but the Commonwealth Parliament can do this.

speech.para: In a further memorandum presented on the 28th October, 1908, he said -

quote.para: As the power to protect the manufacturer is national, it follows that unless the Parliament of the Commonwealth also acquires power to secure fair and reasonable conditions of employment to wage-earners, the policy of protection must remain incomplete.

speech.para: Sir EdmundBurton, speaking to the motion moved by Mr. Higgins in June, 3901, said-

quote.para: The grant of interstate freetrade, which follows the adoption of a uniform tariff, is likely in many respects to be crippled, unless the Commonwealth lias power to deal uniformly with the conditions of employment throughout Australia. The conditions of employment and the price of articles are inseparably interwoven, and these conditions and prices are also inseparable from the nature of the tariff, whether it operates externally only, or externally and internally among the States.

speech.para: Those are the words of Mr. (afterwards Sir Edmund) Barton, admittedly one of the finest of Australian statesmen. An examination of the political history of Australia will show that the best brains that we have produced have stood four-square to the conclusion that the supreme control of arbitration should be in the hands of the federal court. The Prime Minister and the Attorney-General refused to carry out the law, because of partisan administration, and they decided to jettison the whole system. As the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) has truly said, the Government has no justification for scrapping the law just because there are offences against it. If that were the case with our criminal code, our laws would be at sixes and sevens. The Government, in sacrificing the federal arbitration system has given the country additional and positive evidence of its weakness in administration. Dealing with the basic wage, the late Mr. Justice Higgins said -

quote.para: The first task I had to face was not, strictly speaking, conciliation or arbitration. The Federal Government imposed certain excise duties on agricultural implements manufactured, but it provided for the remission of the duties in the case of goods manufactured under conditions as to the remunerations of labour, which the president of the court should certify to be fair and reasonable.

speech.para: That was the spirit behind arbitration at that time. The legislators of. the Commonwealth granted concessions to employers on condition that they gave a fair living wage to their employees. It was on that basis that our arbitration court was established, and carried ou for twenty-five years. It is true that the operation of the court has not been satisfactory from all points of view. It has been unsatisfactory from an industrial point of view and particularly from the employers' point of view, but that is no justification' for scrapping our industrial legislation. Where are the legal brains and constructive ability of members sitting behind the Government, when they cannot rise to a situation like this? Cannot this legislation be amended so as to make it workable and equitable? The Government is not game to tackle the issue. The line of least resistance is to scrap this legislation in its entirety. Industrial chaos will arise from the act of the Government ; one does not need to be a prophet to foretell that. In the near future industrial disputes will be raging from one end of Australia to the other, and, with the abolition of the arbitration law, there will be no tribunals competent to handle the disputes. Honorable members behind the Government want to get back to the "good old days," the economic days. The honorable member for Martin (Mr. Graham Pratten) admitted that. They forget that wages and conditions of employment are regulated in every civilized country of the world. I believe that increased production is necessary, and that the resources of Australia should be exploited to their fullest capacity; but I do not say that they should be exploited at the expense of the workers only. What about the employer and the manufacturer? If sacrifices are to be made, the employers should bear them as well as the workers. We find, in view of a recent judgment in the coal industry, that there is no way of checking the profits of the employers. So far as I can gather, there is no law to compel the employer to disclose his profits to any tribunal in Australia. That has been shown in respect of the sugar and other industries. The case can be tested only in the court. We know that the employers water their stock to an alarming extent, but the worker cannot water his conditions; they are hard and fast. Honorable members behind the Government harp on the necessity of bringing together the parties to a dispute. But I ask them to be genuine. Let both sides come together in a spirit of trust, not by the employers holding a gun at the back of the employees, like John Brown is doing at present. He says - "Here are your conditions ; take them or leave them ; as far as I am concerned, you will never know what profits I am making." If that sort of thing continues, industrial unrest must increase from day to day. Why does not the Government introduce legislation to compel John Brown to re-open his mines, so as to prevent the coal industry from being strangled? We shall never get industrial peace if the Government continues to shirk its responsibilities by handing its powers to the States. I rose to associate myself definitely with the Opposition in its protest against the scrapping of the federal arbitration law, which has been built up as a result of a quarter of a century's hard work on the part of the best brains of Australia. I trust that good sense will prevail, and that honorable members will not pass this legislation, unless it is amended to meet the requirements of the industrial situation as it exists to-day. I hope that the bill will meet the fate that it justly deserves, particularly in view of the impetuous manner in which it was introduced by its framers.

talk.start.para: . - I do not propose to offer any apology to honorable members for speaking at this hour of the morning. It has been my misfortune to sit up the whole night to listen to the views of honorable members on the bill. Last week I also listened with attention to a number of other speakers, so that I feel that, in the closing hours of this debate, I have absorbed the essence of the discussion on arbitration. I am, therefore, somewhat pleased that it has fallen to my lot to address the House at such a late stage ot the debate, because it will enable me to speak with assurance. I trust that my remarks will not be misconstrued by honorable members, and will not be received by them in any hostile spirit. I claim the privilege which I have, as a member of the Country party, to act as I think fit in the interests of the electors whom T represent. I do not take the view of those who decline to criticize important legislation if it is sponsored by the Government. So long as I am in this House, I shall protest against anything that I think is wrong, even though my party is against me. This legislation is not an ordinary party issue. I well remember, when I was a boy, that arbitration was the subject of widespread discussion. It was part and parcel of the political and constitutional system of Australia. The decision on this important issue may affect the lives of generations of Australians.

speech.para: This bill is far above ordinary party considerations,' and the ordinary standard of party conduct should not be followed. Honorable members on this side who have sternly rebuked its critics are exceeding their duties as members of this House. Their remarks have bordered close on impertinence. The decision on this bill may affect the whole of our political life, therefore it should not be hastily arrived at. I have spent weeks on its consideration. I began with my mind opposed to the action of the Government ; but, realizing that a serious political position might arise, I decided not to say anything until I could come to close quarters with the leaders of the parties which I support, and hear their views and those of the other members of my party. At the outset I resolved that, before finally making up my mind on the bill, I "should consider the subject from all angles. This proposal is almost as important as federation itself. We must recognize that the federal arbitration system, however lightly honorable members may treat this subject, is apparently to be seriously changed in its character. It is rooted in the very economic and industrial standards of Australia, and it is doubtful whether any legislation can alter it in a day or a fortnight. I doubt whether it may ever be uprooted considering that the workers of Australia, who comprise 90 per cent, of the people of this country, have been operating under it for 27 years. I am surprised that that aspect did not receive greater consideration at the hands of honorable members on this side. I do not blame the members of the Labour party for the attitude that they have taken up, because that is their political business. The Labour party was actually the sponsors of arbitration legislation, which has played an important part in our political, industrial, and economic life. Although the members of that party have not supported compulsory arbitration during recent years to the extent they did some time ago, it is only natural when such a serious change as this is threatened that they should stand up to the principles which many of them have so strongly advocated. I listened very closely to many of the speeches delivered by honorable members opposite and their presentation of the case against the bill has influenced mc to support its second reading. I have analysed their objections to the measure and studied the printed matter prepared by exponents of a federal arbitration system. I have always been a believer in federal arbitration and will continue to be even if this measure is passed. I am satisfied, however, that the members of the Opposition entered this political contest without properly preparing their case. They have been merely on the defensive and quite unable to stand up to the arguments brought forward by the supporters of the Government.

In the first place I should like to deal with the suggestion that the Government has not received a mandate from the people to abolish federal arbitration. My view is that federal arbitration will not be abolished even if this measure becomes operative. But I was somewhat puzzled in determining the action I should take in connexion with this measure, because there is not the slightest doubt that the Prime Minister did not receive a mandate from the people at the last election to introduce legislation involving such a drastic change of policy. I have been a supporter of the Government for six and a-half years, but I cannot recall one instance during the last election campaign when it was mentioned that there was a possibility of the Arbitration Court being abolished or the Commonwealth relinquishing certain of its powers in this regard. If that had been the issue I, .as a strong advocate of the system of arbitration, particularly under federal control, would have studied the situation very closely. . I understood that the industrial policy of the Government involved the strengthening of the federal industrial system in operation at the time of the 1925 election. In these circumstances I cannot agree with my colleagues that it was even suggested to the electors that such a change would be made. The absence of a mandate from the people caused some perturbation in my mind, and I naturally asked why the Government had so suddenly decided to adopt what I regarded as a most unusual course. The telegram which the Prime Minister despatched to the members of the Nationalist and Country parties came, as the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) said, as a bolt from the blue. I fully believed that something of a very unexpected character had arisen which the right honorable gentleman could not mention in his telegraphic communication. I read in the newspapers that he had been in conference with the State Premiers in Canberra where the subject of federal arbitration had been discussed and that the Government had made an offer to practically withdraw from the field of arbitration. I did not read anything in the report of the proceedings of the conference that suggested that the State representatives had presented an ultimatum to the Commonwealth; the impression I formed was that the State Premiers were rather surprised at the right honorable gentleman's offer. It seemed to me that the State Premiers had no authority to accept the Prime Minister's offer, and they, as creatures of political circumstances, were, I suppose, in a somewhat difficult position in that they had not submitted such a proposal to their electors for their approval. It was apparent to every one that the action taken by the Government came as a surprise, not only to the Government's supporters, but to the general public.

The Prime Minister stated that expense and inconvenience were being caused by the overlapping of federal and State awards, and that if his proposals were adopted the cost of production would be reduced. The Government does not appear to have any cogent reasons for acting in this way and will eventually have to justify its action before the people. Although I do not represent an industrial constituency, I felt that I was under an obligation to protect not the interests of only the supporters of the Country party, but also a number of workers in my electorate. I refrained from speaking earlier in the debate to enable mo to ascertain the views of other honorable members and to decide whether it was possible for supporters of the Government to vote for the bill without stultifying themselves.

talk.start.para: - Did not the Prime Minister justify his action at the party meeting?
- No.
- The Leader of the Opposition cannot expect me to reveal what occurred at the party meeting.
- In giving the history of the proposal the honorable member is expressing what is in his mind ; I thought the position might have been explained to the party.

- The matter was discussed, hut no further information was given than that contained in the Prime Minister's explanation in this Chamber. After perusing the bill and following the debate I have come to the conclusion that, as the Government is staking its political existence upon this issue, it is entitled to do what it proposes without a mandate from the people. As the Government has the courage to do that I intend to support the measure and also stake my political existence upon it. If the people do not approve of the Government's action there will be a change at the next election.
- But what is going to happen after the withdrawal of certain awards ?
- If the present administration is defeated at the next election it will be easy for a new Government to re-introduce the system without great expense.
- The honorable member's statement is a condemnation of the Government's action.

- The federal arbitration machinery is not of a complex nature and the services of the present arbitration judges, who have' been appointed for life, will he available should the system be re-introduced.
- The reconstitution of the court is a minor difficulty, what of the destruction caused by the withdrawal of awards?

- At present 143 awards, covering about 400,000 workers, are registered in the court, and *7e have been informed by the Attorney-General that only twelve of these awards are essentially federal in character.
- Only twelve are operating in all the States; but there are others which are essentially federal.
- Existing awards are to remain in operation until the 30th June, 1930, and I believe that that period should be extended.
- Indefinitely?

- No. The Government, which has staked its existence upon this issue, has to take the responsibility and cannot back and fill without discrediting itself and allowing its opporents to say that it has made an impetuous gesture. Assuming that the date provided in the bill is adhered to, it would still be competent for the State Governments, if they so desired, to renew essential awards for a longer period. I admit the possibility that certain States may not do that. But we have been told by the State Premiers, who have shouldered the responsibility, that they are prepared to provide machinery to take over the federal awards in the easiest and most expeditious fashion.
- Does the honorable member think that we shall be able to throw our responsibility upon the States in that manner?

- The States have assumed that responsibility ; even Western Australia, which is at present governed by a Labour Ministry. There is an additional responsibility cast upon honorable members on this side in regard to this bill. I personally am in favour of the federal arbitration system, but the majority of this party are solidly against me. The State Governments and this Government must stand or fall on the issue. If this Parliament runs its full term it will be quite a simple thing for the Commonwealth to inform the States that it proposes again to exercise the powers which it is now relinquishing. It must be remembered that no constitutional change is involved. I favour a constitutional change. I fought for that in 1926 as strenuously as any honorable member in the House, and I am prepared to fight for it again if the Government gives me the opportunity. But for various reasons the Government does not propose to afford that opportunity. The Commonwealth, is not surrendering its power to carry on arbitration, and that is to me the greatest weakness about the proposed change. It may really be only a temporary expedient, and the people who are now under the impression that a great and permanent change is being effected that will dispense with duplication will probably receive the shock of their lives in the near future. That aspect of the matter has not been properly impressed upon the public, and especially upon the employers, who are taking a rather haphazard view of the future. They are under the impression that this is to be a permanent change, but there is no guarantee that it will be permanent. That is the risk they are taking, and it is "their funeral."

speech.para: There are 400,000 employees working under federal awards, and it is a very serious thing for a parliament to withdraw them from federal jurisdiction when they do not desire that withdrawal. Here again the Government has assumed responsibility for the action and has advanced its reasons, the principal reason advanced being that the change will prevent duplication. No evidence has been forthcoming from either side of the House that this change will lower the cost of production. Many honorable members are fond of using catch phrases which would sound very well, but which, when analysed, mean very little. It was stated by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and many honorable members on this side that 90 per cent, of the reason for this change is the desire to avoid duplication. Are the facts as to duplication so serious that they justify this great change? I listened very attentively to the debate and I have heard nothing to indicate to me how that duplication can be injurious to the country. Even the controllers of industry who favour the change have not advanced any proof that duplication exists to such an extent that the action of the Government in surrendering 95 per cent of its federal powers is justified. I do not, like the honorable member for Balaclava (Mr. White) and others, claim to be a captain of industry. However, I have seen various phases of industry operating under both federal and State awards. My limited knowledge may have led me to a wrong conclusion, but I have not seen any evidence of duplication of awards to suggest that dual control exercises a disastrous influence on industry, and warrants this drastic change. I have been closely associated with the great news paper industry of Australia, which for fifteen years has worked satisfactorily under the federal arbitration jurisdiction, and I assure honorable members that the results have been revolutionary. I -personally have enjoyed the benefits that have accrued, and many present day journalists, who in their youth toiled for little recompense, have also enjoyed those benefits. I trust that when the bill is in committee the Attorney-General will take care that the great bene fits conferred on that industry by federal arbitration will not be sacrificed, and that honorable members will take the greatest care to see that nothing slips through the committee stage by oversight. The profession of a journalist has been converted from practical slavery, with little recompense, to one of decency, competency, and fair pay. I believe that to be the opinion of 99 per cent, of the journalists of Australia.

There is another point that has not been stressed in this debate. When we talk about overhead costs, and the necessity to reduce the cost of production, we do not sufficiently consider the waste in industry caused by incompetent employees. Journalism affords an instance. Before its members came under the Federal Arbitration Court the industry was overloaded with derelicts; boozers who would work for a couple of days for a few shillings, and then go on the drunk for a fortnight. Those men were really not fitted for the task of moulding the public opinion of the country. Even on the big city dailies the conditions were anything but good, and some of our finest journalists of today eked out a very precarious livelihood in those earlier times. All that has changed, and now many bright lads enter the profession because it affords an adequately remunerated livelihood. I shall deal only briefly with the theatrical industry. If its employees are to be jeopardized by this measure the Government is in duty bound to see that the industry remains under federal jurisdiction.

talk.start.para: - How can that be done?
- We shall sec in committee. I am confident that the Goernment will safeguard the interests of those concerned.

speech.para: The speeches of honorable members opposite having failed to convince me, I have decided to give the Government the benefit of the doubt. The one outstanding instance of disobedience to federal arbitration is that of the timber workers' strike. But it not fair to assume from that isolated case that federal arbitration has failed. That individual case does not constitute a justification for the Government to withdraw its benefits from every other industry that has worked loyally under the federal system, particularly as duplication has not been proved. "We have had no evidence as to the influence of duplication upon industry.

talk.start.para: - What about the Sunshine Harvester Company?
- I have heard that somebody connected with that firm died worth ?2,000,000 so the effect of the duplication could not have been too serious.
- It resulted in increasing the cost of implements.

- The farmers consider the implements well worth the cost. Too many of the employers of Australia are ignoring the need for greater efficiency in their business. Individuals may be making efforts to achieve efficiency, but the employers as a class are doing nothing in this direction. Distinguished visitors from overseas have pointed this out, and even the Prime Minister has said that the employers must get out of the habit of using old plant and inefficient methods. The Minister for Customs advocated the formation of business mergers in order to increase efficiency. I am sorry that honorable members on the other side have not, during the course of this debate, laid greater stress upon the need for efficiency in business. If the employers think they will get any benefit out of this measure, and apparently they do, the duty devolves upon them as well as on the employees to assist in reducing production costs by cutting down overhead charges.

speech.para: The case of the Opposition breaks down when it comes to deal with the timber workers' dispute. It is not my place to preach to the Opposition. They know their own business, but there is no doubt that honorable members opposite have given their approval to the timber strike, which has been one of the most prolonged and brutal in the history of industrial dis turbances in Australia. In Sydney, at all events, it is led by a gang of men who anywhere else would be taken by the scruff of the neck and sent packing. The strikers have been encouraged to come out in their thousands with sharpened sticks - javelins in fact, -

talk.start.para: - The honorable member is commenting upon a matter which is sub judice. 'Men have been committed for trial on charges arising out of the things he is discussing.

- If that is so, I shall not discuss it any further. I may say, however, without prejudice to any impending legal proceedings, that the results of this dispute have been most disastrous, and I am convinced that it is the real cause of this legislation being before us at the present time. We have also to consider the attitude of the Australian Workers Union, that great industrial organization which everyone living in the country must respect, and which has some very fine men connected with it. This organization has been leading the fight against the present bill, but it has not succeeded in making out its case. In Queensland where it has had the assistance of a friendly government for fourteen years it has experimented with State arbitration without giving the Federal system a chance.
- Well, that is quite fair.
- Yes, hut it furnishes a bad argument for the Australian Workers Union in its present fight against, the Government's proposals.

- Surely the honorable member will admit that if the Australian Workers Union could- be assured of securing as effective State arbitration courts throughout the Commonwealth as that functioning in Queensland it would not be so gravely concerned about the prospective abolition of federal arbitration. In South Australia and Tasmania however, it has little chance of securing anything of the kind.
- The journalists have State awards as well as their federal award.

- No, the calling is covered entirely by the federal award, except in Queensland. It seems to me that Queensland - the naughty boy amongst the States - is really the root cause of the present attack on federal arbitration.
- "We have higher wages in Queensland than in some of the other States.

- The wage has been prescribed under the authority of a Labour government. "When Labour governments are established in the other States I have no doubt that they will sweep away the various industrial tribunals which previous governments established. In New South Wales, for instance, a Labour government would probably constitute an arbitration court which would control industry in a manner objectionable to the majority of the employers. That is another risk that employers are running in supporting this measure, but that, of course, is the employer's own funeral. No doubt the employees will benefit in the long run under State control of industry as they have done in Queensland. In view of that, I cannot understand why the Labour party is sp strongly opposed to this bill. If the people of Australia do not like, the system which it is now proposed to set up, a future Labour government will have an opportunity of altering it. Even the Sydney Morning Herald, in yesterday's issue, had this to say -

quote.para: No change whatever in the constitutional position is to he brought about. The people as Commonwealth electors will possess the power to rectify any mistake which by majority they think has been made. If they are dissatisfied when next they are appealed to they will give warrant for a complete re-entry of the vacated field. Manifestly they would do so by showing confidence in the Labour party, the policy of which provides for a change in industrial arbitration methods so drastic that the cleared ground would be an aid rather than a hindrance to its plans.

speech.para: Thus, by not submitting this question for decision at a referendum, we are possibly involving the employers and controllers of industry in greater risks than they themselves are aware. I- do not feel any sympathy with them because they themselves have endorsed the proposal. They had every opportunity for months past to study the question, and make their protests to the Government. Therefore, unless their objection has been suppressed by the newspapers, it is evident that the great majority of the employers, and associations of employers, favour the proposal.

talk.start.para: - The employers endorsed it because they think wages will come down.

- That may be so, but it has not been proved, during the course of this debate, that wages will come down as a result of the passage of the bill. On the other hand, it has been shown that in those States in which Federal Arbitration Court awards have not been accepted, wages are higher than elsewhere. This applies in the case of the pastoral award in New South Wales, and also in that of Queensland.
- The employers expect that wages will come down.

- The answer is that the employers may be making the mistake of their lives. That, however, is their own affair ; they are not fools. The honorable member for Balaclava is, T think, an employer, and he is no fool, though he expresses himself as satisfied with this proposal. If it does not work out right he will have to suffer with the others. I have a shrewd suspicion that when Labour governments get back into power in the various States the employers will again seek to have their industries brought under federal jurisdiction.

speech.para: It is, however, with the constitutional aspect of the matter that I am most concerned. I am convinced that the Government, even without the mandate given to it at the last election, would be justified in dealing with this issue, because it is staking its existence, and that of its supporters, upon it. There remains, however, the great constitutional question as to whether the Commonwealth is to be greater or lesser than the States. I have always been a constitutionalist as honorable members know. I have played a leading part in the new state movement, which I am still hopeful will become an important issue before Parliament. If I thought that the passage of this bill would result in preventing the. report of the Royal Commission on the Constitution being considered in this House with a view to constitutional amendments being decided upon, I would have no hesitation in voting against it. I am confident, however, that that will not be the result. I am confident that the appointment of this commission which has been sitting for two years, and which has cost the country ?17,000, was a bona fide effort on the part of the Government to learn what constitutional alterations it is necessary to effect.

talk.start.para: - The commission should not be the authority to determine what alterations ought to be made.

- I agree, and it will not be called upon to make that decision. This Parliament will be the final authority, but the commission will advise Parliament of the results of its investigations. and if Parliament does not approve of the recommendations it will not submit them to the people for endorsement. I do not think that the matter is of vital importance at this stage, because some future 'Parliament can always alter what is being done now if it does not meet with the wishes of the people. In 1926 we asked the people to approve, by referendum, of the proposal to widen the industrial powers of the Commonwealth, and honorable members on both sides of the House enthusiastically supported, the proposal. There was not a man on the Opposition side who did not throw up his hat and say that it was the very thing which he had always wanted, yet the proposal was not agreed to. Last year we asked the people to agree to an amendment of the Constitution enabling the Commonwealth to enter into financial agreements with the States. The necessary power was given, showing that if we are united we can get the people to agree to any necessary constitutional amendment. The trouble in 1926 was that the executives controlling the Labour movements in the States opposed the proposal for granting wider industrial powers to the Commonwealth. The honorable member for Dalley (Mr. Theodore), now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, was one of those whose influence helped greatly to bring about the defeat of the proposal.
- In what way?
- The honorable member stood for the supremacy of State rights.
- The honorable member is not justified in saying that.
- The honorable member for Dalley was leading the campaign against the proposal.
- The Treasurer (Dr. Earle Page) said that I was campaign director for the " Noes," but I can assure the honorable member that I took no part in the referendum campaign.
- It is fair to say that the honorable member advised the electors to vote " No."
- The honorable member is not justified in saying that. At that time I took no part in the referendum proposals; I issued no statement, and .1 made no speech.
- Did not the honorable member express an opinion for the guidance of the public?
- No. Many other statements made in relation to my attitude towards the referendum were also untrue.

- I must accept the assurance of the honorable member; but I am sorry that it has taken him so long to clear the matter up. For three years I have been under the impression that we had Mr. Lang and Mr. Theodore to thank for the defeat of the referendum proposals. Every State "righter and State politician was opposed to them. But the chief reason for the failure of the proposals was that the Government did not have its heart in the campaign. Many of the electors did not hear one address in favour of its,, proposals. Yet, in spite of the opposition of Mr. Lang, they were accepted by the people of New South "Wales and Queensland. Many honorable members on the other side who at first supported the proposal took no active part in the campaign." With the exception of a few "diehards," whom I prefer to call heroes, honorable members opposite rendered little or no assistance. If to-day honorable members opposite could guarantee that the whole strength of the Labour movement would be behind a further appeal to the people to alter the Constitution in order to give the Commonwealth control of industrial affairs, I should vote for another referendum; and I should be prepared to accept the consequences.
- If the honorable member will study the Labour party's platform, he will see where it stands in the matter.

- The honorable member forgets that what he says in this House carries no weight whatever with labour organizations outside. In 1926 every member of the House professed to be in favour of the proposals; but the people rejected them, largely because many who offered to help were missing when the guns were fired. I hope to have an opportunity of raising this question again in the near future. If the Labour party could give an assurance that Labour organizations throughout the Commonwealth would actively engage in a non-party fight for complete Commonwealth powers, as they did iu connexion with the financial issue, many honorable members on this side would be prepared to stake their political lives in order to give the Commonwealth absolute control of industrial conditions in Australia.

.- I may be permitted to say to honorable members opposite " Greeting." They have come back to the chamber like giants refreshed after a good night's rest. They are looking brighter than I feel after having followed closely the debate which has lasted for over 40 hours.

speech.para: Never in my political history, extending over twelve years, have I been so agitated in my mind as to what I should do, as I have been in relation to the question now before us. Nor have I ever previously been so inundated with representations from various sources and advice from people who are desirous of directing my footsteps along the right path. During the last week or two, there have been within the precincts of this House a number of gentlemen who have felt it their duty to come to Canberra to endeavour to keep the feet of honorable members in the straight and narrow way. Some of them desired to interview me. I felt it to be my duty not only to meet them, but also to hear what they had to say and to read what they offered me to read. I felt that on an important question, such as that now confronting us, every man should acquaint himself with the facts. I desired to get information from both sides so that I could cast an intelligent vote. For about one and a quarter hours the discussion lasted. As a result of that interview I am more firmly convinced than ever that the action I proposed at first to take was the right one, and that if I followed their lead I should land myself and the country in a state of chaos, which I need hardly say I have no desire to do. The effect of arbitration on industry has been fully debated by members on both sides of the chamber. I can recall no other measure concerning which so many diverse opinions have been expressed. Some honorable members opposite have very little regard for the men whom they term capitalists. "We have had evidence of that even this morning in references made to an elector in my district - a man- who has rendered signal service to the people of this country, but, because in doing so he is said to have amassed a fortune, he is ridiculed and described as an employer who at all times desired to get all he could out of his employees and to give them as little as possible in return. During the last weekend I made it my business to visit the large manufacturng establishment to which I have referred. I asked for some statistics in regard to wages paid and prices charged, which were readily furnished and can be verified. The honorable member for "Wimmera (Mr. Stewart) has often expressed the opinion that the prices charged for agricultural implements are extortionate when compared with pre-war prices.

talk.start.para: - Yet he buys them.

- He buys them because they are the best obtainable. The figures which have been placed in my hands show that between 1914 and June, 1927, there was an increase of 113 per cent, in the wages paid to the employees in that establishment. During the same period the cost of the raw material handled in that factory increased by 78 per cent., while the average cost of the product of the factory increased by 37 per cent. A careful examination of those figures will show that this industry has been of incalculable benefit to the people of Australia. Not only has the man on the land benefited from the establshment of the Sunshine Harvester Works, but the men employed there have also derived benefits.
- Does the honorable member want to reduce their wages?

- No ; I do not advocate the reduction of wages. I believe that the cost of production can be lowered by means other than the reduction of wages or the lengthening of working hours. If we can get men engaged in industry to take an interest in their work as the men at Sunshine are doing, the results will be beneficial to both manufacturers and employees. A better understanding between employer and employee would mean cheaper production. I have visited the Sunshine Harvester Works on many occasions. The men who are engaged on piece-work there have told me that in no circumstances would they willingly revert to the old system of day labour. They know the advantages of piece-work. The more work they do the more they receive in return. The aim of men in every walk of life is to get as much as they can; but they should also give fair value for what they receive.

-I ask honorable members to cease interjections. During the night honorable members who spoke were given a fair hearing. I ask honorable members to preserve the same dignity in the proceedings of the House now. At this late stage in the sitting I do not desire to name any honorable member.

- I am glad that honorable members opposite are awake and are taking an interest in what I am saying. Anyman who has delved in the earth for a living has a great deal of respect for the reasonable claims that workers may make upon an employer. Honorable members opposite appear to imagine that they are the only ones who have had to work hard; but some honorable members on this side of the chamber could give them a little information about what real work is like.
- Does the honorable member suggest that the workers of Australia are going slow?

- There are good and bad workers just as there are good and bad employers. I should not like honorable members opposite to have to work for some employers for whom I have had to work. It must be patent to everybody that more cannot be taken out of industry than is put into it. But some people in this country seem to think that if they can bring about the downfall of capitalism and industry as we know it, they will be able to usher in the millennium. That is far from the truth. As honorable members know, there are many textile workers in my constituency. The representa tives of these workers waited upon me a fortnight ago to place before me their views upon this bill. In the course of our discussion I learned that the textile workers very rarely submit a plaint to the Arbitration Court. They meet their employers in conference, reach an agreement, and use the arbitration machinery merely to ratify their joint decision. That system could be adopted in very many other industries with great advantage to the nation. But unfortunately there are some persons in the community who batten upon industrial trouble. They are never happy unless they are stirring up strife. If these individuals are allowed a free hand, the nation will never become prosperous. We must solve the problems which industry is at present encountering and the best way to do it is to bring the parties closer together. Between 2,000 and 3,000 men and women are employed at the Sunshine harvester works and they are able, through the representative of each shop meeting the management regularly in conference, to rectify practically all the troubles that occur there. From time to time friction is felt but the cause of the trouble is always remedied before a dispute of any magnitude occurs. It will be found that generally men who are given a fair spin . act fairly. On the other hand, those who are subjected to unfair treatment are not particular about the means they adopt to get their own back.

speech.para: A little earlier in this debate the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers)' gave us some information upon the subject of soldier settlement. He said that the position should be inquired into at the earliest possible date. I agree with him. Thousands of our ex-service men are in a precarious position. Many of them do not know where they will get their next bag of flour. If we can do anything to help them we should do it. A reduction in the cost of the plant that they require on their holdings would mean a big thing for them. The honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers) made an earnest appeal for a return to sane conditions - an appeal that should not fall upon deaf ears.

The honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) has made several similar appeals in relation to the coal-mining industry. He is a new member of this Parliament but he has impressed us all by his earnestness. I have read his speeches over and over again, and have marvelled that such conditions as he has outlined could exist in Australia.
Mr.Fenton. - The conditions have been caused partly by Mr. John Brown locking out his men.

talk.start.para: - Mr. John Brown does not control the 54 collieries that the honorable member for Newcastle referred to in one of his speeches. The honorable member in the speech I have in mind declared that the highest average weekly wage earned on the coal-fields over a certain period was ?3 8s. 3d. and the lowest average weekly wage for the same period was ?1 12s.1d. No one would think of suggesting that ?38s. 3d. is anything like a living wage for a man. The wages are low, because there are many more thousand workers on the coal-field than the output warrants. In the boom years thousands of men went to work there, but we are now exporting far less coal per annum than we did in 1915.
- The coal-fields are operated by the piece-work system.
- That is not the trouble. These men cannot be paid the basic wage under existing conditions. In recent years we have lost more than half of our export trade in coal.
- Will the passing of this bill assist us to regain it?

- The honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) has expressed fears that some of the trade may never be regained. My object in drawing attention to this situation is to show that the industry cannot be continued under existing conditions. No government can bolster up an industry indefinitely. I deplore the fact that men are working on the bread-line, but I am surprised that they are content to stay round the pit's mouth under the present conditions. Other men leave their homes in search of employment.
- Many of them have done that; but it is impossible for the majority of them to leave their homes, into which they have sunk the savings of a lifetime.

- I realize that there are difficulties in their way ; but, if they cannot obtain work near their homes at a remunerative rate, would it not be better for them to seek it elsewhere ? Of course, the prospect of their obtaining employment in these times is anything but bright. I have referred to an interview I had with representatives of industrial organizations recently, and I have also obtained a good deal of interesting information that I intend to place on record. It comes from sources that are considered by honorable members opposite to be reliable - from members of the Australian Labour party. This is what Mr. Jock Garden thinks of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court -

quote.para: There is no member of the working class whol ikes to "down " tools. There is some fundamental cause operating in industry which makes him rise in revolt, and we want to get on to that basic thing, which causes this unrest. I have analysed the position for the last five years, and I say that all large disputes have been occasioned by thebeliberations of the Arbitration Court. It is no use shutting our eyes to the facts. I could enumerate case after case - where judges who have no knowledge at all of industry, have given awards that have created friction where there should have been no friction at all. The employers will use every means in order to obtain a victory. Both sides will do so. I do not blame the employers any more than I blame ourselves. We do exactly the same thing as they do, but if we were to meet around the table regarding matters as to which there was likely to be a dispute, no disputes would take place.

speech.para: He advocates conciliation rather than the present arbitration system. Mr. D. J. Davies, Vice-President of the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, in New South Wales, states -

quote.para: Regarding the arbitration machinery, the miners all along have been opposed to compulsory arbitration, but they have from time to time adopted voluntary methods of arbitration in the shape of conciliation courts, and probably they have changed their ideas and systems more than any other industry in this country. They have had conciliation boards, the State arbitration court, boards presided over by Judge Edmonds and established under the War Precautions Act, and, lastly, the coal tribunal; but they have all along refrained from utilizing the system of arbitration which has been applied to other industries. The miners have always had a dislike for the legal fraternity entering into discussions on Industrial questions in regard to which they know practically nothing, and in regard to which they introduce legal technicalities and legal interpretations of the law. The cost to our union for arbitration has been nothing compared with the cost entailed by other unions, yet the mining industry probably is one of the most intricate to govern, and one which is more prone to industrial unrest than any other. What do we find with arbitration? We find that a judge goes on to the bench after being legally trained, and comes to a decision after weighing the evidence presented. He is hardly in a position to help the litigants to come together, as he listens to barristers and lawyers whose interests depend on making the case last as long as possible by creating as much matter as possible to fight over. We must get away from that method.

speech.para: Mr. H.C. Gibson, a prominent trade unionist, was President of the Melbourne Trades Hall Council when he made the following statement as to the desirability of peace in industry -

quote.para: It might be time well spent if 1 took a few moments to delve into some of the causes, because when all is said and done, the question arises what is cause, and what is effect? In some quarters our arbitration registration has been blamed for the present situation, and in that connection I want to make a confession, although it may appear strange coming from me. I am inclined to the view that arbitration legislation has been a contributing factor to the problem. I say that as an arbitrationist of twenty-one years standing. I was brought up to look upon the British Judiciary as something which, like Cesar's wife, is above suspicion. After twenty-one years I have come to the conclusion that judges, like the rest of us, are human. They have no superlative attributes, and eases have been brought under my notice where something more than bias has been indulged in. Self-interest has entered into the matter. Where lias the twenty-one years' experience of the arbitration system led us? It has placed the parties in industry in opposite camps: that is undisputed. It had a tendency not by its phraseology, but by its administration, to push them further apart. It might be asked what evidence we have of that. Take the organization that I primarily represent in the industrial world of the Commonwealth. About the middle of 1914 my organization had registered, under our Commonwealth Arbitration Act, 037 agreements, mutually arrived at round the table, which bound the members of my organization on the one hand, and 037 employers on the other hand, to observe certain rates, and certain conditions of labour. To-day we have not 30. Now that is not because we have not tried in the meantime. Our efforts have been more concentrated in the last three years in an effort to bring about agreements, because our common sense has proved to us that if we can get the parties to agree, and get an agreement drawn up in black and white, and signed, it is more likely to be bided by, than anything which is enforced by an independent third party. But we have failed, and I place the responsibility for failure primarily at the door of the Arbitration Court, and the present Arbitration Court system.

speech.para: I have another quotation from a leading trade unionist, whose name has been mentioned freely in the discussion on the bill. I refer to Mr. E. J. Holloway, late secretary to the Melbourne Trades Hall Council. He declares -

quote.para: When the Arbitration Act came into existence, conditions all round were improved, the status of the workers became better, industry was placed on its feet, and every one profited, but, like the things I have started to talk about in the first place, the changing methods of doing the work of the world, the increase in organization, and the more perfect organization, matters have reached such a stage in connection with arbitration that new machinery is necessary to meet the changes. That is the only difference. The Arbitration Act has served its day and generation. It did remarkably good work; it saved the situation so far as Australian industry was concerned. It has now become cumbersome, costly, and clumsy, until to-day it is not such a useful machine. I will not suggest that it could not be made useful. If the act had been amended by experts, or if a conference like this could have made it fit for the requirements of the day. instead of leaving it where it was when introduced 27 years ago, things might have been different. It should be quite possible to make the Arbitration Act a useful, simple, smoothworking, modern machine, to cope with modern requirements. I have always favoured some really flexible modern machinery as simple as possible. The administration, the duty of experts only, could be quickly changed from time to time to meet changing circumstances. My final word is that if we can evolve some easy, simple machinery, which can be quickly assembled to handle potential disputes, before stoppages take place, without any long-drawn arguments, it would be something worth while. I have in mind some sort of machinery necessitating perfect organization, discipline, and authority on both sides, so that everybody the employers' side represents, and everybody we represent, would obey its decisions. If we could erect some machinery of that kind, very useful work could be done. The reason the industrial legislation of this country has failed is because of its slow, cumbersome, expensive, and unsympathetic methods caused by ignorance. With Mr. Crofts and others I have waded through cases in the Arbitration Court lasting three and four months on end. As laymen we have to put up arguments and statistics, and all kinds of information against King's Counsels drawing 30 and 40 guineas a day. We have been anxious to get a decision, because of the unrest amongst the people we represent, people who have been clamouring for two or three years to get a decision in regard to the matters presented to the court; but the gentlemen on the other side quite naturally have made the case last as long as possible.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 8 a.m. to 9.S0 a.m. (Saturday).

talk.start.para: - Mr. T. C. Howard, secretary of the Adelaide Trades and Labour Council, said -

quote.para: I have followed the trend of arbitration ever since the days of Charles Cameron Kingston, who created the first wages board in South Australia. I consider that the present arbitration system has served its purpose, and I quite agree with Mr. Holloway in that regard. There is room for improvement, and we ought to get down to the fundamental basis of the arbitration system, and to see what improvements can be effected. Personally, I think a board should be created on the lines which exist in South Australia, where representatives of employers and employees sit together, with an independent chairman, or, if necessary, a judge appointed byboth sides in the industry. Those are matters which have to be considered. That board would be charged with the duty of scheduling industry, not on the lines of the courts, but on the lines of industry. I know that the opinion on the other side of the table is to have conciliation boards of a voluntary character, but we on this side of the House have a lot to contend with in that regard.

speech.para: I quote those leaders of the Labour movement because they should know something of the subject upon which they are speaking. Situated as I am, I cannot do better than be guided by the views of men who have had extensive experience of the difficulties which confront unions in trying to get decisions from the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. During this debate a good deal has been said about the flouting of the court and deliberate breaches of the industrial law. A serious aspect of the timber workers' strike was that a large number of federal unions were assisting the strike by compelling their members to pay levies and other contributions to make its continuance possible. That strike, the waterside workers' strike, was against an award of the Federal Arbitration Court, and I ask those unionists who believe in the principle of arbitration to consider the full significance of their action. The result of it must be to discredit the principle of arbitration and to imperil the existence of the federal arbitration system. For the information of honorable members I place on record this list of unions which have been voluntarily or compulsorily contributing to the timber workers' strike fund -

quote.para: Australasian Council of Trade Unions, Iron Workers, Liquor Trades, Tramway, Amalgamated Road Transport, Boilermakers, Australian Engineers, Moulders, Sheet Metal Workers, Amalgamated Printing Trades, Stovemakers, Federated Engine-drivers, Municipal Employees, Tobacco Workers, Rubber Workers,

speech.para: Shop Assistants, Australian Meat Industry, Amalgamated Carpenters, Builders' Labourers, Shipwrights, Storemen and Packers, Bricklayers, Water and Sewerage Union, Brick and Tile and Pottery, Bottle Blowers, United Labourers, Wire Workers, Timber Workers, Gas Employees, Textile Workers, Building Trades, Hospital Employees, Ship Painters and Dockers, * Australian Railway Union, " Wool and Basil Workers, Saddlers, Stonemasons, Operative Painters, Wicker Workers, Gramophone Record Workers, Blacksmiths, Bedstead Makers, Fire Brigades, Shop Assistants, Bridge and Wharf Carpenters, Hairdressers, Bakers, Clothing Trades, Undertakers, Amalgamated Postal Workers, Electrical Trades, Food Preserving, Breadcarters, Boilermakers' Assistants, Sugar Workers, Carters and Drivers, Coachbuilders, Stovemakers, Australian Workers Union, Manufacturing Grocers Union, Merchant Service Guild.

Those unions must represent thousands of members, who, willingly or unwillingly, are contributing towards the support of men who are violating the law of the land. Can honorable members of the Opposition justify such an action ? Do they consider it in the best interests of Australia that the law should be openly flouted in this way? I invite them to answer that question.

talk.start.para: . - I am fully convinced of the wisdom of the proposal that the Commonwealth shall retire from the field of industrial arbitration. I am an ardent supporter of the principle of Commonwealth control, and because the arbitration system is of such importance to the hopes and aspirations of our people, we cannot view lightly any proposed change. For many years it has been apparent that certain agencies have been militating against the success of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. It has not failed, but adverse influences have made it impossible for its full value to be reaped by the community. Unfortunately, it is impossible to overcome those difficulties by amending the law, because on several occasions the people have, by referendum, refused to the Commonwealth the additional powers that are necessary to enable the court to function effectively and enforce its awards. That lack of power would operate against the success of any system of conciliation and arbitration. If and when the States accept full responsibility for industrial jurisdiction, their courts will be confronted with the same troubles as the federal court has experienced. Honorable members opposite will admit that, and the reason is that there is in our midst a section of people who are determined to prevent, by any and every means, peace in industry, and will go to any lengths to break down a system that would ensure to workers in industry an adequate return. It is not that these bodies do not wish the workers to enjoy higher wages, but they are determined to effect a change in the social order by abolishing the capitalistic system of private ownership. It is their belief that there can be no peace in industry until the workers own the fields, the factories, and the workshops, and they openly confess that they will do all in their power to prevent the possibility of pea co between the employer and the worker. Unfortunately, they have the backing of the political Labour party, to which the support of the industrial unions is essential for political purposes. This debate has emphasized the fact that the Labour party is not very much concerned with the value which the worker is to get for his labour under any system of conciliation or arbitration; its members are determined to follow the lead given by the revolutionary elements. They have lived and thrived on the false assumption that all other sections are opposed to the desires of the workers. This bill is evidence that the Government wishes to do its utmost to bring about peace in industry, and ensure the observance of the conditions that some tribunal may prescribe. The people in Queensland voted strongly in favour of the Commonwealth having full powers in the industrial field. They realize that the present state of affairs cannot continue, and that they are suffering because of the industrial chaos that reigns. It is evident that some alteration is necessary, and I support this bill, because it would be impossible to secure from the people, even by another referendum, the powers which the Commonwealth needs.
- "Why does the Government stone-wall this bill ?

- Had the honorable gentleman been leader of the Government the " gag " would have been applied long ago. I speak from experience in another sphere. 'Desirous of terminating the present unsatisfactory position, the Prime Minister met in conference the Premiers of the States, and suggested that all the power necessary for a successful arbitration system should be referred by the State Parliaments to the Commonwealth Parliament. "With one exception, the Premiers flatly refused to grant that power. So jealous were they of the rights of the States that the Prime Minister realized that it would be futile to consult the people by another referendum. The Premiers accepted full responsibility for the regulation of industry by arbitration or conciliation within their own boundaries. Another referendum would probably be no more satisfactory than the last one. Even the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore), while asking that another referendum should be taken, carefully refrained from stating whether he would support the appeal to the people. He said that his attitude would depend upon what powers were to be sought by the Commonwealth. In other words, whatever form the application for increased powers might take, the honorable member would find some excuse for opposing it. It is clear, therefore, that the powers that are essential for the effective regulation of industry throughout Australia could not be vested in the Commonwealth Parliament by either the people or the State Parliaments. The control of industrial affairs by the State authorities will bring about greater competition. This might operate against the best interests of a section of the community, were it not that the Government proposes to set up a tribunal which will have power to co-ordinate the determinations in the various States, and so bring about some degree of uniformity. If that be realized, we shall have gone a long way towards securing that control of industry which has been denied to the federal authority by referendum, because the various State tribunals will have an opportunity to enforce their determinations. We know that it will be necessary for them to enforce them. Honorable members opposite have stated that there will not be a cessation of industrial trouble. We are aware of that. There never will be so long as .we have in Australia a certain section that is determined to break down any system of arbitration that may be in operation, and prevent employers and employees from working peaceably together.

speech.para: The administration of the Labour party iu both the State and Commonwealth spheres has not been such that we can look to that party to improve the condition of our industries or increase the value of production. So long as the members of that section do not offend the industrialists they are content. Their ob,ject is to foster turmoil so that they may pose as the friends and supporters of the workers. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore) is a supporter of industrial arbitration, if we can judge by his actions while Premier of Queensland and his expressions of opinion on the hustings. Before he entered this Parliament he always claimed that the awards of the Arbitration Court should be obeyed and must be upheld. It would appear, however, that in the last couple of years he has departed from that principle and is prepared to speak and act at the behest of the extreme section of the industrialists.

The Government proposes a change in method, not- in principle. We shall still have arbitration courts, and no obstacle will be placed in the way of conciliation. Those honorable members who sit on this side support the principle of having one authority to deal with industrial affairs. We are justified in permitting the States to operate, seeing that full powers have been denied to the Commonwealth. In Queensland the Commonwealth Arbitration Court has been the subject of much unfair political criticism. Whenever there is industrial turmoil there is a disposition to blame that court; yet only 26 of the 141 federal awards operate in that State. The pastoral employees' organization has written to members of this Parliament protesting against this proposal; yet during the last election it feared that its members in Queensland were to be brought under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Court and that they would thereby be detrimentally affected. I quote the following from the Longreach Leader of the 30th August, 1929-

quote.para: During the last Federal and the more recent State election campaigns, the Labour party in Queensland in particular visualized attacks on the -workers' wages and conditions if candidates with their brand on were not elected. Did they not submit propaganda to the electors in the electorates interested in the pastoral industry that station hands' wages would be reduced by 15s. 4d. per week if the Bruce-Page party were returned to power, and proportionate reductions to shearers and shed hands by bringing the industry under the ambit of the federal court? And, during the State campaign the same propaganda was disseminated.

speech.para: The Australian Workers Union asked its members to support the Labour party and thus obviate the possibility of their being brought under an award of the federal court. This journal further states -

quote.para: In the federal campaign the Australian Workers Union Secretary, Mr. W. J. Riordan, who was defeated by Mr. Grosvenor Francis for Kennedy, was the originator of the 15s. 4d. per week reduction bogey.

speech.para: An honorable member of this House, who has spoken against this proposal of the Government, was to some extent responsible for that bogey, because at the time he was president of the Australian Workers Union'. The articles goes on to say-

quote.para: Perhaps Mr. Martens in his inconsistency may conveniently forget that at the time he was State president of the same organization.

speech.para: I could give further examples of abuse of the federal court by labour organizations and attempts to prevent the spread of its influence in the hope that ultimately it would be abolished. If honorable members will consult the files of labour journals prior to the announcement that the Government proposed to retire from the industrial field they will find that those journals were enthusiastic in their determination to upset the court and its awards. It is not so long ago that the effigy of a judge of the Arbitration Court was burnt in Sydney and insulting references were made to the court with the idea of destroying the respect which the people held for it and creating turmoil. If the powers that were sought by the Government in 1926 had been granted action could have been taken to prevent much of the turmoil that has since existed.

This is an honest effort by the Government to improve the conditions of the people of Australia, not only industrially but in every other direction. Until there is peace in industry we shall not have an adequate return from either' employers or employees. The Government desires that the worker shall receive the full return for his labour and that a better relationship shall exist between him and his employer. The following is an extract from an article published in the Trade and Production Supplement of Australian Goal, Shipping, Steel and the Harbour -

quote.para: The Trades Union Conference held in Melbourne has decided on a "campaign of resistance" to the proposals of the Federal Government to curtail the power of the Federal Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. A long string of resolutions beginning with "a" and ending with "j" were passed by the conference. The A.C.T.U. "are out to resist the Government proposals." The A.C.T.U. are champion "resisters." The A.C.T.U. resisted the election of the Bruce Government, they resisted the passage of the Arbitration Bill, they resisted the personnel of the court, they resisted the awards made by the court, and now they are resisting the limiting power of the court which they say is rotten.

talk.start.para: - Honorable members on this side finished hours ago ; why this stone-walling.

- I understand that the debate does not conclude until the right honorable the Prime Minister has replied. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore) is always restless when reference is made to the Australasian Council of Trade Unions. The honorable member was once regarded as a person who adhered to the principles which he strongly advocated ; but since he has been a representative of New South "Wales in this Parliament, he has been in close association with the extremists, and the lofty ideals which he once cherished have sunk into oblivion. When the honorable member came to the State in which he was once so favorably known, to assist in an election campaign, he found to his disappointment that those whom he once regarded as his friends were not willing even to listen to him on a public platform. The Australasian Council of Trade Unions which has opposed the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, which it says is rotten, seems to be the controlling influence in the Labour party which bows to its behests irrespective of the welfare of the people which it is supposed to represent.
