I confidently assert that the vast majority of the electors of Queensland - a State possessing enormous potential wealth - will welcome this proposal as they are confident that it will be the means of improving the industrial conditions existing not only in Queensland, but in every State. Under the present system the Arbitration Court is being used in a way that was never intended, and under a State system of arbitration as outlined by the Prime Minister there is every prospect of the industrial situation improving. I make no apology for supporting this measure, because I believe it will be the means of ending much of the industrial turmoil that now exists. It will be of inestimable benefit to the primary producers who under the present system have been handicapped in the marketing of their produce by frequent and unnecessary disputes on the waterfront. With more stable conditions in industry, a larger amount of capital will be available for investment, and it should not be long before every section of the community will feel the benefit of the Arbitration system which the Government has decided to introduce.

.In addressing myself to the subject of arbitration which is agitating the minds of practically every person in Australia who takes an interest in this country's progress, I shall endeavour to keep my mind free from bias and from using any expressions likely to increase ill-feeling, which, unfortunately, is so prevalent in our industrial life. I was impressed with the remarks of the honorable member for Richmond (Mr. R. Green) who quoted some very interesting figures showing how the votes in certain electorates were recorded on the. referendum submitted to the people in 1926. I took the trouble to obtain the figures for the district of Angas, and found that on the question of granting increased industrial powers to the Commonwealth the electors turned down the proposal by 29,764 votes to 11,545 votes. In placing these figures against those recorded at the last federal election it will be seen that about 5,500 electors who voted for the Labour candidate must have also voted against granting additional powers to the Commonwealth. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore) endeavoured to show that we are experiencing a period of industrial peace ; but unfortunately the Opposition team work was not altogether satisfactory, as the honorable member for Newcastle (Mr. Watkins), who has been a member of the Federal Parliament continuously since its inception and who is a most earnest representative of labour, said that there was more industrial turmoil in Australia to-day than ever before, If that is so, the Commonwealth Arbitration. Court, which has been extolled as the means of preventing industrial unrest, cannot have been the success which honorable members opposite suggest.

speech.para: I listened with interest when the right honorable member forNorth Sydney (Mr. Hughes) was speaking on the bill now before the House. The right honorable gentleman is regarded with admiration and respect for the wonderful service he performed in the nation's interests during the Great War; but, unfortunately, a good deal of his speech on the bill consisted of personal abuse. His best friends must admit that he has not forgotten what occurred several years ago, when, after outliving his usefulness, he was superseded by the present Prime Minister. During his speech he referred to the fact that the Prime Minister had been the leader of the Government for over six years, when I interjected, " That is the trouble." The right honorable gentleman reminds me of a small boy who is not a good loser, playing marbles for "keeps," and who when he is losing goes to a corner of the playground and sulks. The right honorable member should not forget that, with his undoubted ability, he is still able to render great service to his country, but he will never be able to do so while he continues to ventilate petty personal grievances. I remind the right honorable member of the biblical phrase, " I had rather be a doorkeeper in the house of my God than dwell in the tents of wickedness ". In this connexion I am also reminded of these words in the 3rd chapter of St. James, verse 6 -

quote.para: And the tongue is a fire, a world of iniquity: so is the tongue among, our members that it defileth the whole body and setteth on fire the course of nature; and it is set on fire of hell.

speech.para: He also introduced into his speech a limerick concerning the young lady of Riga. The right honorable gentleman reminds me of the nursery rhyme which runs -

quote.para: Humpty dumpty sat on a wall,
Humpty dumpty had a great fall;
All the king's horses and all the king's men
Could not put humpty dumpty together again.

speech.para: There were a few references in the right honorable gentleman's speech to the subject-matter of the bill to which I should like to briefly refer. He went to great pains to support the Federal Arbitration Court, and to show that the Government should not relinquish the powers which it is at present exercising. Yet, in speaking on the Crimes Bill on the 10th February, 1926, the right honorable gentleman said -

quote.para: This is the national Parliament of Australia. We have been given a mandate to deal with industrial turmoil, to use our utmost endeavours to insure industrial peace. But when all is said and done, we have to make the humiliating confession that we have not the power to deal effectively with this great question. We cannot make an industrial law; we cannot make a law relating to corporations, or trusts, or combines; we cannot deal with the matter directly, or get to close grips with it. These industrial disputes arise out of the conflicting interests between organized labour and organized capital. We have no power whatever to deal with organized labour directly. We cannot make a law relating to labour and industry. We cannot make a law dealing with corporations as they ought to be dealt with. We have no power over organized labour, nor organized capital. We cannot make a law securing uniform hours of labour throughout this country, and at this juncture nothing is more necessary than just such a law. In New South Wales there is a law prescribing a 44- hours' working week, but its operation is confined to the territory of that State. In Victoria and in the other States the working week is one of 48 hours. This difference will create endless difficulties, and will be most prolific of those very disputes that we are trying to prevent. We should be able to pass an industrial law to secure uniformity of labour conditions and to clothe the arbitration court with power to make a common rule. We have no such power.

speech.para: The statement continues -

quote.para: By this bill we shall be able to deal only with some kinds of transport, and not with all kinds. We cannot deal, for instance, with a strike on State railways.

speech.para: The right honorable gentleman went on to say -

quote.para: The people sent us here to do something. And as things are we can do nothing effective. We are now at the beginning of a new Parliament. The Government, returned by an overwhelming majority, has a mandate if any Goernment ever had, to go to the root of this matter. But we can only play with it unless we amend the Constitution, and give this national Government the power to deal with these things which every other Government has. We talk about dealing with industrial questions, and I do not care what measures the Government introduces its power is so limited that its choice of methods is not very wide.

When industrial unrest arises out of a dispute between organized labour and organized capital, whether corporation, combine or trust, we have no power to deal with either party. A Parliament so constituted is national only in name.

speech.para: It might be claimed that the right honorable gentleman slipped a bit that day, and did not realize what he was saying. To disprove that, I shall quote what he said when speaking on the Constitutional Alteration (Industries and Commerce) Bill on the 3rd of June, 1927. My extract is to be found at page 2595 of Hansard, volume 113, and it reads -

quote.para: The situation imposes upon us the solemn duty of looking at these proposals most carefully, in order that the Parliament may be lifted out of its present humiliating position. As things are now, it can deal with neither labour nor capital. It cannot legislate to control any union or any company in this country. It cannot protect a union, nor can it prosecute one. It cannot even make a uniform company law.

speech.para: And then he repeated what he had said on the second reading of the Crimes Bill, which I have already read.. That being so, what are we to think of the right honorable gentleman, when he now contends that the federal authority should handle industrial problems? Four different referendums have been taken, asking the people if they were prepared to extend the powers of the Commonwealth Government, and in each case the verdict was in the negative. To. win a referendum it is necessary to obtain a majority of the electors and a two-thirds majority of the States. At present Western Australia, Tasmania, and South Australia are very, hard hit as a result of federation, and, although Western Australia and Tasmania are receiving grants, and South Australia is claiming a grant from this Parliament because of the disabilities' under which they are suffering, they are not prepared to clothe this Parliament with any additional powers. If a referendum were held to-morrow it is probable that the result would be a greater majority than the last against handing over further power to the Commonwealth Government.

Honorable members opposite have had a real good innings at the expense of the State Parliaments. They claim that this Government is throwing the workers to the wolves. Apparently their assump tion is that when John Jones is a federal elector he is an angel, but when he is a State elector he is a wolf. With the exception of Queensland, which for political purposes stands aloof and at each election reproduces its 30,000 electoral "ghosts," the States of the Commonwealth and the Federal Government have joint electoral rolls. Apparently, honorable members opposite think that when those whose names are on these rolls are voting as federal electors all is well, but if it is a State election the same electors, according to honorable members- opposite, are wolves. From this it must be concluded that the persons whom the wolves elect to the State Parliament are super-wolves. It is a great, reflection upon our British parliamentary institutions to contend that the six State Parliaments are nothing but the dens of vicious wolves. In all the States there are hundreds of thousands of electors who are members of unions. I suppose that, on the reasoning of honorable members opposite, they, too, are wolves.

Now I have a very high regard for the honorable member for South Sydney (Mr. E. Riley). He is an old industrialist who has spent a lifetime in the service of the workers of the country : a man who is obviously sincere in his opinions. This is what he had to say at page 1053 of Hansard, volume 113, on the 19th February, 1926, when dealing with the Crimes Bill-

quote.para: I remember when Mr. B. R. Wise, the Attorney-General of a Liberal administration in New South Wales, introduced the first arbitration legislation passed by an Australian Parliament. As a result of that legislation there were no strikes in New South Wales for some time. But that legislation was entirely different from the existing arbitration legislation of the Commonwealth, and for that reason strikes are now more frequent than they were then. Under the legislation of New South Wales, to which I have referred, the employers and the employees had direct representation on the bench. Their representatives appointed a chairman. That was real arbitration.

speech.para: I have no doubt that the honorable member still holds that opinion.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member was referring to industrial machinery that was in operation about 21 years ago.

- The honorable member is unable to explain the metamorphosis that has taken place. I shall now direct my attention to what the Australasian Council of Trade Unions has to say on this subject. This statement cannot be too frequently repeated. Everybody who . reads the newspapers will remember that until the proposal of the Commonwealth Government to relinquish federal arbitration was put before the Premiers' Conference, there had been bitter and vile attacks in the press upon the federal arbitration system. The workers had been instructed by their " misleaders " to resist the award of the Federal Arbitration Court, and it is interesting to find the following statement in the Pan-Pacific Worker on the 2nd April, 1928:-

quote.para: It is impossible to estimate the moral harm which has been done to the Australian working class by its hasty and ill-considered acceptance of arbitration as the solution of Labour's problems.

The vehement opinions of the Pan-Pacific Worker were endorsed by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions, which passed a resolution on 15th May, 1928, expressing full satisfaction with the character and tone of the publication.

speech.para: On the 14th July, 1927, the Council of the Australian Railways Union passed a resolution declaring that " the perpetuation of arbitration is to the detriment of the organized workers of the Commonwealth, and the Australian Railways Union in particular." A second resolution called for collective action on the part of the working class in opposition to what it called the "chloroforming effects of arbitration courts." Those resolutions were again affirmed in May last.

talk.start.para: - By whom?
- By the same people.
- No such resolution has been endorsed by the Australian Railways Union.
- I am giving honorable members the facts.
- They are not facts. They do not represent the opinions of the Australian Railways Union.

- Now that the Government has brought down this measure, no doubt partly influenced by the expressed desires of the Australian Railways Union, labour organizations and honorable members are turning a political somer sault. The following is from a report published in the Sydney Morning Herald on the 11th February of this year : -

quote.para: As a means of resisting future awards of the Arbitration Court which may determine upon, the 48-hour week being worked in other industries, the conference of unions convened by the Australasian Council of Trade Unions decided, on Saturday,9th February, 1929, to institute a boycott against the court. The following resolution was passed: - "Thatall unions nowbefore the Federal Arbitration Court be urged not to proceed with their claims or to appear before the court officially."

speech.para: Arbitration at that time was supposed to have outlived its usefulness; it should be cut out; unionists should have nothing more to do with it. Now the Government proposes to do the very thing the unions were then asking and the unions are opposing it. Why? For the simple reason that it is being done by this Government. If the union leaders express themselves as being in favour of the Government's proposal it would be tantamount to admitting that somebody other than themselves was able to take an interest in the " poor unfortunate workman." That is why, in 1926, although the proposal for wider Commonwealth power was supported by every member in this House, with the exception of two, when it was discussed here, the Labour organizations outside opposed it when it was submitted to the people at the referendum, and during the campaign itself Opposition members were mostly either silent or took the negative side.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Theodore) took part in a meeting in the Sydney Town Hall on the 18th February, 1929, in support of the timber workers' strike. Consider what it means that a member of our National Parliament, sworn te give true allegiance to the King, should take an active part in a meeting in support of the timber workers' strike. As a lawmaker of this country the honorable member is expected to support the laws. An award of the Arbitration Court is made under the law, and if members of Parliament break that law how can we hope that it will be respected by any one else. When a minister of religion of any sect whatever breaks the moral law, it gives greater scandal in the community than when a layman does the same thing, and his action reflects upon the dignity and prestige of his religious organization. In this case the Deputy Leader deliberately "went to a meeting and supported the breaking of the law by the timber workers. He is reported to have spoken as follows: -

quote.para: That the timber worker had been singled out as the first group in a general onslaught on the wages and conditions of the Australian workers. It was not a mere accidental outcome of a casual consideration by the Arbitration Court, but part of a well-devised scheme on behalf of the employers of the Commonwealth, acting in conjunction with the Government of Australia and the Governments of the States.

speech.para: He says that he is a believer in arbitration, yet he urged the timber workers to break an award made by the Arbitration Court. He added that he had no belief in arbitration as it was perverted by the Bruce-Page Government. What did he mean by that? Mr. Bruce was not on the Arbitration Court bench. The timber workers were not striking against an award made by the Government, not even against one made by that wicked man, Mr. Latham. It was an award of the Arbitration Court. Mr. Theodore proceeded -

quote.para: I agree heartily with the action taken by the timber workers of Australia in resisting this attempt on their conditions. I am a believer in arbitration, and so is the Labour party - of whose platform it is a plank - but not arbitration as it is perverted by the Bruce Government.

speech.para: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was not content with inciting unionists to disobey the awards of the court, but he cast reflections upon the court itself. His statement continues-

talk.start.para: -The honorable member is not in order in quoting passages which reflect upon the court.
- I am voicing my protest against that criticism.
- Nevertheless, the honorable member must not quote such passages because that would result in the inclusion in Hansard of matter reflecting on the court.
- I am glad, Mr. Speaker, that you allowed me sufficient latitude to voice my indignation against such statements. Mr. Theodore concluded his remarks with the following words : -

quote.para: It is not arbitration as it has been administered by the prejudiced court, which makes crimes of those claims that are only the workers' due.

speech.para: The honorable member for Dalley is very much a slave of the wild element of the Labour movement. At one time he was opposed to that element, but since he came south he seems to have been disciplined by it.

I propose to show why the federal attempt to control industrial matters has not been so effective as we may reasonably expect the efforts of the States to be when they take up the work. I shall also show how costs of production may be reduced, and how industry may avoid the present waste of effort involved in the administration of industrial awards. The existing conflict between State and Federal control of industry is tersely summed up in the following statement of Dr. Hewittson President of the South Australian Industrial Court, in the following words : -

quote.para: There are two Commonwealth awards operating in the same field as the (State) determination. The resulting' complications arc chaotic. If it were desired to design such a situation it might be conceived by the disordered mental efforts of a commission of lunatics. Not only are there two living wage rates arrived at by different methods and different authorities - the very basis of the two jurisdictions also differ. The State Industrial Board regulates the whole industry as scheduled. Some of the employees in the industry are members of one general union, some of another or others.

Each union may go to the Commonwealth court and get an award on classifications and on rates which conflict with the determination rates, if not with each other. These incongruous regulations are intruded into the industrial machinery of the board, machinery which has been adjusted to work in co-ordination and unison with the local industrial scheme. The consequences arc the very opposite of those intended or desired. There is confusion, harassment and unrest, instead of industrial order and peace. The mischief is intensified when men in the same nominal classification or doing the same kind of labour, work sometimes side by side for different rates of pay.

speech.para: Dealing with the inconvenience and expense caused to parties appearing before the Federal Arbitration Court, Dr. Jethro Brown, who was then President of the South Australian Industrial Court, said thirteen years ago -

quote.para: As proceedings in the federal court have been conducted in the past, great inconvenience anil expense have been caused to the parties.

As a general rule, compulsory conferences (which precede the formal litigation) are held in Melbourne. The formal proceedings are also generally opened there, and as much as possible of the formal hearing conducted there. Where New South Wales' interests are involved in cases, it is customary for the court to sit there after proceedings in Melbourne are completed. The court then sometimes sits in other places, though the tendency of the court has been to avoid this wherever possible. This mode of procedure has proved very inconvenient and expensive to South Australian parties. Apart from the actual time spent in attendance at the hearing, proceedings are seldom continuous, and time is wasted in awaiting a resumption of the hearing, and in travelling to and from the place of hearing. This applies not only to the advocates for parties, but also to the parties themselves who must be in attendance to instruct their advocate us well as to give formal evidence.

speech.para: Under this system high salaried officers and representatives of the workers in an industry have to leave the job and often waste time for long periods in the capital city of another State waiting for their case to come before the court. The managing heads of industrial units, instead of concentrating on the job of making a better article for a lower price, have to spend their time arguing cases before "the court, and all this adds to the cost of production. The artificial creation of disputes has been one of the most disastrous developments of the federal arbitration system. It was characterized by Mr. Justice Griffith as " a fraud on the Constitution." The practice of creating industrial disputes by the service of logs of claims, and the refusal of those claims by employers, has been held by the High Court to be legal. Yet no one has ever pretended that it was within the comtemplation of those in whose minds the Constitution had its birth. Nor Was it held to be legal without a spirited opposition from Sir Samuel Griffith who protested that " mere mischief makers cannot by the expenditure of a few shillings in paper, ink and postage stamps, create such a dispute." Dr. Jethro Brown, an ex-President of the Industrial' Court of South Australia said : -

quote.para: By the irony of fate, this sub-section of the Commonwealth Constitution which was designed to prevent, and if possible, settle, industrial disputes of an interstate character, has been the means of increasing them.

speech.para: One of the greatest difficulties of our federal awards is that the right atmosphere cannot be created in a court sitting at a great distance from the seat of the dispute. State courts, because of their knowledge of the local conditions, would be in a much better position to deal effectively with disputes, because they would be guided by first hand knowledge, and would not have to call so much formal evidence. Climatic, geographical, and geophysical conditions are so diverse in Australia, and economic conditions and social customs so different in various localities, that no federal tribunal can hope so to frame its awards that justice will be done to all who must obey them.

Last Christmas time I visited Western Australia, where I could not but feel that although I was in Australia, the atmosphere was entirely different from that of the eastern States. The people there did not know their fellow citizens of the other portions of Australia as those citizens know one another. The long stretch of railway separating Western Australia from the eastern States makes that State different from the rest of Australia. The aspirations of its people are different; their fiscal views are different; even the political Labour party in Western Australia holds entirely different views from those held by the Federal Labour party. The Labour Premier of Western Australia, Mr. Collier, welcomed with open arms the suggestion that the State should take over the control of its industrial affairs. If honorable members have any doubt as to the opinion in Western Australia about industrial matters, I advise them to visit that State during its centenary celebrations, and learn for themselves the feeling there. What we want in industrial affairs is less politics, less angling for votes, less looking to a next election.

I am proud of the Prime Minister and those members supporting him in connexion with this bill because of the criticism to which they have been subjected. What has been the chief argument of those who have endeavoured to persuade honorable members to oppose this measure? They have said, in effect, " we have so many hundreds, or thousands, of members in our unions. If you vote for this bill, you will go out at the next election." That is equivalent to saying " Do not do what you think is right; but think of the next election." Far too often political considerations have overridden the best interests of the country. I may be wrong, but I hold the view that if members' political actions were always to be guided by thoughts of the next election, it would be better to close the doors of Parliament. I am reminded of the story of the candidate for political honors who after having delivered an address to the electors, said. "Ladies and gentlemen, those are my views; if you do not like them tell me what you want me to say, and I will amend my views to suit your desires." That is entirely wrong. The attitude of a candidate for Parliament should be rather - "Electors, those are my views, my honest convictions. I may be wrong, but though the heavens fall, though you throw me into utter darkness, I would rather go down fighting and holding those views, than prostitute myself by suiting my views to your desires."

There would be more peace in industry if it were not for men known as organizers, but who in reality are disorganizes. In the Melbourne Herald of the 2nd September, 1929, the following paragraph appeared under the heading. " Company news ; profit-sharing results."
Mr. F.R. Burley, chairman of Berlei Ltd., stated at the company's annual mooting that the profit-sharing system adopted in 1915 continues to show excellent results.

The employees now hold more than 60,000 profit-sharing certificates, on which dividends are paid as often as shareholders receive dividends on their shares. The mutual confidence and goodwill thus established have produced more than mere paid service in true co-operation and the highest esprit de corps, with the result that they could safely challenge any agitator or extremist to create trouble between the management and the staff.

That company is not alone in its experience, for Wunderlich Limited has the same system in operation. Those companies are agitator-proof; and when the State tribunals, these " get together " committees, have been set up, there will be greater peace in industry and more profit for the workers. One of the reasons for the opposition of this measure is that there will be fewer jobs to let when peace in industry has been attained. The agitator will then have to do some work. Instead of compulsory arbitration, we want more co-operation, more profitsharing, more friendship in industry. We must get away from the idea that the boss and the worker are natural enemies. Employers and employees must be brought to understand one another better and to realize that, just as in a tug-of-war team work is essential, so it is essential in industry. If the captain is not supported by his men, it is useless to continue the game. There would be greater prosperity, and life would be much more worth living, if the pin-pricking which exists in industry to-day were to cease. A little more of the milk of human kindness in our dealings one with the other, a little more harmony and good will among those engaged in industry would usher in a new and better industrial era. Only by such means can the interests of the Commonwealth be advanced.

talk.start.para: . - I should not have risen were it not that the subject of this debate has also been the subject of an inquiry by a Royal Commission. Fortunately, that inquiry has ended. The Commission's report has been signed, although it has not yet been presented to His Excellency the Governor-General. In view of my connexion with that Royal Commission, I thought it inadvisable to take any part in this debate. My views on arbitration are outlined in the report. I do not, however, desire that the debate shall terminate without explaining the reason for my nonparticipation in it.

. - I should have appreciated an opportunity to take part in this debate some 45 hours ago; but at this stage of the sitting I have very little to say. I wish definitely to register my approval of the bill. Some honorable members have said that the announcement of the Prime Minister that the Government intended to evacuate the field of industrial arbitration came to them like a bolt from the blue. It did not affect me in that way. I had realized for some time, as had also many of my constituents, that the people generally were becoming very tired of arbitration. The action of several important trade unions in definitely rejecting the awards of the court has seriously impaired the faith of the people in the system. We all hoped when the Attorney-General introduced the last amendment to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act that the law would be tightened up in such a way that effective action could be taken against those who disobeyed the law. But our hopes were doomed to disappointment. These organizations and individuals still defy the court. Consequently, I was not greatly surprised when I received the telegram from the Prime Minister. I believe, that thousands of people will appreciate the action of the Government. I shall vote for the bill.

.I have no intention of delivering a long speech. I congratulate the Government upon having introduced the bill. My opinions on the subject with which it deals are too well known to the House to need reiteration now. The honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Rodgers) and myself put our position quite clearly to honorable members three years ago when we found ourselves standing against every other honorable member. I am glad that, at last, the Government has realized the necessity of giving the States complete control of their own domestic legislation. The honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) remarked that the darkest hour was always just before the dawn. I hope that we are now passing through the darkest hour of our industrial history. With the passage of this measure I trust that we shall forget the spirit of enmity and antagonism which at present exists in the field of industry, and that the people of Australia will come to realize the necessity of producing more wealth if they wish to enjoy substantial prosperity. This is one of the best moves that the Government has yet made, and I hope that it will mark the end of the wretched political interference with the industries of the country. Like the honorable member for Barker (Mr. M. Cameron) I shall vote for the second reading of the bill. If the proposed amendment of the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) is moved I shall vote against it.

talker.role: Prime Minister and Minister for External Affairs
talker.name: BRUCE, Stanley
Mr BRUCE

talk.start.para: . - This measure has been exhaustively debated, and everything that could be said against the proposals of the Government must surely have been said. Some honorable members have complained that they waited in vain to hear from me any reasons for supporting the bill. I may reply that I have waited in vain to hear any substantial reasons why the measure should not be supported. The few reasons that have been repeated so often in the debate have not changed my opinion that the measure is a wise one, and will be of the greatest possible benefit to Australia.. It is remarkable that so few reasons could be urged against the Government's proposals. Most of the speeches in opposition to the bill followed the same lines, no new adverse argument having been advanced since early in the discussion. I shall, therefore, have no difficulty in showing that there is no substance in the criticism to which the bill has been subjected, and that the arguments on which the criticism was based are weak in the extreme.

speech.para: I shall not deal at any length with the insinuation of some honorable members that the Government was actuated by improper motives in introducing the bill. That insinuation is much to be regretted, for it has lowered the tone of one of the most important debates that has occurred in this House.

talk.start.para: - That is the right honorable gentleman's attitude in every debate whenever he is opposed.

- Unfortunately it has to be so, because of the honorable gentleman's methods. I am certain that this insinuation will carry no weight either in this Parliament or in the country. Many may believe the arbitration policy of the Government to be unwise, but few will dream of attributing the introduction of the bill to improper- motives, and those who do will have been misled by untrue statements as to the object and intention of the Government respecting arbitration.

speech.para: The most sinister suggestions, the most poisonous and offensive charges, were made by the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes). It is a tragedy that a gentleman who held the high and honorable position of Prime Minister of this country for so many years should descend to the methods that he adopted the other night. His insinuations, and, in fact, most of his speech were directed against myself. He said that the measure had been brought down to save me, and that I could no longer pose as one who would administer the laws impartially. He declared that the withdrawal of the John Brown prosecution was the genesis of the hill and the explanation of its introduction.

If honorable members will consider what those charges amount to, they will realize how degrading it was for the right honorable member to have made them. The implication was that I have introduced a measure in which I do not believe, and which will be of no benefit to the country, simply to try to save my own political life.

talk.start.para: - Good gracious ! Who would suggest a thing like that?

- One would not expect the honorable member for Dalley (Mr. Theodore) to understand that any one should act from honorable motives. His whole record shows that an attitude of responsibility, and appreciation of the decencies of life, would never appeal to him. I have felt it necessary to refer to these charges because the people should understand the depths to which some politicians can descend in a party controversy of this kind. Such an attitude towards a measure which is of vital importance to the whole Commonwealth is almost tragic.

speech.para: There are few other points in the remarks of the right honorable member for North Sydney to which I wish to refer. His speech must have caused considerable disappointment to every member of the House; it certainly did to me. I am always prepared to honour an opponent, and I entered the chamber when the right honorable member rose to speak in the expectation of hearing from him an address of the brilliancy of which he is capable, a keen analysis of the Government's proposals, and some helpful contribution to the debate. But he did not give us anything of the kind. The right honorable gentleman seems, unfortunately, to have developed a considerable dislike to myself, and this clouded his whole speech, with the result that his contribution to the debate was valueless. Of course, he said some delightful things. He gave full rein to his feelings in his allusions to myself. There was his reference to me as a dilettante in politics, and the picture he drew of me springing from stunt to stunt. This must have been particularly amusing to those who remember the right honorable gentleman's own path in poli tics. There was little else in his speech to which I shall allude.

A point much stressed by the opponents of the bill was that if it became law the workers of this country would lose an institution which, in the past, had safeguarded them from exploitation and injustice, and had made possible the standard of living of which we all are proud. There is no justification for that objection. All that the bill does is to end the dual control of industry by abolishing the Federal Arbitration Court, and leaving to the States the regulation of their own industries, which is not a new thing. The States will again have complete control of their own industrial affairs, and the worker, and the honorable and decent employer, will therefore still enjoy protection against unfair treatment and the competition of unscrupulous rivals. There will still be the regulation of wages, factories acts, workmen's compensation acts, and all the protective legislation that has gradually brought about the industrial system that we now enjoy. Yet the right honorable gentleman from North Sydney - I quote him to show the exaggeration in which he indulged - said that the withdrawal of the Commonwealth from the field of arbitration will mean that the workers will return to the " economic desolation " from which the federal court now protects them. Could any statement be more ridiculous, when all that will happen is that dual control will cease, and industrial regulation will be left to the State authorities subject to the legislation of the State Parliaments, whose electors are the very same persons who return members to the Commonwealth Parliament? There is no justification whatever for saying that the bill will take from the workers the industrial protection which they have enjoyed in the past. We know that, to a great extent, this statement is made for a political purpose, to influence the workers against the measure; but the people of this country are far too intelligent to he misled by such gross and palpable misrepresentation.

Possibly the outstanding contention, and that on which most stress was laid, was that the Government had no mandate from the people for this proposed legislation. In introducing the bill, I dealt with that aspect of the case, and declined to accept the view that we have no mandate. I have listened carefully to all the arguments advanced during the debate, and I have not heard any that supports the contention.

talk.start.para: - That is an exaggeration.
- The Prime Minister is entitled to put his views before the House without interruption.
- He is not putting them correctly. The Prime Minister will be reported in Hansard as saying that he listened to all the arguments advanced.
- The honorable member is out of order. The Prime Minister must be permitted to exercise his right of reply to the debate.
- I rise to a point of order. The Prime Minister stated that he had listened to the whole debate, when, as a matter of fact, he has heard only a portion of it.

- The Prime Minister has not committed any breach of the Standing Orders. Freedom of speech is the most sacred of the privileges a member enjoys, and the Prime Minister must be allowed to make his speech in his own way. Of course, if a member thinks himself misrepresented, he may, at the proper time, make a personal explanation; but he must not, by interjecting, interfere with the Prime Minister in putting his argument before the House.
- The Prime Minister has made a statement that does not conform with the facts.
- There is no point of order.

- I venture to suggest that the Government has the clearest mandate that could be given by the people for the course it is pursuing. At two elections - in 1925 and in 1928 - we told the electors that we would take every step in our power to try to improve industrial relations in this country and to bring harmony between employers and employees. We said that we would do whatever appeared to be necessary to achieve that object. Those statements created the atmosphere in which those two elections were fought. The Government has done what it has considered wise to bring about these things. The right honorable member for North Sydney said that the Government's action affronted his sense of decency; that we have been recreant to our trust; that we have betrayed the people; and that election pledges mean nothing to us. But in 1926 we took a referendum which the right honorable member supported, though rather mildly. Speaking on the 16th August, 1926, at the Chatswood Town Hall, he said -

quote.para: Although, in his own opinion, some of Mr. Bruce's proposals went too far, he was going to vote for it, [the referendum] because Mr. Bruce went to the country and got a strong mandate to take measures to ensure industrial peace. The man who gets such a mandate should be supported.

speech.para: The right honorable gentleman has, from time to time, referred to the fact that our whole procedure has been that of constantly appealing to the people for increased powers to deal with the industrial situation. But according to the speech from which I have quoted, he was of opinion, in 1926, that we had got a "strong mandate to take measures to ensure industrial peace," and were entitled to exercise it. We are exercising it now by the introduction of this bill.

talk.start.para: - The Prime Minister has no mandate to hand arbitration power over to somebody else.

- The suggestion behind the statement that we have no mandate is that the people had no knowledge that we even considered the scrapping of federal arbitration. Yet, before the last election, I made a definite statement in Perth, which, as it has been quoted in the debate, I need not now repeat. I made the definite statement that unless awards were obeyed it would be impossible to continue the system of compulsory federal arbitration. Then in my policy speech I indicated that we would take any measures that we considered necessary to achieve our object. The Attorney-General, in introducing an amending arbitration 'bill in the last Parliament said that the act, and the continuance of federal arbitration were dependent on a realisation on both sides that there must be obedience to awards. The people of this country knew perfectly well that that was the position - that the Government was not prepared to continue the present system unless the awards of the Arbitration Court were obeyed.

speech.para: Throughout the last election campaign, I went to almost every corner of this continent, and dealt with this matter at length. I told the people that arbitration was an experiment, and that unless awards were obeyed, it would be impossible to continue the system, as to do so in such circumstances would bring the law into contempt, and if that happened the whole basis of our civilisation would be undermined. Unquestionably, the people were told, time and again, that that was the attitude of the Government. Furthermore, the election was fought on the understanding that the Government would take every step in its power to improve industrial conditions, and to bring about better relations between employers and their employees. Therefore, the people did give the Government a mandate to take whatever steps it considered would help to bring about industrial peace. We are now moving in that direction,- and we accept full responsibility for our proposals. ,

The speech of the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Maxwell) must have confirmed us all in the opinion that he is a great advocate; but I do not think he impressed the House with his ability as a logician, because the honorable gentleman's argument was not logical, and I shall mention one or two statements in which the absence of logic was most apparent.

talk.start.para: - This is hitting below the belt.

- Honorable members opposite appear to have misunderstood what I said. I have cast no reflection on the honour and integrity of the honorable member for Fawkner, and I should have thought that it would be unnecessary to say that of one who is so well known to the House. In a brilliant speech he expressed what he believed, and he will vote, I am sure, in accordance with his conscientious conviction. Nevertheless, I affirm that his argument was false and illogical. He went so far as to say that, no matter how meritorious our proposals or how far-reaching their good, he must oppose so drastic a change as they would cause until he had asked for and obtained the approval of those who had sent him here. He further suggested that this bill appeared to be an attempt to steal a march on the electors. I do not think he intended that statement offensively.
- I did not. I said, not that the bill appeared to be an attempt to steal a march on the electors, hut that I thought it amounted to that.
- The precise words used by the honorable member are immaterial, because I exonerate him from any intention to make a suggestion that was offensive to the Government.
- Hear, hear !
- I ask the right honorable member for North Sydney not to interject in a manner which has the effect of preventing the Prime Minister from getting a proper hearing.
- My interjection was " Hear, hear !"
- It was the tone in which it was uttered to which I take exception. I ask the right honorable member to give to the Prime Minister as courteous a hearing as he himself received.

- The honorable member for Fawkner said that, if there were no other reason, the absence of a mandate from the people would prevent him from supporting this measure. I suggest that his subsequent statements were illogical, for he told us that, after he first heard of the Government's proposals, he assured a deputation that he would keep an entirely open mind until he had learned the details of the proposal, and the arguments with which the Government supported the bill. If he felt so strongly on the subject of a mandate surely he was precluded from considering any argument as to the merits or demerits of the measure.
- The Prime Minister might have been able to persuade me that he had a mandate.

- The honorable member's attitude was illogical. The Government contends that it has a mandate from the people to take any action it thinks will contribute to the achievement of the policy upon which it was elected, namely, the improvement of the industrial conditions of the Commonwealth and the creation of better relations between employer and employee. The right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) took the greatest exception to what he described as my flouting of the platform of the Nationalist party. That criticism sounded strange, in view of the fact that in 1926 he supported similar action taken by me. In that year the platform of the Nationalist party provided for -

quote.para: Amendment of the Commonwealth Constitution and/or the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act and Industrial Peace Acts to limit the powers of the Commonwealth Arbitration Courts to matters that are really and not merely formally of an interstate character, the jurisdiction in other industrial matters to be left entirely to the State industrial tribunals.

speech.para: Notwithstanding that, the Government, in 1926, asked the people, by referendum, for increased constitutional powers, which would have given the control of industry to the Commonwealth instead of to the States.

talk.start.para: - Hear, hear ! That is the point.
- The platform of the Nationalist party, at that time, advocated the limitation of the powers of the Commonwealth, and the handing over to the States of the great majority of our industries.
- But the Commonwealth was to take the full power over those if did control.
- That is what is proposed in this bill.

- The fact is that in 1926 I appealed to the people by referendum on a proposal that was opposed to the policy of the Nationalist party, and in that appeal the right honorable member for North Sydney supported me. Since 1926 the platform of the Nationalist party has been amended; it now provides for the transfer of full industrial power to the Commonwealth. Yet, because on this occasion I am taking action which is in conflict with the platform of the party-
- The right honorable gentleman admits that?
- Certainly.
- That is a confession.

- Not at all. As Prime Minister of this country I am not restricted to action within the platform of any party. Honorable members opposite are in a different position. If they were in power, their Prime Minister would have to accept the dictation of persons outside this House. He would not be able to depart one iota from the programme laid down for him to follow. That is not the position of those in the Nationalist party ; it is certainly not a position which 1, as Prime Minister, would occupy.
- L'etat c'estmoi.
- When in 1926 I acted in opposition to the party platform, the right honorable gentleman had no criticism of my action to offer, but actually supported me.
- That is quite untrue.

- Yet now, in 1929, when he dissents from my action, departure from the strict platform of the party is in his eyes a crime of which no parliamentarian should be guilty. This matter of party loyalty came up for a great deal of discussion during the referendum campaign of 1926, and a spirited controversy on the subject was waged between Senator Massy Greene and Mr. Bavin, the Premier of New South Wales. I propose to read a passage from a statement by Senator Massy Greene which I regard as laying down the proper relations of a political leader to the party whose organization is supporting him in the electorates -

quote.para: We Nationalists hold that, unfettered by any conference resolutions or any printed programmes, our parliamentary leaders have the right to put their policy to the people when appealing for their support at a general election, and if they receive the endorsement of the people, the endorsement necessarily determines the policy of the National party on the issues of that election.

speech.para: The principle thus enunciated I shall certainly maintain so long as I am the political leader of any party.

Another criticism of the bill is that it will not remove duplication of jurisdiction. Honorable members on both sides of the House have declared that the Government is merely proposing to substitute six systems for the seven now existing, and that from this change little advantage can accrue. The honorable member for Fawkner, on this point also, was illogical. He said that we are getting rid of the federal system, but will still have six separate State systems in operation. The fact is that in any particular State only one arbitration system will operate and in a neighbouring State another system will operate; but that will not constitute duplication. Duplication arises when, on the State system of arbitration, a federal system is superimposed. The question we have to ask ourselves is - Will the individual worker or employer in his industry be governed by one system or two? By the action the Government is taking, duplication is being removed, because there will be only one control over each individual worker or employer. In the future only one authority will control each individual and each industry.

Then it was said that the action of the Government would destroy uniformity. Many speakers have assumed that uniformity exists at the present time, an assumption that must have been dissipated in the course of the debate. Accepting the statements of many honorable members, one would think that under the federal arbitration system there is a closer approximation to uniformity throughout Australia in regard to the basic wage than under the several State systems; that is not so. On the 1st August, 1929, the greatest divergence in the federal basic wage was the difference between ?4 Os. 6d. paid in Brisbane and ?4 14s. 6d. paid in Sydney, the figures for other capital cities being ?4 8s. 6d. for Adelaide, ?4 6s. 6d. for Perth and ?4 5s. 6d. for Hobart. Under. the awards of the States the greatest divergence is only that between ?4 5s. and ?4 7s., the former figure relating to New South Wales, and the latter to Western Australia. In South Australia the State basic wage is ?4 5s. 6d. and in Queensland ?4 5s. Therefore, so far as the basic wage is concerned, it cannot be contended that the removal of the Federal Arbitration Court will destroy uniformity. On the contrary, it will bring us nearer to uniformity. It must be remembered, too, that only twelve federal awards operate throughout Australia. In Queensland there are only 26 federal awards operating out of a total of 125.

It has been argued that where there is a federal award it overrides any State award, and therefore is the only award that is operating; but that .is not so. Where there is a federal award, it does not mean that the whole of the corresponding State award is superseded. It would, perhaps, be more satisfactory if that were the position. Unfortunately, however, only those parts of State awards that are inconsistent with a federal award are superseded, with the result that industries have to be carried on under both.
Probably that has contributed more than anything else to the difficulties in which industry finds itself at the present time.

A strong plea has been made for uniformity in the interest of interstate trade and interstate competition. But, if we wish to arrive at uniformity on that basis, we shall have to go much further than any one has yet suggested. There are other factors which interfere much more seriously with interstate competition, the outstanding one probably being the legislation passed by the State of New South Wales making provision for a 44-hour week. It is impossible at this stage to obtain uniformity in that regard. We should need to centralize all power and all control, making the Commonwealth Parliament the sole authority dealing with taxation and innumerable other matters which to-day are within the sovereign jurisdiction of the States, and in regard to which State laws vary greatly. The disappearance of the Federal Arbitration Court will not have the slightest effect upon that position.

talk.start.para: - In the event of the disappearance of the federal court will a federated industry be subject to. only one supreme control?

- I sincerely .trust that agreements on a federal basis will be arrived at voluntarily, and registered with the State authorities, so that, instead of awards being binding only upon the parties to them, as is the case to-day, there may be a common rule. The existence of the federal court has enabled many centralized federal unions to be built up, and those who are connected with them are determined, if possible, to keep them in existence. That is one of the principal reasons for the large influx of visitors into Canberra during the last few days. When this measure is passed, those federated unions will have an incentive to come to amicable and voluntary agreements with the employers, so as to preserve their federal character. They will be induced to do that because there will be no authority to control any award on a federal basis. Those who are associated with federal unions in an executive capacity will know that their positions will depend upon the retention of their federal character, consequently they will strive for voluntary co-operation.

speech.para: The question has been asked why the Government has changed its attitude, and the honorable member for Fawkner wished to know why no indication of the proposed change was given at the time of the last election, or when Parliament was sitting earlier in the year. The suggestion behind his remarks was that the circumstances are exactly the same now as they were in 1926, and as they were at the time when the last election was held, and when this Parliament sat in February and March. That is not so. During last Parliament the Arbitration Act was amended, the object being to make a final attempt to operate the system successfully. The Government endeavoured to obviate overlapping, and to make provision for a greater use of the machinery of conciliation. It aimed at giving to the general mass of trade unionists control over, their own organizations, and ensuring the observance of awards by both sides. The act, as amended, came into operation last year, just prior to the federal elections. . The Government hoped that both sides would obey awards and that the system would operate satisfactorily. On the eve of the election, however, trouble occurred on the waterfront. To deal with it, the Government had to make use of the trade and commerce power, and passed the Transport Workers Act. The conditions on the water-front were completely revolutionized. There had been outbreaks of violence in practically every capital city, accompanied by bomb outrages. We then saw to what lengths some persons were prepared to go in defiance of the law.

talk.start.para: - Is the right honorable gentleman blaming the trade unionists ?

- I am not blaming the unionists, but I am blaming many honorable members who sit opposite for not having had the courage to denounce what occurred. Later, a strike occurred in the ranks of the timber workers, in defiance of an award of the Arbitration Court, and there were attacks upon voluntary workers who were trying to carry on under the award. Intimidation and violence were resorted to in Sydney and Melbourne. Nefarious practices were indulged in by basher gangs. Having no police force in the various States, the Commonwealth had to rely upon the States to uphold its laws and prevent violence. In Sydney the spectacle was witnessed of a judge of the Arbitration Court being burnt in effigy.
- Hear, hear!

- I should have thought that the right honorable gentleman's sense of responsibility would have restrained him from making such an interjection. Further, when we were attempting to enforce a Commonwealth law in which provision was made for giving men engaged in industry an opportunity to determine the issue by means of a secret ballot, unionists were so intimidated that they could not express their opinions. The ballot-papers were burned, and the Commonwealth Government was powerless to prevent such action. Again, a new atmosphere was created in connexion with the timber workers' strike, and we found between 50 and 60, or possibly more, unions giving financial support to other unionists who were defying an award of the Arbitration Court. An overwhelming majority of the unionists who were contributing to strike funds in the form of levies were enjoying the benefits of awards of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. Last year the arbitration system was being defied and repudiated by Labour leaders. Responsibility for that rests upon honorable members opposite and their friends, who present a ludicrous spectacle now that they are trying to pose as the champions and apostles of the Arbitration Court and the observance of its awards. The people of Australia will not be deceived. That is one aspect of the altered situation that should not be overlooked by the honorable member for Fawkner. When we went to the electors it was hoped that the depression through which the country was then passing was merely temporary and such as we have many times experienced in the past, but that good seasons would be restored and our financial difficulties would disappear. The position has, however, become worse, and it is now clear that the depression is not temporary but is due to some fundamental defect in our economic life. That is clearly demonstrated in connexion with our loan finance. Honorable members are aware of the difficulties experienced by the

speech.para: Commonwealth and State governments in obtaining their necessary loan requirements. A big cut was made in the loan estimates last May, but the position has since become worse, and the Treasurer of the Commonwealth and the treasurers of the States have agreed to a further cut of 20 per cent. This rendered it necessary for definite action to be taken. A most important factor in this connexion is the drop in price of merino wool. The right honorable member for North Sydney asked, "Is there a cause for this? There might be something in support of the Prime Minister's policy if there had been a tremendous fall . in wool prices." Perhaps the right honorable gentleman is not aware that there has been a tremendous drop in the price of wool.

talk.start.para: - When did wool fall ?
- There was a drop recently in Adelaide.

- The right honorable member should be better informed on these matters. The price of wool started to fall about October last - when the price was lower than in the previous year - and by February the position was accentuated by progressive falls that represented a reduction of from 25 to 32 per cent., and at the last sale there was a further drop. The prices of wheat and wool - our two great staple commodities which constitute about 56 per cent, of our exports and upon which the whole of our finances are based - have dropped, and our position makes it clear that steps, will have to be taken to reduce the cost of production. Happily there has been a recovery in the price of wheat which dropped heavily, but we must recognize that that recovery is due to seasonal conditions in another part of the world., and we are not entitled to take it into consideration in studying our future position. All these things have happened during the last few months, and make it essential that we should look to the future. The only way in which we can hope to solve our problems is by reducing the cost of production. The right honorable member for North Sydney discounted practically everything I said on this subject, and stated that the cost of production could be reduced only by reducing wages. He pointed at me the finger of scorn, suggesting that I would reduce wages if I had the opportunity. But I would remind him of some of the things he has said and done. In 1922, when presiding at a conference of employers and employees convened to deal with the economic situation, he definitely stated that -

quote.para: They could not reduce prices unless they reduced wages. As prices climbed wages also climbed and that if prices had to come down wages must come down also.

speech.para: The right honorable gentleman said that I was in favour of reducing wages and that he would not be associated with any action of that kind. He then proceeded in what I would describe as an attempt to get the farmers on his side, But the. primary producers have had sufficient experience of the right honorable gentleman to prevent him from getting away with that. He asked : Would we reduce the price of wheat, meat and other commodities which the farmers are producing ? Do the farmers want a reduction of prices? The farmers have sufficient intelligence to know that before they would be asked to accept a reduction of the prices of their products the prices of the articles which they buy would have to come down.

There have been great developments throughout the world in recent years, and the cost of production in the Commonwealth can be reduced more by improving our methods and by close co-operation between the parties in industry than by reducing wages. If we can achieve that we shall derive a double benefit. We shall get increased purchasing power and at the same time a reduction of the cost of living. The right honorable gentleman asked, "How are you going to do it?" It will bc our endeavour to bring those engaged in industry closer together. What is being done in America ? In that country both sides realize that it is in their interest to increase production and efficiency, and under that system both parties benefit. The employers and the workers are beginning to realize that high wages increase the purchasing power of the people. . If we can get both parties together we may be able to achieve a great deal.

If this measure is passed by Parliament an opportunity will be provided for closer co-ordination by removing the duplication of systems that we have at present. If we can do that we will have an opportunity of securing industrial peace such as we nave never experienced before. If we can reduce the . cost of production without affecting our standards of living the purchasing power of the wages of the workers will be increased, and that will contribute towards a higher standard of living.

talk.start.para: - I desire to make a personal explanation. The right honorable the Prime Minister, when referring to certain bomb-throwing incidents, seemed to suggest that unionists were responsible. On behalf of the trade unionists I repudiate that statement. I objected to the right honorable gentleman's statement at the time, and he said, "I do not blame the unionists. You are responsible for the bomb throwing." I repudiate that statement, too, and throw the vile slander back into the face of the Prime Minister.
- I referred to certain bombing outrages, and the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Fenton) suggests that in my remarks I associated-
- Attributed--

- That I attributed these outrages to unionists. When he interjected to that effect I immediately said that I made no such suggestion. Nor did I say that honorable members opposite were responsible for the bombthrowing. But I blamed them for their lack of courage in not denouncing those who were responsible for the outrages. If any honorable member thought that my words implied something else, I have now repeated what I did say, and the misunderstanding or doubt should be completely removed.

- I also wish to make a personal explanation. The right honorable the Prime Minister (Mr. Bruce) referred to certain events which occurred in 1926 in relation to the proposed amendment of the Constitution, and to my attitude towards those proposals. The right honorable gentleman has completely misrepresented the facts. He seeks to draw an analogy between the present situation and that which existed at that time. No such analogy exists.
- Is the right honorable member . for North Sydney in order in making another speech?
- If he considers that he has been misrepresented he is entitled to make a personal explanation, as I understand he is now doing.

- The position in 1926 was that the Nationalist party believed in the amendment of the Constitution. I believed in an amendment of the Constitution, and when the right honorable gentleman made his proposals I supported them. He now says that the uses to which he proposed to put the extended powers which were asked for were con-, trary to the programme of the National party at that time. With that I had nothing to do. All I did was to support the endeavour to obtain wider powers, which was entirely in consonance with the programme of the National party. The present position is entirely different. Then the proposal was to extend the powers of the Commonwealth; now it is to make acomplete surrender of the powers of the Commonwealth in the industrial field.

- I feel that I am entitled to make a further personal explanation. I stated that, in 1926, the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes) supported the Government's proposal for a referendum, which was opposed to the platform of the Nationalist party. I am now again taking action which is opposed to that platform, and, on this occasion, the right honorable gentleman says that it is an outrageous thing for me to do; that he could not support me in it.

talker.name: BRUCE, Stanley
Mr BRUCE

talk.start.para: . - I should have explained the motion had I notmade a statement two days ago warning ho or able members that it was proposed to sit on Tuesday of next week and of the following week, but that this will not be the beginning of four days a week sittings. It is intended to continue with the committee stages of the Maritime Industries Bill next Tuesday, and the Government will also have to bring down a Supply Bill, which must be through the Senate by the 20th inst. The order of business next week will, therefore, be the committee stages of the Maritime Industries Bill for the first three days, and on Friday we shall probably have to go on with the Supply Bill, in order that it may go through another place in time.

talk.start.para: .- (By leave)- The Government has been giving very careful consideration to the question of the form of control that should obtain in the future in the Federal Capital Territory, having regard to the fact that the ' period of office of the Chief Commissioner will expire on the 2nd of November next. It is clear that in the immediate future it will not be practicable to proceed with the development of the capital city at the same rate as was necessary during the period of the transference of the Parliament and the first Government departments brought from Melbourne. During the past four years the annual expenditure within the Territory has averaged over ?1,800,000. In the year 1926-27, the expenditure amounted to ?2,437,607. For the year 1929-30, it is not possible to provide more than ?705,000. The extent of the curtailment of the constructional and developmental programme which this reduced provision will necessitate will be readily apparent. The Chief Commissioner, Sir John Butters, was among the first to realize that the altered situation would, not justify the continuance of the high salary hitherto associated with his position. He pointed out that his interest was largely concerned with the developmental side of the national capital, and intimated that he did not propose to ask for an extension of his appointment beyond the 2nd of November. In accepting the resignation of . Sir John Butters, the Government desires to place on record its deep appreciation of the services he has rendered to Canberra and its recognition of the efficiency, with which he has carried out, under conditions of great difficulty, the important and responsible duties assigned to him.

answer.para: The second Commissioner, Mr.Crosby Goold, whose services were generously loaned to the Government, by the City Council of Malvern for a period of twelve months, is desirous- of returning to his permanent position, and, in. response to his own request, the Government has agreed to the termination, of his engagement. In doing so, the Government desires to acknowledge the valuable assistance it has received from Mr. Goold during his term of office.

The retirement of. Sir John Butters and Mr.Crosby Goold, and the curtailment of the developmental expenditure has compelled Ministers to consider the form of the future government of the capital. After full . consideration; we have come to the conclusion that it would be' premature, and not- in the interests either of the Territory or of its residents, to alter the existing form of government during the present transitional period, and we propose to continue the Commission for a further period of at least twelve months. Parliament will then probably be in a better position to formulate more permanent proposals for the government of the Federal Capital Territory. It is accordingly proposed to appoint Mr. A. J. Christie, late Director of Post andTelegraphs, Brisbane, and now Chief Accountant of the Postmaster General's Department, as Chief Commissioner, and. Mr. J. S. Murdoch, Director General of Works, and Chief Architect for the Commonwealth, as second commissioner. It is proposed' that Mr. - Christie - shall be paid a salary of ?1,500 per annum, and Mr. Murdoch a salary of ?1,400 per annum. The Government feels that it is fortunate in being able to secure the services, of these two officers. In order to Observe the undertaking given last year that Parliamentwould have an . opportunity of considering within twelve months the question of the future government ofCanberra, I move - .
Debate (on motion by Mr. Theodore) adjourned.

talk.start.para: . - I promised the honorable member for Batman (Mr. Brennan) to have a short statement prepared with regard to the optional clause of Article 36 of the Statute of the International Court of Justice. The statement is as follows : -

quote.para: THE OPTIONAL CLAUSE OF ARTICLE 36 OF THE PERMANENT COURT OF INTERNATIONAL JUSTICE.
The' Optional Clause of Article 36 of the Statute of the Permanent Court of International Justice is as follows; -

The members of the League of Nations and the States mentioned in the . annex to the covenant may, either when signing or ratifying theprotocol to. which the present Statute is adjoined, or at a later moment, declare that they recognize as compulsory ipso facto and without special . agreement, in relation to any other member or State accepting the same obligation, the jurisdiction of the court In all or any of theclasses of legal disputes concerning:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The interpretation of a treaty.
b ) Any question of international law.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The existence of any fact which, if established, would constitute a breach of an international obligation.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The nature or extent of the reparation to be madefor the breach of an international obligation.

quote.para: The declaration referred to above may be made unconditionallyor on condition of reciprocity on the part of several orcertain members . or States, or for . a certain time.

In the . event of a . dispute, as towhether the court has jurisdiction, the matter . shall be settled by the decision of the court. 2: A country which accepts the optional clauseundertakes, therefore, to submit to the' Permanent Court for' decision all disputes falling within the four categories' that are mentioned above that may arise between it and any other country which also accepts the optional ' clause. -That is to say, when such a dispute arises, no question comes up of the parties discussing what methods of' settlement shall be adopted and the principles which shall be applied to the settlement of the dispute. The difference will automatically- go to the court at the instance of one orother of the disputants. - The last paragraph of Article 36 gives- the' court considerable power in determining whether or not a dispute is one which- compulsorily comes before the court.- The decision of thecourtthat the latter has jurisdiction is binding on- -the party which may- contest that jurisdiction in the particular case.
